State Law reference— Local government, O.C.G.A. tit. 36. 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters shall constitute and be designated "The Code of Sylvester, Georgia," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1965, § 1-1) 
State Law reference— Codification requirements, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall be observed. The rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provisions excluding such construction or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
Generally. 
(1)  The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter, when they shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade or with reference to such subject matter. In all interpretations the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the council, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(a), (b). 
(2)  All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the mayor and council may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and application of any provisions of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the other provisions of this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. The specific controls over the general. 
As soon as possible. The term "as soon as possible" means within a reasonable time, having due regard to all the circumstances. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(5). 
City. The term "city" means the City of Sylvester, Georgia. 
City council, council. The terms "city council" and "council" mean the city council of the City of Sylvester, Georgia. 
Code. The term "Code" means The Code of Sylvester, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. 
Computation of time. When a number of days is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, only the first or last day shall be counted. If the last day shall fall on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action shall fall on a public or legal holiday as set forth in state law, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following business day to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, an intermediate Saturday, Sunday and legal holiday shall be excluded in the computation. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(3). 
Conjunctions. Where a provision involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either…or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
(1)  The term "and" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. 
(2)  The term "or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination. 
(3)  The term "either…or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly, but not in combination. 
County. The term "county" means Worth County, Georgia. 
Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring a city officer or city employee to do some act, it is to be construed to authorize the officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act. 
Following. The term "following" means next after. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(8). 
Gender. Words of one gender includes all other genders. 
State Law reference— Gender, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(4). 
Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them, unless it is otherwise declared. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(5). 
Keeper, proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons, whether acting by themselves or acting as a servant, agent or employee. 
May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive. 
State Law reference— Definition of "may," O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(10). 
Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(11). 
Must. The term "must" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
Number. The singular and plural number include the other, unless expressly excluded. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(6). 
Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(12). 
O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. 
Officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies. Whenever reference is made to officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies by title only, the reference refers to the officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of the city. 
Owner. The term "owner," as applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or of a part of the building or land. 
Person. The term "person" includes any association, club, society, firm, corporation, partnership or body politic and corporate, as well as an individual. 
State Law reference— Definition of "person," O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(14). 
Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. 
Preceding. The term "preceding" means next before. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(15). 
Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(16). 
Public place. The term "public place" includes any place that the public is invited or permitted to go or congregate. 
Real property. The term "real property" include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
Signature, subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include the mark of an illiterate or infirm person. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(19). 
State. The term "state" means the State of Georgia. 
Street, road. The terms "street" and "road" include any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, lane, or viaduct and any other public highway in the city, including, but not limited to, the paved or improved surfaces thereof. 
Tenant, occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, include any person holding a written or oral lease of or who occupies the whole or a part of a building or land, either alone or with others. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future, as well as the past and present. 
State Law reference— Tense of words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(7). 
Week. The term "week" means seven days. 
Will. The term "will" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
Writing. The term "writing" includes printing and all numerals. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(23). 
Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(24). 
(Code 1965, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; effect of history notes; references in Code. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections or deemed to be any part of such sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Editor's notes, charter references, cross references, and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  All references to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections are to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
(Code 1965, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect or any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1965, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances or resolutions passed subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of these subsequent ordinances or resolutions, until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending those provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section ____________ of The Code of Sylvester, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows: …." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section not theretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "The Code of Sylvester, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ____________ , which section reads as follows: …." The new section may then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or other provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be, or by setting them out at length in the repealing ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1965, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  Supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances or resolutions and parts of ordinances or resolutions included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the person may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinances or resolutions inserted into the Code. 
(d)  In no case shall the person make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever except by ordinance of the mayor and council, which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1965, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty, unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section or it is clear from the context that it is the intent to impose the penalty provided for in this section upon the officer or employee. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided: 
(1)  A person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 180 days, or community service, or by any one or more of these punishments, subject to all limitations contained in the Charter. 
(2)  With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(3)  With respect to violations of this Code that are not continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(4)  In addition to the penalties provided in subsections (c)(1) through (3) of this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance shall be deemed a public nuisance, and may be abated by the city as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(d)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. 
(e)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief and by such other means as are provided by law. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent equitable relief. 
(Code 1965, § 1-9; Ord. No. 2003-15, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
State Law reference— Limitations on penalties, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2). 
Sec. 1-9. - Official city time. 
Time referred to in ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations of the city shall mean Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time as applicable, and acts and deeds of commission prohibited after a named hour or before a named hour shall be held and understood to mean such hour by Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time as appropriate. Wherever any reference to time is made in any of the ordinances and regulations of the city, such rules, ordinances and regulations are hereby amended to provide that the time provided therein shall be and is hereby made Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time as appropriate in accordance with the laws of this state. 
(Code 1965, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-10. - Severability of Code. 
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, that unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code, since they would have been enacted without the incorporation in this Code of the unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1965, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-11. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this Code, insofar as they are the same as those of ordinances and resolutions existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-12. - Prior offenses, penalties, contracts or rights not affected by adoption of Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance or resolution in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-13. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects the validity of any of the following ordinances or portions of ordinances, which ordinances or portions of ordinances continue in full force and effect to the same extent as if published at length in this Code: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness. 
(2)  Authorizing or approving any contract, deed, or agreement. 
(3)  Granting any right or franchise. 
(4)  Making or approving any appropriation or budget. 
(5)  Providing for salaries or other employee benefits not codified in this Code. 
(6)  Adopting or amending the comprehensive plan. 
(7)  Levying or imposing any special assessment. 
(8)  Dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, sidewalk or alley. 
(9)  Pertaining to subdivisions not codified in this Code. 
(10)  Dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision. 
(11)  Levying, imposing or otherwise relating to taxes not codified in this Code. 
(12)  Pertaining to zoning, including but not limited to the basic zoning ordinances and ordinances rezoning specific property or amending the zoning map. 
(13)  That is temporary, although general in effect. 
(14)  That is special, although permanent in effect. 
(15)  The purpose of which has been accomplished. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 2-1—2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MAYOR AND COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-31. - General rules for conduct of business. 
The following general rules for the government of the mayor and council, and the orderly dispatch of business are hereby adopted: 
Rule 1. Quorum. A quorum for business shall consist of two councilmembers and the mayor or other presiding officer. 
Rule 2. Meetings. The mayor and council shall hold a regular meeting on the first and third Mondays in each month, at the council chamber or such other place as may be designated on motion by the mayor and council, with the right to adjourn and continue any of such regular meetings to any other date and hour decided upon by the council; provided that any other date may be constituted a regular meeting day until further notice, but notice of such action must be given by one publication in a newspaper having a general circulation in the city, at least one day prior to the day set for such additional regular meetings. The mayor, or in his absence the mayor pro tem, may in his discretion, or upon the written request of at least two members of the council, call special or regular meetings. 
Rule 3. Notice of meetings. The city clerk, or any member of the police force designated for that purpose, shall notify each member of council personally, or by leaving written summons at their most notorious place of abode, of the date and hour of each special or extra meeting. The mayor, each member of council and all city officials are charged with notice of the hour and date of each regular meeting. 
Rule 4. Reading of minutes. The clerk shall read the minutes of the preceding meeting or meetings of the council at the subsequent regular meeting, in order that any clerical error or omission may be corrected or supplied. Such reading of the minutes may be omitted by unanimous consent of the councilmembers present. 
Rule 5. Yea and nay vote. Whenever any member shall require it, the yeas and nays of the members present shall be entered on the minutes on any question taken. 
Rule 6. Elections. It shall be necessary in all elections by the council that a majority of the vote of the members present shall be obtained before a candidate is elected. 
Rule 7. Accounts. 
Rule 8. Bids for public work. 
Rule 9. New rules; amendment of rules. Any proposition to alter or amend any of the rules of council, or to make new ones, shall be offered at least one meeting previous to its adoption, and can thereafter be adopted only by two-thirds of the members of the council present agreeing to such proposition. 
Rule 10. Business before or at extra or special meeting. The summons or notice of all extra or special meetings of the mayor and council shall express the cause thereof, and no business shall be brought before the council at any extra meeting which is not set forth in the summons or notice, unless a vote of two-thirds of the members of the council present shall determine otherwise. 
Rule 11. Meetings to be public. The doors of the council chamber shall on all occasions during the sittings or meetings of the council be kept open to the public, and shall only be closed upon a majority vote of the council resolving itself into a committee of the whole. 
State Law reference— Open and public meetings, O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. 
Rule 12. Introduction and passage of ordinances and resolutions. Upon their introduction, all ordinances and resolutions shall be read the first time by the clerk. The question then shall be "Shall this ordinance or resolution be committed or filed." As desired, the ordinance or resolution shall be either committed to the proper committee, or filed until its second reading, unless unanimous consent (where same is permissible) is requested or given for the immediate second reading of such ordinances or resolutions, as to which the question shall be upon the passage of the ordinance or resolution and put as follows: "All in favor of the passage will say aye, and all opposed, no." After a resolution or ordinance has been referred to a committee, and such committee has reported on the resolution or ordinance, the question shall be first, upon agreeing to the report of the committee, "All who favor the report of the committee, say aye, all opposed, say no," after which the question shall be upon the passage of the ordinance or resolution. 
Rule 13. Presiding officer vacating chair. When desirous of making a motion or debating a question, the mayor or other presiding officer shall appoint the mayor pro tem or, in his absence, a member of the council to preside. 
Rule 14. Councilmembers as sureties. The mayor and council shall not accept any bond provided to be given to the city upon which a member of the council is surety. 
Rule 15. Suspension of rules. The operation of any of the general rules of the council may be dispensed with by unanimous consent of the members present. 
(Code 1965, § 2-21) 
Sec. 2-32. - Rules of order; debate limited; filling in amounts and dates. 
(a)  Rules of order. In the conduct of meetings of the mayor and council, the provisions of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, governing parliamentary practice and procedure shall govern. 
(b)  Debate limited. No member of the council shall speak longer than 20 minutes, or more than twice on any question. 
(c)  Filling in amounts and dates. In filling in blanks representing amounts and dates, the largest sum and the longest time shall be put first. 
(Code 1965, § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-33. - Order of business. 
The order in which all business of and before the mayor and council shall be considered shall be as follows: 
(1)  Reading of minutes. 
(2)  Accounts. 
(3)  Reports of committees. 
(4)  Introduction of ordinances and resolutions and their first reading. 
(5)  Petitions and applications. 
(6)  Second reading of ordinances and resolutions and their passage. 
(7)  Unfinished business. 
(8)  New business. 
(9)  Miscellaneous matters. 
(Code 1965, § 2-23) 
Sec. 2-34. - Impeachment of mayor or councilmember. 
(a)  Grounds; vote required. The mayor or any member of the council who shall be guilty of malpractice in office, or any willful neglect or abuse of the powers and duties of such office, upon trial and conviction by a three-fourths vote of the whole body, the mayor voting except in case of his own impeachment, shall be dismissed from office. The trial shall be had and conducted as provided in this section. 
(b)  Complaints. All complaints against the mayor or any member of the council shall be in writing, setting forth distinctly the cause of the complaint and giving the names of witnesses thereto, if any, shall be directed to the mayor and council, and shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(c)  Procedure after complaint filed. Any person may file the complaint. Immediately upon receipt of the complaint the clerk shall notify the mayor, except in case of the mayor's impeachment, in which case the clerk shall notify the mayor pro tem, who shall call a meeting of the council. If at such meeting a majority of the council shall deem the complaint sufficient to authorize an investigation, they shall call a meeting for the trial of the member complained of, at the earliest date practicable. 
(d)  Articles of impeachment. If a trial is ordered, it shall be the duty of the city attorney to draw articles of impeachment, based upon the complaint, which shall be filed with the city clerk at least five days prior to the date set for the trial. Upon receipt of the articles of impeachment it shall be the duty of the city clerk to attach to the articles of impeachment a notice directed to the party complained against, which notice shall specify the time and place of trial, and command the appearance of the accused. The notice and copy shall be served upon the accused by the chief of police or any police officer, at least two days before the date of trial. 
(e)  Conduct of trial. The trial shall be conducted in the manner employed by the courts, both the mayor and the council and the accused having the right to introduce evidence and appear by counsel, it being the duty of the city attorney to act as prosecuting officer in such trials. 
(f)  Verdict and judgment. The council shall render a verdict upon each article of impeachment, to be followed by the judgment, which shall be entered by the city attorney upon the original articles and signed by the mayor or other presiding officer. The verdict and judgment shall be spread upon the minutes of the mayor and council. 
(g)  Subpoenas. It shall be the duty of the city clerk, on application, to issue under his seal subpoenas for witnesses, which shall be directed to the person desired, and shall state the time and place of trial; provided, however, that a verbal summons of any witness by any police officer shall be a valid summons, and it shall be the duty of the witness so summoned to appear. The mayor and council may compel attendance of witnesses by attachment and fine as in cases of contempt. 
(Code 1965, § 2-25) 
Sec. 2-35. - Powers and duties of mayor. 
(a)  Generally. The mayor shall have general supervision of the affairs of the city. He shall exercise general executive authority in the execution of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council, and see that all laws and ordinances are enforced, and shall see that all officers of the city faithfully discharge the duties required of them. He shall preside at all meetings of council, and shall have full power and authority to enforce the rules of order as adopted by council. 
(b)  Authority as judge. It shall be his duty also to preside in the municipal court in the absence of the judge and to try all offenders against city ordinances. 
(c)  Penal warrants. When acting as judge he shall, upon application of any person legally made, or upon information of any officer of the city, issue his warrant for the apprehension of any and all offenders against the laws of the state within the city, or against the city ordinances, and he shall examine such offenders at such time as he may direct, and if the facts authorize it, he shall bind over the offender for his appearance before the state tribunal to answer an indictment for such offense. 
(d)  Treasury warrants. It shall be the duty of the mayor to draw his warrant upon the city treasury for any and all appropriations made by the council, and for all amounts and sums of money which have been passed on and ordered by the council to be paid and for the payment of money from the treasury in all cases provided for by the ordinance. Such warrants shall be duly attested by the city clerk and, when properly receipted, shall be vouchers to the credit of the treasurer. 
(e)  Annual report. It shall be the duty of the mayor at the end of the municipal year to make and publish, in a city newspaper, a general report of the condition of city affairs, with such suggestions as he may deem proper for the good of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-36. - Powers and duties of mayor pro tem. 
The mayor pro tem, in the absence or disability of the mayor for any cause whatsoever, shall be clothed with all the rights and powers, and charged with all the duties, of the mayor, the mayor pro tem to act fully in the place or stead of the mayor. 
(Code 1965, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-37. - Authority of mayor as to city employees. 
(a)  Supervision. The mayor shall possess a superintending power over all salaried officials, all appointees of council, and all other agents or employees of the city. 
(b)  Action upon complaint. Upon any complaint against or for neglect of duty by such persons, he shall investigate the complaint, and if he deems it advisable or necessary, report the delinquent and the charge to the city council, and he shall also have the power to suspend any of such persons for any flagrant violation of duty rendering it necessary or advisable to take such steps, which suspension he shall report at the next regular meeting of the city council, or at an extra meeting called for that purpose, and the investigation or trial in the premises shall be conducted as provided for in this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 2-43) 
Sec. 2-38. - Compensation of mayor. 
The salary of the mayor shall be $600.00 per month, payable monthly. 
(Code 1965, § 2-28; 2001 Ga. Laws (Act No. 128), page 4168, § 3) 
State Law reference— Salary and compensation of members of governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4. 
Sec. 2-39. - Compensation of councilmembers. 
The compensation of the members of the council shall be $400.00 per month, payable monthly. 
(Code 1965, § 2-29; 2001 Ga. Laws, (Act. No. 128), page 4168, § 3) 
State Law reference— Salary and compensation of members of governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4. 
Sec. 2-40. - Weapons prohibited at meetings. 
As used herein, the term "weapon" shall have the same meaning as set out in O.C.G.A. § 16-11-125.1. 
As provided in O.C.G.A. § 16-11-127, and except as specifically exempted below, all individuals are prohibited from carrying or possessing a weapon at any meeting of the City of Sylvester City Council. This policy shall apply to all individuals, including city employees, officers, and council members. The restrictions contained herein shall also apply to all employees, including those employees that hold a Georgia weapons carry license. 
In order to enforce the provisions contained herein, and pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-11-127(e)(1), ingress into any building in which a meeting of the City of Sylvester City Council will be held shall be restricted and screened by security personnel for the time period spanning 30 minutes prior to the meeting until 15 minutes following the conclusion of the meeting. At least one such of security personnel shall be a certified peace officer pursuant to O.C.G.A. tit. 35, ch. 8. 
The restrictions contained herein shall not apply to the City of Sylvester Police Department or any city employee who is under the direct supervision of the Sylvester Police Chief. 
(Ord. No. 2014-10, § 1(Exh. A), 11-17-2014) 
Secs. 2-41—2-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance providing for salaries or other employee benefits not codified in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-13(5); plumbing inspector, § 22-151 et seq.; gas inspector, § 22-231 et seq.; emergency management director, § 34-33; appointment of judge; presiding officer, § 38-31; chief of police, § 62-71 et seq.; zoning administrator to enforce zoning ordinance, app. A, § 20-01. 
State Law reference— Powers relating to administration of municipal government, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-61. - Classification and pay plan; personnel rules and regulations. 
(a)  For the purpose of governing the administration of the compensation functions of the city, there will be adopted by resolution a classification and pay plan. 
(b)  For the purpose of governing the administration of the personnel policy function of the city, there will be adopted by resolution personnel rules and regulations. 
(c)  Such documents are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 80-3, §§ 1—3, 5-5-1980) 
Sec. 2-62. - Oath of office. 
All officers and employees of the city shall, before entering upon the discharge of their respective duties, take and subscribe the following oath, before some officer authorized by law to administer oaths: "I ____________ do solemnly swear that I will properly perform the duties of the office of ____________ in and for the City of Sylvester, to the best of my knowledge, skill and ability; so help me God." The oath shall be entered upon the minutes of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-38) 
Sec. 2-63. - Certificate; acceptance of office. 
All officers and employees of the city shall, before qualification, receive a warrant or certificate of election, which shall state that the election or appointment is made subject to the laws and ordinances of the city then or thereafter applicable to the office. The certificate or warrant shall be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk under the seal of the city. At the time of taking the oath of office the person to whom such certificate or warrant is issued shall, before being finally qualified, sign a written acceptance of the office, stating that the appointment is accepted subject to all rules, regulations, laws and ordinances of the city then or thereafter applicable. 
(Code 1965, § 2-42) 
Sec. 2-64. - Grounds for fine, suspension or removal from office. 
All municipal officers and employees shall be subject to fine, suspension or removal from office for malpractice, inattention, incompetency or insufficiency in the discharge of the duties of their respective offices, or insubordination. In addition to the causes for removal specified, intoxication at any time during the term of office by any salaried officer or employee shall be sufficient cause for discharge. All officers elected by the city council shall take and hold office with the understanding that this section is a part of their contract of employment. 
(Code 1965, § 2-44) 
Sec. 2-65. - Absence from duty. 
No officer or employee of the city shall absent himself from the city without the permission of the mayor or other officer acting in his stead, or of the head of the department to which the officer or employee may belong. Any officer or employee violating this section shall be subject to fine, suspension or dismissal, as provided in section 2-68. 
(Code 1965, § 2-45) 
Sec. 2-66. - Loans to employees from city funds. 
No loans to city employees from city funds shall be made. 
(Code 1965, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-67. - Return of property and materials upon leaving city employment. 
At any time an officer or employee of the city leaves the employ of the city, all property, equipment, materials and clothing furnished to him, and which are the property of the city, shall be returned to the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-48) 
Sec. 2-68. - Proceedings against city officers. 
(a)  Complaints. All complaints against municipal officers shall be in writing, setting forth distinctly the cause of complaint and giving the names of the witnesses thereto, if any, shall be directed to the mayor and council and shall be filed with the city clerk, who, immediately upon receipt of the complaint, shall notify the mayor, who shall call a meeting of the council. If at such meeting a majority of the council deems the complaint sufficient to authorize proceedings, they shall order the suspension of the officer complained of until a further meeting of the council, which shall be called at the earliest date practicable for the trial of the officer; provided that, if the mayor in his discretion deems it advisable, he may suspend the officer against whom complaint has been filed, until a meeting of the mayor and council can be had. 
(b)  Notice to defendant. Upon determination that the complaint is sufficient, it shall be the duty of the clerk to prepare a notice directed to the officer complained against, which notice shall specify the time and place of trial and command the appearance of the officer complained against. The notice shall be served upon such officer by any police officer of the city at least two days before the trial. 
(c)  Subpoenas. It shall be the duty of the clerk, on application, to issue under his hand and seal subpoenas for all witnesses, directing them to appear at any trial by the mayor and council; provided, however, that a verbal summons of any witness by any police officer shall be a valid summons. The mayor and council may compel the attendance of witnesses by attachment and fine for contempt. 
(d)  Trial procedure. Trial shall be conducted in the manner employed by the courts, both the city and the officer charged having the right to introduce evidence and appear by counsel, it being the duty of the city attorney, except in cases of his own trial, to act as prosecuting officer. The council may either suspend, dismiss or fine any officer whom it may, upon such trial, deem guilty of any of the charges preferred. 
(e)  Verdict and judgment. The council shall render a verdict, which shall be followed by the judgment of the council, to be entered by the city attorney upon the complaint. The verdict shall be signed by the mayor, and the verdict and judgment shall be spread upon the minutes of the council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-49) 
Secs. 2-69—2-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER 

Sec. 2-91. - Position established; appointment; removal. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of city manager. 
(b)  The appointment of a city manager will require the affirmative vote of at least three members of the council or two councilmembers and the mayor, but the affirmative vote of at least four councilmembers or three councilmembers and the mayor shall be required for firing or removal from office of the city manager. 
(c)  Neither the mayor nor a member of the council shall be appointed city manager or acting city manager during the term of office for which he was elected or for a period of one year thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 92-2, § 1, 8-17-1992) 
Sec. 2-92. - Compensation. 
The city manager shall be paid an annual salary to be fixed by the mayor and council. The annual salary shall be paid in monthly installments. 
(Ord. No. 92-2, § 2, 8-17-1992) 
Sec. 2-93. - Qualifications. 
The city manager shall be chosen by the mayor and council solely upon the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications with special reference to his special experience in, or knowledge of, accepted practice in respect to the duties of his office, as set forth in this division. A bachelor's degree in public or business administration is required and a master's degree in public or business administration is preferred. 
(Ord. No. 92-2, § 3, 8-17-1992) 
Secs. 2-94—2-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-121. - Duties as to council; custody of records; custody of city seal. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep minutes and records of the council, to keep an index to the record and enter alphabetically therein the acts and doings of the council, and to have the custody and charge of all records, books and papers belonging to the city. All deeds, leases and other instruments executed by the council shall be attested by him, and he shall affix thereto the official seal of the city, of which seal he shall be custodian. 
(Code 1965, § 2-50(a)) 
Sec. 2-122. - Issuance of licenses; ordinance book; accounts; finances. 
(a)  The city clerk shall issue all licenses granted in accordance with city ordinances or authorized by the council, and keep a record of such licenses. He shall keep an ordinance book, in which he shall record or have printed the city ordinances, properly indexed. It shall be his duty to issue all executions, as required by the ordinances or authorized by the council. He shall keep an execution docket in which he shall enter all executions issued by him. He shall keep a book in which he shall enter all orders or warrants of the mayor and council, and shall keep a record of all bonds issued by authority of the council, and all other obligations entered into and collected by the city council, that a fair exhibit may be at any time made of the liabilities of the city. He shall deposit immediately all money coming into his hands belonging to the city, and shall open an account with the chief of police, charging him with the amount of all executions and claims of the city which the chief of police is liable and bound to collect for the city, filing his receipts as vouchers for the council and in settlement of his accounts. He shall report upon the condition of these accounts as often as may be required by the council. He shall be charged with the gross amount of the city tax digest, and shall specify the time allowed by ordinance for collecting the same. 
(b)  He shall keep a record book in which he shall enter, under the appropriate heads, the receipts and disbursements of his office, keeping separate accounts for the funds specially appropriated and their disbursements; also, separate accounts showing the different sources of revenue, that a true statement of the finances, as well as the condition of the different funds, will, at any time, appear at a glance. It shall be his duty to receive all moneys and securities belonging to the city, whether notes, bonds, mortgages, leases, stocks or other evidence of debt, for which he shall properly receipt, to be filed with the city clerk as vouchers for the council in their settlement of his accounts. All moneys arising from fines, or from other sources, collected by any other officer of the city or member of the council, shall be delivered to the city clerk, and he shall receipt therefor in like manner. He shall receive no funds that are not lawful, solvent or current at the time, unless specially ordered to do so by the council. He shall so keep the funds as to guard the city from loss through any possible contingency of fire, theft or otherwise. His books, papers, vouchers and other documents of his office shall be subject, at all reasonable times, to the inspection of the mayor and council, or any member thereof. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-50(b), 2-52(b)) 
Sec. 2-123. - Inventory of city property. 
The city clerk shall keep in some convenient form and manner a list or inventory of the effects and assets, books, furniture and property of the city, designating in his report thereon to the council the uses for which they are employed, and the general conditions thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 2-50(c)) 
Sec. 2-124. - Inspection of clerk's records. 
The books and records of the city clerk shall at all reasonable times be subject to the inspection of the mayor and council, or any member thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 2-50(d)) 
Sec. 2-125. - Delivery of records to successor in office; final settlement of accounts. 
(a)  Before retiring from office, the city clerk shall turn over to his successor in office all the books, records, papers, maps, and vouchers of the city and the seal of the city, taking his receipt therefor, which shall be recorded by his successor, for all of which articles coming into the hands of the clerk he shall be held accountable. 
(b)  Immediately upon the expiration of his term of office he shall surrender all money remaining in his hands, notes, bonds, and other evidences of debt due the city, or assets of any kind whatever that may come into his hands during his term of service, not otherwise accounted for, for which his successor shall give proper vouchers, which vouchers he shall file in final settlement of his accounts with the city council. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-50(e), 2-52(c)) 
Sec. 2-126. - Records retention schedule. 
(a)  Those local government records retention schedules as promulgated by the Office of the Secretary of State of the State of Georgia, as amended from time to time, and found on the following website: 
http:/sos.georgia.gov.archives/pdf/state_spec_reports/Local_Government_Schedules_Nov_07.pdf 
are hereby approved and adopted as Records Retention Schedules for the City of Sylvester. 
(b)  The city clerk is responsible for records management activities and is charged with the responsibility for directing and coordinating all records management matters. 
(c)  No record shall be destroyed except in accordance with approved retention schedules. 
(d)  Whenever any records are destroyed, a certificate of destruction shall be prepared and forwarded to the city clerk who shall show the type of records destroyed, the approved retention schedule number, the dates covered, and the volume destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 2004-03, §§ 1—4, 2-16-2004; Ord. No. 2008-14, §§ 1—4, 10-20-2008) 
Secs. 2-127—2-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-151. - Qualifications. 
No one shall be elected city attorney who has not been duly admitted to the State Bar of Georgia. 
(Code 1965, § 2-51(b)) 
Sec. 2-152. - Compensation. 
The city attorney shall receive such salary as may be prescribed by resolution of the mayor and council, and the salary shall not be increased or diminished during his term of office. 
(Code 1965, § 2-51(c)) 
Sec. 2-153. - Representation of city in legal actions. 
The city attorney is hereby appointed as the legal representative of the city in all cases of litigation brought by or against the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-51(a)) 
Sec. 2-154. - Additional duties. 
The city attorney shall be the legal adviser of the city when called on for opinions from the proper heads of the different departments of the city, provided he may demand that the question proposed shall be made in writing. He shall be under no duty to act until the different matters properly referable to the legal department are referred to him for attention by the respective heads of the departments of the city. He shall keep a record of all opinions rendered by him and of all cases brought by or against the city. On request of the mayor and council, or any member thereof, it shall be his duty to draft any ordinance or resolution for introduction, and in such cases he may demand that the request be in writing, setting forth in detail the subject matter of the proposed legislation. When requested, he shall attend all committee or commission meetings of the city. In addition to the duties prescribed in this section, he shall perform such other duties as are by ordinance imposed upon his office. 
(Code 1965, § 2-51(d)) 
Secs. 2-155—2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 94. 

Sec. 2-181. - Compensation. 
The salary of the superintendent of public works shall be such as may be prescribed by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-53(a)) 
Sec. 2-182. - Duties generally; police powers. 
The superintendent of public works shall perform such duties as are prescribed by lawful order of the mayor and council, and he shall be clothed with police authority to arrest for violations of all regulations pertaining to his office. 
(Code 1965, § 2-53(c)) 
Sec. 2-183. - Property inventory. 
(a)  The superintendent of public works shall make and keep a correct inventory of all property belonging to the city and coming into his charge, and shall make an annual report of such property, which report shall show: 
(1)  The number of articles (named) on hand at the date of the last report; 
(2)  The number of articles (named) received since the last report; 
(3)  The number of articles (named) at the date of the present report; and 
(4)  A note of the condition of the property on hand. 
(b)  The report shall show all property, or account for its absence. On retiring from office he shall take, and file with the city clerk, a receipt from his successor for all property in his hands belonging to the city, which receipt shall be credited on his account with the city, and all property unaccounted for shall be charged to him at the cost price, and, unless paid for, suit shall be entered on his bond for the amount due. 
(Code 1965, § 2-53(d)) 
Secs. 2-184—2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - BONDS 

Sec. 2-201. - Terms; payment of cost. 
All officers and employees of the city shall give good and solvent bond, acceptable to the mayor and council, payable to the mayor and his successors in office, for the benefit of the city, and for the use and benefit of the public, to secure and indemnify the city and the public for any loss or damage by reason of their default, misfeasance, malfeasance, nonfeasance or negligence. No officer or employee shall be qualified until such bond has been given and approved, and the bond shall be filed with the clerk and safely kept by him. The amounts of the bonds shall be as in this Code provided for the respective officers, and the cost thereof shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-39) 
Sec. 2-202. - Amount. 
Employees of the city shall be bonded in the following amounts: 
(1)  City clerk: $15,000.00. 
(2)  Employees in city office: $5,000.00. 
(3)  Chief of police: $5,000.00. 
(4)  City manager: $100,000.00. 
(Code 1965, § 2-40) 
Sec. 2-203. - Authority to increase amount of bond or require additional security. 
All bonds given by officers and employees of the city may, by a majority of the council whenever the interests of the city shall require it, be required to be increased in amount, or additional security may be required. In case any officer elected shall fail or refuse to give bond, or shall fail to give additional security or to increase the amount of his bond, his office shall be declared vacant, and the vacancy shall be filled in the manner prescribed by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 2-41) 
Secs. 2-204—2-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - SOCIAL SECURITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Social security coverage for employees of political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 47-18-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-221. - Authorized. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city, at the earliest date possible under the agreement entered into by the state and the federal Social Security Administration, to extend to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this division, the benefits of the system of Old Age and Survivors Insurance as authorized by the federal Social Security Act, the state enabling act, and amendments thereto. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 2-64) 
Sec. 2-222. - Execution of necessary documents. 
The mayor shall execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia for coverage of city employees and officials as provided for in section 2-221, to include any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner by such law provided, namely, firefighters. 
(Code 1965, § 2-65) 
Sec. 2-223. - Amendment to original plan. 
(a)  The mayor or other designated official of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute an agreement amending the original plan and agreement with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia, providing for the release of social security escrow deposits. 
(b)  The city agrees to abide by the rules and regulations of the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia, referred to in this section as the "state agency," in regard to collections from city employees and in making reports and payments to the state agency. 
(c)  The city hereby pledges an amount which it would receive in state grant funds as security for assurance that it will make collections from its employees, submit required reports, and remit payments to the state agency as agreed to in its plan of coverage of employees for social security benefits. The city further agrees that if the amount of state grant funds which it is entitled to receive in a calendar year is less than its annual payment to the state agency, as may be determined by the state agency, then the city shall deposit in escrow, when so notified in writing by the state agency and in accordance with its rules and regulations, an amount which, when added to the city's state grant funds, would total an amount sufficient to meet its obligations of reporting and remitting collections to the state agency. 
(Code 1965, § 2-65.1) 
Editor's note— The agreement mentioned in the above section is on file in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 2-224. - Withholding from salaries and wages. 
Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in section 2-221 are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. 
(Code 1965, § 2-66) 
Sec. 2-225. - Appropriations by city. 
There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions, administrative expenses, and guaranty fund to ensure that the state will not incur any debt or loss as a result of the agreement referred to in section 2-221. Such funds shall be paid over to the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia in accordance with regulations established by such agency. 
(Code 1965, § 2-67) 
Sec. 2-226. - Records and reports. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports pursuant to this division as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 2-68) 
Sec. 2-227. - Limitation on coverage. 
There is hereby excluded from this division any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 2-69) 
Secs. 2-228—2-250. - Reserved.

Cross reference— Emergency management council, § 34-32. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-251—2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLANNING COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-02, section 3, adopted Jan. 1, 2003, designated the "Worth County Planning Commission" as the planning commission for the City of Sylvester. 
State Constitution reference— Home rule for municipalities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV. 
State Law reference— Municipality coordinated and comprehensive planning, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-271. - Created. 
In order to guide and accomplish a coordinated and harmonious development of the city which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote public health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity, and the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, the Sylvester Planning Commission, referred to in this article as the planning commission, is created and established as authorized by the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-272. - Membership. 
The planning commission shall consist of five members. Each council member shall appoint one member who shall be a resident of the council member's election district. The mayor shall appoint an at-large member who shall be a resident of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-273. - Terms. 
The terms of the members of the planning commission shall be four years, except that in the appointment of the first planning commission, the members from Districts 1 and 2 shall be appointed for a term of one year, the members from Districts 3 and 4 shall be appointed for a term of two years, and the at-large member shall be appointed for a term of three years. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-274. - Vacancies; removal. 
Any vacancy in membership of the planning commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by the city council, which shall have the authority to remove any member for cause on written charges, after written notice and a public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-275. - Compensation; expenses. 
The members of the planning commission shall receive such compensation as determined by the mayor and council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-276. - Organization. 
The planning commission shall elect its chairman and vice chairman from among its appointed members. The term of chairman and vice chairman shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-277. - Rules of procedure. 
The planning commission rules of procedure shall be in accordance with the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-278. - Meetings; when held; records public. 
(a)  The planning commission shall meet on the first Thursday of each month, or at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the chairman or the board may determine. 
(b)  Except for lawful executive sessions, all meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public, and all records of the planning commission shall be public record. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-279. - Expenditures. 
The expenditures of the planning commission shall be within the amounts appropriated by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Sec. 2-280. - Powers and duties. 
From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then the planning commission shall have all the powers, duties, and responsibilities set forth in the Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2006-06, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 5-15-2006) 
Secs. 2-281—2-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMUNITY RELATIONS COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-286. - Established. 
There is hereby established in and for the City of Sylvester the Sylvester Community Relations Commission to be composed of eleven members who shall be residents of the city. Each council member shall appoint two members to the commission and the mayor shall appoint three members. Emphasis in the selection of members shall be upon obtaining a group diverse with respect to race, religion, economic status, type of employment, age, national origin, sex, geographic location, and political party affiliation. Each of the eight members appointed by the city council members shall be appointed to an initial term of two years and until a successor is appointed and qualified. The three members appointed by the mayor shall each be appointed for an initial term of one year and until a successor is appointed and qualified. After initial appointments have been served, terms shall be two years each in duration and until successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 2004-15, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 2-287. - Officers appointed. 
The chairman of the Sylvester Community Relations Commission shall be appointed by the mayor of the City of Sylvester annually from the members of the community relations commission, said chairman to serve for one calendar year or until a successor has been appointed and qualified. The Sylvester Community Relations Commission shall appoint such additional officers as it shall deem appropriate and necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2004-15, § 2, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 2-288. - Duties, powers, and functions. 
The Sylvester Community Relations Commission shall have the following duties, powers, and functions: 
(1)  To encourage, promote, and develop fair and equal treatment and opportunity for all persons regardless of race, color, creed, sex, or national origin; 
(2)  To coordinate and assist local governmental agencies on human relations in their efforts to promote better relations; 
(3)  To cooperate with community, professional, civic, and religious organizations and federal, state, county, and municipal agencies in the development of public information programs, leadership, and activities in the interest of equal opportunity and treatment of all racial, religious, and ethnic groups; 
(4)  To conduct research projects and studies and to make reports on race relations in the city; 
(5)  To annually and periodically report to the mayor and city council of the city on the activities of the Sylvester Community Relations Commission; 
(6)  To adopt such rules and regulations as are necessary to govern the proceedings of the Sylvester Community Relations Commission and to conduct all meetings in accordance with said rules and regulations; 
(7)  To investigate, study, and inform the public as to any complaints received concerning the above areas; 
(8)  To provide a forum for airing community problems and grievances. 
(Ord. No. 2004-15, § 3, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 2-289. - Compensation. 
No member of the Sylvester Community Relations Commission shall receive any compensation for his or her activities as a member of said body. The Sylvester Community Relations Commission shall submit an annual budgetary request to the governing authority of the city. The governing authority of the city is hereby authorized to appropriate funds for use by the Sylvester Community Relations Commission, as provided herein 
(Ord. No. 2004-15, § 4, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 2-290. - Attendance at meetings. 
The absence of any member from three consecutive meetings of the Sylvester Community Relations Commission shall automatically create a vacancy, which shall be filled by each official or his/her successor who originally made the appointment for the unexpired term of the member whose absences created the vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 2004-15, § 5, 12-20-2004) 
Secs. 2-291—2-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-13(1); any ordinance making or approving any appropriation or budget saved from repeal, § 1-13(4); taxation, ch. 86. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-341. - Designation of city depositories; bond. 
One or more state depositories in the city shall be by the mayor and council designated as city depositories, and it shall be the duty of the city clerk to deposit all funds of the city coming into his hands in such state depositories. If more than one state depository is designated, he shall deposit such funds in each in such proportion as shall be designated by the mayor and council. Such state depositories shall first enter into a bond with good security to be approved by the mayor and council, conditioned to safely keep all money and assets as provided in this section, and to promptly pay over such money and assets upon proper warrant at any time such money and assets may be called for. The condition to safely keep and promptly pay over shall be without exception of fire, burglary, storm, accident or casualty of any kind whatsoever, and all failure of such state depositories, and shall be an obligation to safely keep and promptly pay over, absolutely and at all events. 
(Code 1965, § 21-1) 
State Law reference— Deposit of funds in banks or depositories, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-10 et seq. 
Sec. 2-342. - Establishment of funds for city monies. 
At its first meeting in January each year, the mayor and council shall establish and designate the various funds in the city depositories for the receipt of city monies, and shall prescribe the purposes thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 21-2) 
Sec. 2-343. - Establishment of system of accounting. 
The system of accounting and bookkeeping of the city shall be such as shall be prescribed and from time to time readjusted by the mayor and council. The city clerk shall purchase such books, records, stationery and forms as shall be prescribed for such purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 21-3) 
State Law reference— Accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-344. - Execution and contents of treasury warrants. 
All warrants drawn on city funds shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk, shall be dated, and shall show by what authority, and for what purpose drawn, and the particular fund out of which it is to be paid. The warrants shall be consecutively numbered and detached from stubs of like number showing a brief record of the warrant. When paid and returned, the warrants shall be kept and preserved by the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 21-4) 
Sec. 2-345. - Warrants for bills of departments. 
Separate warrants shall be issued for bills for each department, in order that they may be more easily checked, and merchants and others shall render their accounts against the city for each department separately and separate warrants shall be drawn by the mayor and clerk for each bill. 
(Code 1965, § 21-5) 
Sec. 2-346. - Disbursement of city funds restricted. 
No officer of the city shall disburse city funds, except the city clerk with the consent of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 21-6) 
Sec. 2-347. - Audits. 
It shall be the duty of the mayor and council to have a complete audit of all the books and accounts of the city at least once in each year, and to make certain that all receipts and disbursements are proper, and according to law and city ordinances on the subject. 
(Code 1965, § 21-7) 
Secs. 2-348—2-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MUNICIPAL BONDS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal bonds, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-38-1 et seq., 36-82-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-371. - Action preliminary to bond ordinance. 
Preliminary to any issue of bonds by the city, the proposal for the issue shall be referred to the mayor and council, who shall give diligent consideration to the proposal, and no ordinance providing for a bond issue shall be in order until such action on the preliminary proposal has been taken by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 21-74) 
Sec. 2-372. - Tax levy for retirement of bonds. 
For all bonds issued by the city there shall be levied and assessed, in addition to all other taxes, for each year, during the term for which the bonds run, an ad valorem tax upon all taxable property in the city, in such amount as will be sufficient to pay the bonds, principal and interest, at their respective dates of maturity, such tax to be promptly collected in each and every year, in the same manner as other city taxes. When collected, such tax shall be turned into the sinking fund, and appropriated as provided in this division. 
(Code 1965, § 21-75) 
State Constitution reference— Levy of taxes to pay bonds, Ga. Const. art. IX, § V, ¶ VI. 
State Law reference— Municipal bonds, O.C.G.A. § 36-38-1 et seq.; local government bonds, O.C.G.A. § 36-82-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-373. - Bond book. 
The city clerk shall keep a bond book with a complete and detailed statement and description of each bond issued, and such book shall at all times show the status of each bond. 
(Code 1965, § 21-76) 
Sec. 2-374. - Registration authorized. 
All bonds evidencing the indebtedness of the city may, upon written application or request of the holders of such bonds, or any of them, be registered, both as to principal and interest, or as to principal only. 
(Code 1965, § 21-77) 
Sec. 2-375. - Registration book. 
The city clerk shall procure and provide a suitable book, to be kept on file in his office, in which, upon written application and presentation of a city bond by the holder thereof, he shall enter a description of each bond so presented, stating the number, of what issue, the amount, the date issued, the date of maturity, the rate and maturity of interest, the date and number of the ordinance authorizing, how and where payable both as to principal and interest, by whom signed, and such other data as may be necessary for a ready identification of the bonds registered, together with the name of the person registering the bond, the capacity in which such person holds the bonds, for whose benefit the bond is registered, to what extent the bond is registered, or whether registered as to principal or principal and interest. 
(Code 1965, § 21-78) 
Sec. 2-376. - Application for registration. 
In order that city bonds shall be registered as provided in this division, the holders shall first make written application for such registration, presenting therewith the bonds desired to be registered, which application shall be made to the city clerk, and shall state the number of the bonds presented, of what issue, the date, the amount, when due and to what extent the bonds shall be registered. The application shall be signed by the applicant, who, if holding a bond in any capacity other than for himself, shall sign the application in the name of the party for whose benefit he holds the bond, stating the capacity in which he signs and attaching proof thereof, the sufficiency of which proof shall be determined by the city attorney. 
(Code 1965, § 21-79) 
Sec. 2-377. - Statement of registration. 
After any city bond shall have been registered it shall be the duty of the city clerk to stamp, print or write upon each bond a statement of the registration in substantially the following form: 
Registered by ____________ nonnegotiable, as to principal and interest only to ____________ of ____________ at ____________ or his legal representatives, at ____________ . 
This day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 20 ____________ . 

 
(Code 1965, § 21-80) 
Sec. 2-378. - Endorsement of registration upon bonds. 
If any city bond is registered both as to principal and interest, the clerk shall destroy the coupons and stamp, write or print upon each bond a statement, properly dated, of the amount and value of such coupons, and that the interest, at the rate and on the date as provided by the coupons, will be paid only to the holder or his legal representatives, or make the entry as provided for in section 2-377 or an entry to the same effect, upon each coupon and leave them attached, either as may be desired by the holder. 
(Code 1965, § 21-81) 
Sec. 2-379. - Transfer of registered bonds. 
In order to transfer any city bond which has been registered under this division, the holder thereof shall present the bond to the city clerk and shall authorize such transfer in writing, giving the name of the transferee, the number of the bond, the issue, and the maturity. Such authority shall be signed and acknowledged in the presence of a notary public, or some other officer authorized by law to administer oaths, and such notary public or other officer shall certify, in writing and under the seal of his office, that such authority was signed and acknowledged in his presence. In addition to giving such written authority, the holder shall enter a statement of the transfer on the face of each bond, properly dated and signed. Thereupon the clerk shall enter the transfer of each bond opposite the original entry of registration in the book provided for in this division, giving the name of the transferee and the date of transfer, and shall always enter each transfer on each bond over his official signature. The transferee may thereafter, in the manner prescribed in this section, also transfer such bond. 
(Code 1965, § 21-82) 
Sec. 2-380. - Rendering registered bond negotiable. 
When any city bond is registered as to the principal only, the bond may be made fully negotiable by transfer in the manner prescribed in section 2-379, in the general terms "to bearer." When so done, the clerk shall cancel all formal entries on the face of the bond. 
(Code 1965, § 21-83) 
Sec. 2-381. - Sinking fund. 
(a)  Establishment; use. All taxes collected for the payment of the principal and interest of city bonds shall be kept as a separate fund, known as the "sinking fund," and under no circumstances shall such fund be paid out for any purpose other than the payment of interest and principal on the bonds for which it was collected, or for the purpose of investment as provided by law and city ordinances. If an officer honors or pays any warrants on such fund for any purpose other than those named in this section, he shall be guilty of malpractice and liable to impeachment. 
(b)  Investment; reports. The custodian of the sinking fund shall promptly make arrangements for the investment of the principal of the sinking fund, as is required by law, upon approval of such arrangements by the mayor and council. The custodian shall make a report every six months, showing in detail the conditions of the sinking fund and the investments made therefrom. 
(Code 1965, § 21-84) 
State Constitution reference— Sinking fund required, Ga. Const. art. IX, § V, ¶ VI. 
State Law reference— Deduction of sinking fund in computing bonded indebtedness, O.C.G.A. § 36-82-8. 
Secs. 2-382—2-410. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

State Law reference— Management and disposition of property, O.C.G.A. §§ 6-30-2, 36-37-6. 

Sec. 2-411. - Record of real estate; approval of title prior to purchase of real estate.

It shall be the duty of the city attorney to abstract and pass upon the title to all real estate purchased by the city, and no title shall be accepted without his written approval of the title to such real estate. 
(Code 1965, § 2-2) 
Sec. 2-412. - Sale of real estate. 
All sales of real estate by the city shall be authorized by ordinance of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-413. - Sale of personal property. 
No personal property belonging to the city shall be sold except upon authority, by ordinance, from the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-4) 
Sec. 2-414. - Inventories of personal property. 
Every city official or employee charged with the keeping of any personal property shall submit an accurate inventory and return thereof annually to the mayor and council, on the first Monday in each year, showing the amount, disposition and condition of the property, and it shall be the duty of the mayor and council from time to time to cause inspection of such property. 
(Code 1965, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-415. - Purchase of personal property. 
All purchases of personal property shall be authorized by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-6) 
Sec. 2-416. - Use of city machinery. 
No machinery belonging to the city may be loaned to anyone without special permission from the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 2-7) 
Sec. 2-417. - Authorizing the purchase, acquisition, construction, etc. of telecommunication systems and facilities. 
The mayor and council shall have the power to provide for the purchase, acquisition, construction, extension, operation, and maintenance of telecommunication systems and facilities both within and without the corporate limits of the city and to furnish telecommunication services to consumers for profit both within and without the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2004-05, s; 1, 5-17-2004) 
Secs. 2-418—2-610. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PROCUREMENT 

Sec. 2-611. - Definitions. 
When used in this article, the following words, terms, and phrases, and their derivations shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bid bond means a bond with good and sufficient surety or sureties for the faithful acceptance of the contract payable to, in favor of, and for the protection of the governmental entity for which the contract is to be awarded. 
City means the City of Sylvester, Georgia. 
City council means the governing body of the city. 
City manager means the city manager of the city. 
Competitive sealed bid means a method of soliciting contracts whereby the award is based upon the lowest responsive responsible bid in conformance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-91-21. 
Competitive sealed proposal means a method of soliciting contracts whereby the award is based upon criteria identified in a request for proposals in conformance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-91-21. 
Construction means the process of building, altering, improving, or demolishing any public structure or building, or other public improvements of any kind to any public real property.
