ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 22-31. - Applicability. 
For purposes of this article, the term "building" shall include structures of whatsoever character erected, repaired or altered within the city. It shall be unlawful to construct, erect, add to, alter or repair any building or structure within the city except in the manner and according to the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 5-10) 
Sec. 22-32. - Designation of building code. 
The building code adopted in section 22-1 shall be known and may be cited as "The building code of the City of Sylvester, Georgia." 
(Code 1965, § 5-2) 
Sec. 22-33. - Fire districts. 
For the purposes of the building code adopted in section 22-1, two fire districts or zones are hereby established, as follows: 
(1)  First fire district. The first fire district or zone shall consist of those areas of the city designated as commercial and/or manufacturing districts in the zoning ordinance and upon the zoning map of the city. The first fire district may also be designated the "fire zone," or the "inner fire limits," and whenever in this Code any one or more such terms are used they shall be construed to refer to the first fire district described in this subsection. 
(2)  Second fire district. The second fire district or zone shall consist of all of the area of the city outside the first fire district described in subsection (1) of this section. The second fire district may also be designated and referred to as the "outer fire limits." 
(Code 1965, § 5-3) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. 
Sec. 22-34. - Performing work without permit. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, repair or alter or to assist in the erection, repairing or altering of any building in the city without a permit. 
(Code 1965, § 5-9) 
Sec. 22-35. - Additions and alterations. 
Any addition or alteration made for any purpose in, to or upon any building or structure, except necessary repairs not affecting the external or party walls, chimneys, stairways or height of a building, shall, to the extent of such alteration or addition, be subject to the requirements of this article and the building code adopted in section 22-1. 
(Code 1965, § 5-11) 
Sec. 22-36. - Schedule of permit fees. 
No building permit shall be issued by the city until there has been paid to the city by the individual, firm, or corporation applying for such permit to erect, repair, or alter any building in the city a permit fee based on the following schedule: The fee for permit construction, repair, or alteration of buildings shall be in an amount equivalent to a percentage of the construction costs, repair costs, or alteration costs on the building for which the permit is to be issued. Such percentage shall be established from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 5-14) 
Secs. 22-37—22-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 94. 
State Law reference— State fire safety standards, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-12; electrical contractors, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-1 et seq. 

Sec. 22-91. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
Sec. 22-92. - Alteration of wiring. 
(a)  Permit required. No alteration shall be made in the wiring of any building for light, heat or power, nor shall any building be wired for electric lights, motors or heating devices, without a permit therefor from the superintendent of utilities. 
(b)  Inspection and approval. Upon the completion of the wiring of any building for the purposes enumerated in this section, it shall be the duty of the person doing the wiring to notify the superintendent of utilities, who shall at once inspect such wiring and appliances pertaining thereto. If the wiring is approved by him, he shall issue a certificate of satisfactory inspection, which shall contain the date of such inspection and an outline of the result of his examination. All certificates of inspection shall be issued in duplicate and numbered in the order issued, and a copy retained and filed with the city clerk by the superintendent. 
(c)  Use of current. Prior to inspection and approval, the electric current shall not be turned on. 
(Code 1965, § 8-5) 
Sec. 22-93. - Certain wiring to be in conduit. 
All wiring for commercial uses and/or for industrial uses, and all wiring in the first fire district, shall be in conduit only. 
(Code 1965, § 8-6) 
Sec. 22-94. - Disconnect switch at service entrance. 
A separate disconnect switch shall be installed at each service entrance for electrical service. 
(Code 1965, § 8-7) 
Sec. 22-95. - Connection of neon lights, fluorescent lights or other low power factor apparatus to transmission lines. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect to the electric transmission lines of the city any line or wire which directly or indirectly supplies electric current to any neon light or neon sign, or any fluorescent light or sign, or any other type of lighting or sign having low power factor characteristics, in any case where the customer's aggregate connected energy load of this type equipment exceeds 100 watts, unless such units are equipped, either individually or as a group, with corrective apparatus scientifically adequate and proper to increase the power factor of such equipment in each case to at least 90 percent lagging. It shall be unlawful to maintain any lighting or sign enumerated in this section already connected with transmission lines of the city until it is equipped with such corrective apparatus to increase the power factor as provided in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 8-8) 
Sec. 22-96. - Fuse plugs or circuit breakers required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain, or to permit the maintaining, on premises in his charge within the city any system of electric wiring for lights and/or power unless it is so contrived and connected that the current consumed at all times passes through standard and recognized fuse plugs or circuit breakers of the kind in general use and suitable for the voltage of the electric current received on the premises in each instance. 
(Code 1965, § 8-9) 
Sec. 22-97. - Use of substitute for fuse. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to insert a penny, or other metal substance other than a standard and recognized fuse plug, in any fuse block connected with electric wiring within the city. 
(Code 1965, § 8-10) 
Secs. 22-98—22-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 94. 
State Law reference— Plumbers, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
ASTM. The abbreviation "ASTM" refers to the American Society for Testing Materials. The marks, stampings, etc., refer to the current approved specifications of this organization. 
Firm and corporation mean a business organization engaged in the work of plumbing, the members of which may or may not be master plumbers or journeyman plumbers. Plumbing work by firms and corporations and issuance of permits to firms and corporations shall be governed by section 22-174. 
House drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a house drainage system which receives the discharge from the soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of any building and conveys the discharge to the house sewer. 
House sewer means that part of the horizontal piping of a house drainage system extending from the house drain to its connection with the main sewer or septic tank, and conveying the drainage of but one building site. 
Journeyman plumber means a person who has practical knowledge of plumbing and drain laying, and is qualified to install, construct, alter or repair plumbing, ventilation and drainage under the general supervision of a master plumber. 
Local ventilating pipe means a pipe through which foul air is removed from a room. 
Master plumber means a person who has theoretical and practical knowledge of plumbing and drainlaying, and the ability to prepare plans and specifications and to properly supervise the installation, construction, alteration or repair of plumbing, ventilating and drainage. He must have served at least two years as a licensed journeyman plumber. 
Plumber means the trade or calling carried on by any person who holds himself out to the public as a plumber and who does plumbing for the public as a means of livelihood. Any person holding himself out in the manner defined and for the purpose stated in this definition is hereby declared to be, for the purpose of this article, pursuing the trade or vocation of a plumber; provided, however, that this article in no way applies to or affects those who supply plumbing material either wholesale or retail, and who do no plumbing work for themselves or others. 
Plumbing means the art of installing, repairing or servicing, wherever located, a plumbing system or any part thereof, including the pipes, fixtures and apparatus necessary for bringing in the water supply and removing liquid and water-carried wastes. 
Plumbing fixtures means receptacles intended to receive and discharge water, liquid or water-carried wastes into a drainage system with which they are connected. 
Plumbing system includes the water supply distributing pipes, the fixture and fixture traps, the soil, waste and vent pipes, the house drain and house sewer, and the stormwater drainage, with their devices, appurtenances, and connections, all within or adjacent to the building. 
Size and length. The given caliber or size of pipe is for a nominal internal diameter, except that other than iron pipe size, brass tubing is measured by its outside diameter. The developed length of a pipe is its length along the centerline of the pipe and fittings. 
(Code 1965, § 17-31) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-122. - Prerequisites for doing plumbing work. 
Before any person shall engage in or do any plumbing in the city, or outside the city when such work is connected to the water system of the city, except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be necessary for him to comply with the regulations contained in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 17-5) 
Sec. 22-123. - Permits. 
(a)  Required. No person shall install or repair any plumbing, except repairs not involving the removing or alteration of soil, waste or vent pipes or traps, until a permit has been secured from the building inspector as plumbing inspector. Not less than four hours before any plumbing work is started, including drainage, sewerage, extensions, or alterations, except as noted in this subsection, a permit must be secured for such work to be done. 
(b)  Plans and specifications. Before any permit will be issued, plumbing must be laid out in plan and other necessary views to show the location and type of fixtures, size of pipe, etc., together with specifications of materials to be used. Each set of plans and specifications must show the name of the owner and the location of the proposed work. 
(c)  Issuance restricted. Except as otherwise provided in this article, the building inspector as plumbing inspector shall not grant a permit to any person unless he has fully complied with all the terms of this article. Any permit granted in violation of this section shall be void. 
(Code 1965, §§ 17-12, 17-13) 
Sec. 22-124. - Disputes between plumber and inspector. 
In case of dispute between any plumber and the building inspector as plumbing inspector, as to layout, plans, specifications or materials, either may appeal to the mayor and council, and the decision of the mayor and council shall be final. 
(Code 1965, § 17-14) 
Sec. 22-125. - Inspections generally; tests; completion of work. 
(a)  Inspections generally. All piping, traps, fixtures and house sewers of a plumbing system shall be inspected by the building inspector acting as plumbing inspector to ensure compliance with all the requirements of this Code and the installation and construction of the system in accordance with the approved plans and the permit. 
(b)  Test of water piping. Water piping shall be tested under water pressure equal to, or greater than, the pressure for which the system is designed. 
(c)  Test of soil and water pipes. Soil and water pipes shall be tested under reasonable water pressure. 
(d)  Alternate tests. In occupied or finished buildings where water is liable to cause damage, air tests may be substituted for water tests. 
(e)  Methods of testing. 
(1)  Water test. 
a.  The water test shall be applied to the drainage system in its entirety or in sections. If applied to the entire system, all openings in the piping shall be tightly closed, except the highest opening above the roof, and the system filled with water to the point of overflow above the roof. 
b.  If the system is tested in sections, each opening shall be tightly plugged except the highest opening of the section under the test and each section shall be filled with water; but no section shall be tested with less than a ten-foot head of water or a five-pound pressure of air. In testing successive sections, at least the upper ten feet of the next preceding sections shall be retested so that no joint or pipe in the building shall have been subjected to a test of less than a ten-foot head of water or a five-pound pressure of air. 
c.  Under any test, the water or air pressure shall remain constant for not less than 15 minutes without any further addition of water or air. 
(2)  Air test. The air test shall be made by attaching the air compressor or test apparatus to any suitable opening and closing all other inlets and outlets to the system, then forcing air into the system until there is a uniform pressure sufficient to balance a column of mercury ten inches in height or five pounds per square inch on the entire system. This pressure shall be maintained for 15 minutes. 
(f)  Failure to complete work. Where a licensed master plumber, either by contract or employment, has been entrusted with the work, or has secured a contract to connect a building or lot with the public sewers, and, after securing this contract, fails to complete the work or contract within a reasonable time, it shall be the duty of the building inspector acting as plumbing inspector to notify the plumbing contractor of his default. The work or contract must be carried on expeditiously to completion, and should the plumbing contractor, after receiving the notice, fail or refuse to carry on the work or contract, then he shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article, and in addition to any penalties imposed upon the contractor, his bondsman will be responsible for any damage caused. 
(g)  Plumbing inspector to be judge of work; appeals. The building inspector acting as plumbing inspector is to be the judge of the quality and material and workmanship and interpretation of the ordinances as to their meaning. Should any difference of opinion arise, appeal from his decision must be made at once in writing to the mayor and council, stating the full particulars of disputed points clearly, and a copy of such appeal furnished to the inspector in six hours; otherwise his judgment will govern. The inspector shall inspect the entire work and the details thereof from the property line to the roof joint, and anything that may have a bearing upon the successful working or protection of all work. 
(h)  Covering of work. No drainage or plumbing system or part thereof shall be covered until it has been inspected, tested and approved as prescribed in this article. If any work is covered before inspection and approval it shall be uncovered at the direction of the inspector. 
(i)  Notification that work is ready for inspection or testing. 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the master plumber to notify the proper administrative authority and the owner or his authorized agent in writing not less than four working hours, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., before the work is to be inspected or tested. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the plumber to make sure that the work will stand the test prescribed before giving such notification. 
(Code 1965, § 17-15) 
Sec. 22-126. - Inspections required. 
It shall be the duty of the building inspector acting as plumbing inspector, either personally or by his assistants, to inspect all plumbing work done within the area defined in this article during the progress of such work as well as when it is completed, such inspections to be made from time to time and to be thorough and complete. 
(Code 1965, § 17-17) 
Sec. 22-127. - Conduct and scope of inspections. 
(a)  Inspection notices. Inspection notices upon blanks furnished by the building inspector as plumbing inspector shall be filed in the office of the inspector by each person doing plumbing work, giving notice to the inspector of the location, the kind of work and the time at which the work will be ready for inspection, and the work involved will be inspected as soon as possible thereafter. When the work has been completed, the plumber must immediately so notify the inspector. 
(b)  Plumber or representative to be present at final inspection. At the time the final inspection is made, the plumber or his designated representative must be present. 
(c)  Work not to be covered before inspection. No plumbing work may be covered until the necessary inspection has been made. 
(d)  Certificate of final inspection. Upon final inspection, if the inspector determines the plumbing and material are in accordance with the provisions of this article, a certificate of final inspection shall be issued, certifying that the work has been done in accordance with the laws of the city. 
(e)  Disapproval of work. If the inspector finds that any plumbing has not been properly installed, or does not comply with the sanitary requirements of the city, the inspector shall so notify the owner, agent or lessee of such property, and upon notice so to do, the owner, agent or lessee shall make such changes and corrections in the plumbing as may be ordered by the inspector within five days after notice so to do has been received. If the necessary correction is not made, in addition to any other penalties, the city may refuse to furnish water to the premises. 
(Code 1965, § 17-16) 
Sec. 22-128. - Inspection and permit fees. 
(a)  Establishment of fees. The charge for inspection of plumbing work shall be set from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Additional inspections. The charge provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall entitle the master plumber to a second inspection where defects in workmanship are noted during the first inspection. The fee for any additional inspections will be set by the city council through periodic resolution. 
(c)  Billing; payment. Plumbers shall be billed on the first of each month for all sums due the city for inspection charges during the preceding month. Unless the charges are paid by the 15th of the month, the city may refuse to issue any further plumbing permits to any plumber in arrears. 
(d)  Types of fees. The following plumbing permit fees will be set by the city council by periodic resolution: 
(1)  Basic permit fee. 
(2)  Fee for each fixture. 
(3)  Fee for each floor drain. 
(4)  Fee for septic tank installation. 
(5)  Fee for household waste line replacement and most repairs. 
Excluded from this fee structure and permit issuance is that permit required and issued by the utility department. 
(Code 1965, § 17-18; Ord. No. 86-5, 9-2-1986) 
Sec. 22-129. - Self-inspection. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26, relating to self-inspection of water and sewer projects by master plumbers or utility contractors, a licensed master plumber or utility contractor shall have the option of installing a water or sewer line according to the alternative inspection procedure contained in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26 where the installation is on private property outside the building underground. If the master plumber or utility contractor elects to use this inspection procedure he must meet all requirements of this Code and O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26 and the applicable regulations. 
(Ord. No. 96-13, § 1, 11-18-1996) 
Sec. 22-130. - Connection to city services. 
(a)  The city shall make all taps to the city mains and all excavations in the city streets. All such connections shall be done by the city upon application by the owner, for which connections the charges set by periodic resolution of the city council must be paid. 
(b)  When it is necessary to install a pipe larger than four inches, the property owner must pay the additional cost. Where it is necessary to tear up and replace pavement, or a connection larger than four inches is made, the property owner must also pay that additional cost. Deposits covering the work must be made with the application. 
(Code 1965, § 17-19) 
Sec. 22-131. - General standards for work; supervision of work by master plumber. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article, all plumbing work must be done in a workmanlike manner by competent plumbers under the supervision of a plumber duly licensed as a master plumber in the state. 
(Code 1965, § 17-32) 
Secs. 22-132—22-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLUMBING INSPECTOR[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 

Sec. 22-151. - Office established; designation of building inspector. 
The office of plumbing inspector is hereby created. The building inspector shall be ex officio plumbing inspector in and for the city. 
(Code 1965, § 17-1) 
Sec. 22-152. - Police powers. 
The building inspector as plumbing inspector shall have police powers in all matters affecting plumbing. 
(Code 1965, § 17-2) 
Sec. 22-153. - Right of entry. 
The building inspector as plumbing inspector shall have the authority to enter any building at reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting the plumbing. Any person attempting to prevent such inspection, whether an owner or lessee or his agent, shall be in violation of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 17-3) 
Sec. 22-154. - Records to be furnished to inspector. 
In order to secure the greatest cooperation between departments, the superintendent of utilities shall furnish a list of taps, meters, connections, etc., so that the building inspector as plumbing inspector may be better informed on matters affecting the plumbing department. These reports shall be made each week and shall contain the name, location and address of the owner, and the name and address, if available, of the firm or person engaged to do the construction. 
(Code 1965, § 17-4) 
Secs. 22-155—22-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PLUMBERS 

Sec. 22-171. - Bond. 
(a)  Required. No person shall be permitted to engage in and do any plumbing within the area defined in this article, and it shall be unlawful to do so, except as otherwise provided in this article, unless and until: 
(1)  A bond is posted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-14-12(b)(2); or 
(2)  In the alternative, a fidelity bond in the sum of $1,000.00 is procured and filed with the city clerk. Such bond must be issued by a responsible surety company authorized to do business in the state. 
(b)  Conditions. 
(1)  Bonds filed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-14-12(b)(2) shall meet the requirements stated therein. 
(2)  A bond filed with the city clerk shall be payable to the mayor and his successors in office for the use and benefit of the city and the public, conditioned for the faithful performance of all plumbing done by the principal within the area covered by this article, and conditioned further that the principal will comply with all valid ordinances enacted by the city relating to plumbing and indemnifying and saving harmless the city and the general public from any damage that may result from the obligor's negligence or failure to faithfully perform any work properly. The bond shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1965, § 17-7) 
Sec. 22-172. - Working without current license. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in plumbing or to act as a plumber in the area covered by this article without a valid license issued by the state. 
(Code 1965, § 17-9) 
Sec. 22-173. - Firms and corporations. 
Any firm or corporation that desires to engage in the installation of plumbing shall do all work through plumbers duly licensed as master plumbers in the state. If one or more members of such firm or corporation is a plumber who has obtained the required state license, only the member who is actually licensed shall do the actual plumbing work. No permit for plumbing shall be issued to such firm or corporation unless the work is laid out and installed under the supervision of a plumber in the regular and full-time employment of the applicant for the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 17-10) 
Sec. 22-174. - Misuse of plumber's name. 
No person engaged in the plumbing business shall allow his name to be used, directly or indirectly, by any other person for the purpose of securing a permit, sending in notices, returns or doing work under the license or registration of any other person. 
(Code 1965, § 17-11) 
Secs. 22-175—22-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GAS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 94. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-201. - Standards of National Board of Fire Underwriters adopted. 
For the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the handling, distribution and operation of liquefied petroleum gas systems, the standards of the National Board of Fire Underwriters, except such portions as are altered, amended or deleted in this article, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as fully as if set out at length in this section. The penalties for violation thereof shall be the penalties imposed in section 1-8. 
(Code 1965, § 12-2) 
Sec. 22-202. - Definitions of terms used in adopted codes. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in a code or standard adopted in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gas company means the city. 
Proper administrative authority or any term of like import means the superintendent of utilities or such other inspector as may at the time be functioning by appointment of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 12-3) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-203. - Prerequisites for doing gasfitting. 
Before any person shall do any gasfitting in the city, or outside the city when such work is connected to the gas system of the city, except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be necessary for him to secure approval from the superintendent of utilities and to otherwise comply with the regulations contained in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 12-8) 
Sec. 22-204. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall install any gas appliances or make any major repairs until a permit has been secured from the superintendent of utilities. 
(b)  Plans and specifications. Before any permit is issued, the gas work must be laid out in plan and other necessary views to show the location and type of appliance, size of pipe, etc., together with specifications of materials to be used. Each set of plans and specifications must show the name of the owner and the location of the proposed building. 
(c)  Issuance restricted. Except as otherwise provided in this article, the superintendent of utilities shall not grant a permit to any person unless he has fully complied with all the terms of this article. 
(Code 1965, §§ 12-10, 12-11) 
Sec. 22-205. - General standards for work; supervision of work by master gasfitter. 
Except as otherwise provided in this article, all gas work must be done in a workmanlike manner by competent gasfitters under the supervision of a master gasfitter approved under this article. 
(Code 1965, § 12-12) 
Sec. 22-206. - Disputes between gasfitter and superintendent of utilities. 
In case of dispute between any gasfitter and the superintendent of utilities as to layout, plans, specifications or materials, either may appeal to the mayor and council, whose decision shall be final. 
(Code 1965, § 12-13) 
Sec. 22-207. - Inspections required. 
It shall be the duty of the superintendent of utilities, either personally or by his assistants, to inspect all gas work done within the area defined in this article during the progress of such work, as well as when it is completed, such inspections to be made from time to time and to be thorough and complete. 
(Code 1965, § 12-14) 
Sec. 22-208. - Conduct and scope of inspections. 
(a)  Inspection notices. Inspection notices upon blanks furnished by the superintendent of utilities shall be filed in the office of the superintendent by each person doing gas work, giving notice of the location, the kind of work and the time at which the work will be ready for inspection, and the work involved shall be inspected as soon as possible thereafter. When the work has been completed, the gasfitter must immediately so notify the superintendent. 
(b)  Final inspection. At the time the final inspection is made, the superintendent or his designated representative must be present. 
(c)  Work not to be covered prior to inspection. No gas work may be covered until the necessary inspection has been made. 
(d)  Certificate of final inspection. At the final inspection, if the superintendent determines the gas work and material are in accordance with the provisions of this article, a certificate of final inspection shall be issued certifying that the work has been done in accordance with the laws of the city. 
(e)  Disapproval of work. If the superintendent finds that any gas work has not been properly installed or does not comply with the requirements of the city, the superintendent shall so notify the owner, agent or lessee of such property, and upon notice so to do, the owner, agent or lessee shall make such changes and corrections in the gas work as may be ordered by the superintendent, within five days after such notice is received. If the necessary correction is not made, in addition to any other penalties, the city may refuse to furnish gas to the premises. 
(Code 1965, § 12-15) 
Sec. 22-209. - Inspection fees. 
(a)  Establishment. There shall be a charge per house or business or automatic gas heating appliance, and a charge for inspection of replacement of gas ranges or manually operated space heaters. These charges will be set by periodic resolution of the city council. Each separate tenement shall be considered a separate unit. 
(b)  Payment. Inspection fees shall be paid at the time the permit is issued. 
(c)  Additional inspections. The charges provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall entitle the master gasfitter to a second inspection where defects in workmanship are noted during the first inspection. If additional trips are required to inspect the faulty work, an extra charge will be made for each subsequent inspection. 
(Code 1965, § 12-16) 
Sec. 22-210. - Right to turn on gas. 
The city shall have the sole right to turn on gas that is being piped to any new building. The gasfitter may turn gas on to test and make necessary adjustments, but the gas must be turned off when installation is completed. In cases where gas is already on and serving a customer, the gasfitter replacing any appliance may leave the gas on after work is completed. 
(Code 1965, § 12-17) 
Secs. 22-211—22-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GAS INSPECTOR[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 

Sec. 22-231. - Designated. 
The superintendent of utilities shall act as gas inspector, and shall be hired by the city manager upon approval of the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 12-4) 
Sec. 22-232. - Authority to disconnect piping or fixtures; police powers. 
The superintendent of utilities, as gas inspector, shall have police powers in all matters affecting gas work, and he may disconnect any gas piping, fixture or appliance which may be found to endanger life or property, and may disconnect any such work installed without proper permit. 
(Code 1965, § 12-5) 
Sec. 22-233. - Right of entry. 
The superintendent of utilities, as gas inspector, shall have the authority to enter any building at reasonable hours for the purpose of inspecting gas work. 
(Code 1965, § 12-6) 
Secs. 22-234—22-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GASFITTERS 

Sec. 22-251. - Approval of license. 
A license to engage in business as a gasfitter shall be issued only after approval of the superintendent of utilities. The approval and issuance of a license shall in no way be construed as approval of the workmanship or materials used by the licensee, or as an assumption of responsibility by the city for the quality of work and materials. 
(Code 1965, § 12-7) 
Sec. 22-252. - Bond and insurance. 
No person shall be permitted to engage in and do any gasfitting within the area defined in this article, and it shall be unlawful to do so, except as otherwise provided in this article, unless and until a fidelity bond in a sum to be set from time to time by resolution of the city council and public liability and property damage insurance in a sum to be set from time to time by resolution of the city council is procured and filed with the city clerk. Such bond and insurance must be issued by a responsible surety company and insurance company authorized to do business in the state. The bond shall be made payable to the mayor and his successors in office for the use and benefit of the city and the public, conditioned for the faithful performance of all gasfitting done by the principal within the area covered by this article, and conditioned further that the principal will comply with all valid ordinances enacted by the city relating to gasfitting, and indemnifying and saving harmless the city and the general public from any damage that may result from the obligor's negligence or failure faithfully to perform work properly. The bond and insurance shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(Code 1965, § 12-9) 
Sec. 22-253. - Revocation of approval. 
(a)  Authorized. The superintendent of utilities may suspend or revoke any approval issued under and by virtue of this article if he shall determine that work done by the licensee is of an inferior quality by reason of incompetency or neglect and that such action is in the interest of the public. 
(b)  Appeals. From the action of the superintendent, the person charged shall have the right to appeal to the mayor and council, who shall hear the evidence on both sides and may either affirm or reverse the action of the superintendent. If the decision of the mayor and council is adverse to the applicant, he shall have the right of certiorari to the superior court of the county, all as provided by law. 
(c)  Revocation pending appeal. Until the action of the superintendent is reversed, the person charged shall be disqualified to do any gasfitting work. 
(Code 1965, § 12-18) 
Sec. 22-254. - Firms and corporations. 
Any firm or corporation that desires to engage in the installation of gasfitting shall do all work through gasfitters duly qualified under this article. If one or more members of such firm or corporation is a master gasfitter who has obtained the approval required in this article, a license may be issued to the firm or corporation as such, but only the member who is approved shall do the actual gasfitting work. If no member of the firm or corporation is a master gasfitter, its license for gasfitting shall be conditioned upon the employment of a master gasfitter, and no permit for gasfitting shall be issued to such firm or corporation unless the work is laid out and installed under the supervision of a master gasfitter in the regular and full-time employment of the applicant for the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 12-20) 
Sec. 22-255. - Misuse of gasfitter's name. 
No person engaged in the gasfitting business shall allow his name to be used, directly or indirectly, by any other person for the purpose of securing a permit, sending in notices or returns, or doing work under the license or registration of any other person. 
(Code 1965, § 12-19) 
Sec. 22-256. - Exceptions to license requirement. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Public utilities, public institutions, public buildings, or mercantile, commercial or industrial plants which maintain departments for maintenance of gas work in or upon the premises and under expert supervision in conformity with the laws of the state and ordinances of the city relative to gas work; provided, however, that if the superintendent of utilities finds such gas work to be contrary to the regulations and laws of the city and the person responsible for such violation fails to correct the conditions, then and in that event the superintendent shall refuse to issue a permit for further work until the person doing such work obtains the approval required in this article. 
(2)  An individual doing gas work for his own use on premises owned and occupied by him or being built by him for his personal use and occupancy. Such person shall be granted a permit by the superintendent for such work upon his making an affidavit that the premises are owned by him and that they are or will be occupied by him as provided in this subsection. 
(b)  The exceptions in this section apply solely to the requirement of securing a gasfitter's license. A permit for gasfitting, as required under this article, must be secured, the work shall be subject to inspection and the installation must comply with the requirements of this article and all fees levied by this article must be paid. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any of these requirements. 
(Code 1965, § 12-21)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Pawnbrokers. 
(a)  Prerequisites for issuance of license. No license shall be granted to any person to engage in the business of a pawnbroker until the applicant shall have first registered with the city clerk, paid the license fee prescribed, and applied in writing to and obtained from the mayor and council a written permit so to do and given the bond required in this section. 
(b)  Application for license. The application for a pawnbroker's license shall state the location of the place of business and the names of the owners or other persons interested directly or indirectly. If a corporation, the names of all the officers and stockholders shall be stated. 
(c)  Bond. The applicant for a pawnbroker's license shall file and give with his application a bond, with solvent surety, in the sum to be set by periodic resolution of the city council, payable to the mayor and his successors in office, for the benefit and use of the city and of the public, conditioned for the safekeeping and return of all articles deposited with the obligor, and for the prompt report of all suspicious persons dealing with the obligor and stolen or supposed to be stolen property. 
(d)  Reports. Each person engaging in the pawnbroker business shall file daily written reports at 10:00 a.m. with the chief of police, showing the name and description of the persons who pawned or sold articles during the preceding 24 hours, and a description in detail of the article pawned or sold. The chief of police shall obtain such report promptly each day, and it shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to fail or refuse to make such daily report in the manner prescribed, and the license and permit of any such offender shall stand immediately forfeited. 
(Code 1965, § 14-53(a)—(c), (e)) 
State Law reference— Supervision of pawnbrokers by municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-136. 
Sec. 26-2. - Coin-operated machines. 
(a)  Applicability. 
(1)  The rules set forth in this section shall govern the operation of all establishments offering the use and playing of one or more coin-operated amusement machines to the public in the City of Sylvester, Georgia. 
(2)  The term "coin-operated amusement machine" as used herein shall have the same meaning and definition as the term "bona-fide coin-operated amusement machine" contained in O.C.G.A. § 48-17-2. 
(3)  As used in this section the term "establishment", shall mean any establishment of business, any portion of whose revenue is from coin-operated amusement machines as defined in this section. 
(b)  Registration of establishments. All establishments shall be registered with the chief of police of the City of Sylvester, which registration shall include the names and addresses of all persons having a financial interest in the operation of the establishment, and all persons in charge thereof, and such other relevant information as the chief of police shall reasonably require. 
At the time of registration the applicant or applicants shall exhibit to the chief of police all licenses and permits required by O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1 et seq. No establishment shall be permitted to operate in the city unless it and all of its machines are licensed and permitted in compliance with the provisions of that section. 
(c)  Investigation of applicant. 
(1)  The person or persons owing any interest in and/or operating an establishment shall be investigated by the Sylvester Police Department and a report made to the city clerk. This requirement shall be waived if a current investigation report is on file. "Current" is defined as being within the past six months. 
(2)  The police reports shall be sent to the city clerk to be placed in the applicant's file. 
(d)  Facilities. All rooms containing one or more coin-operated amusement machines shall be open to view and accessible to the public, and no such machines shall be placed in a private room or any portion of the business closed off to the public or to the rest of the building by doors or partitions of any kind. Windows shall not be blackened or covered with closed blinds, curtains or anything which interferes with visibility through the window. The operation of all coin-operated amusement machines shall be subject to electronic visual surveillance at all times. Videotapes, DVDs or any other recording shall be maintained by the establishment for a period of not less than 30 days. 
The place where the business of the establishment is conducted shall have separate restrooms for males and females. Such restrooms must be kept clean, and the premises shall be in compliance with all applicable rules and regulations of the Worth County Health Department and/or departments of the city. 
The building or structure in which the establishment is operated shall comply at all times with all building, electrical, plumbing and other codes of the City of Sylvester pertaining to buildings and structures or otherwise regulating quality of construction and maintenance of buildings and structures in the City of Sylvester. 
(e)  Serving food. If food is served, the applicant shall have a valid health certificate issued by the Worth County Health Department before any license to serve food can be issued. 
(f)  Violations and punishment. Commission of any of the following acts by an owner, agent, or employee of an establishment, and/or the violation of any other provision or requirement of this section, and/or the failure to comply with any requirement herein, shall constitute "a violation of this Code" as that term is defined and used in section 1-8 of the Code of the City of Sylvester, and shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8, and all of the provisions of section 1-8 are applicable to this section. Each separate day such violation continues shall be a separate offense punishable as provided above. 
(1)  Engaging in, or permitting or allowing on the premises, sales, in violation of state or federal law, of "controlled substances," as that term is defined by state and/or federal law. The terms "permitting" and "allowing" as used herein include sales where the owner or operator in charge knew, or in the exercise of ordinary care should have known, that such sales were taking place, and failed to take effective action to stop them. 
(2)  Permitting persons to loiter on the premises without legitimate business reasons who are known to the owner or operator or manager in charge of such business, or who in the exercise of ordinary care should be known to them, or who are reputed to be, illegal sellers or purveyors of controlled substances as heretofore defined. 
(3)  Permitting any gambling or betting in the place of business or on the premises. 
(4)  Permitting or committing any violation of state law or city ordinance. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person under 18 years of age to play coin-operated amusement machines [in] an establishment during times when alcoholic beverages are sold, furnished or dispensed therein for consumption on the premises. This subsection shall not apply to persons under 18 years of age who are accompanied by a parent or guardian. Any person desiring admission thereto during hours and times when alcoholic beverages are sold, furnished, or dispensed for consumption on the premises who is or appears to be under 18 years of age, shall produce satisfactory identification and age verification or certify his or her age in writing or produce a written permit before he or she shall be allowed entry. 
(g)  Gambling devices prohibited. No form of gambling shall be allowed in any establishment. No racing or other betting pool shall be exhibited or sold therein. The use of baseball tickers and the posting of results of sporting events is expressly prohibited. 
(h)  Further restrictions. It shall be unlawful for any establishment to maintain connections with any place where gambling or illegal activity is conducted or where persons congregate for the illegal consumption, sale, possession, barter, manufacture, exchange, purchase, dispensation, delivery, or other dealing in of alcoholic beverages for any immoral purpose. 
(i)  Enforcement. It shall be the duty of the police or other constituted authorities to inspect all establishments in the city for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not the provisions of this section are being observed; and it shall be the duty of such officer to report all violations promptly to the city attorney and furnish the city attorney such information and assistance as is necessary for the prosecution of such violations. 
(j)  Exemption. This section shall not apply to establishments operated by private industrial concerns solely for the convenience of its employees, Young Men's Christian Associations; religious orders; charitable institutions; state, county, or city institutions; fraternal orders; or bona fide clubs operating such establishments for members or employees only. 
(Code 1965, § 14-57; Ord. No. 2011-01, §§ 1, 2(Exh. A), 3-21-2011) 
State Law reference— Coin-operated amusement machines, O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1 et seq. 
Sec. 26-3. - Gross receipts tax on secondary electric suppliers. 
(a)  Gross receipts business tax established; verified statement of revenues to be filed. Each secondary electric supplier (including specifically electric membership corporations, whether or not operated for profit), within the meaning of O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq., distributing and selling electric and power within the city, which is not otherwise paying a franchise fee pursuant to a franchise agreement, and whether or not such secondary supplier has, operates and maintains offices within the city, shall pay a gross receipts tax at the rate of four percent on any and all gross revenue derived from distribution and sales of electric power to its customers, members, or purchasers within the city, according to the verified statement of such gross revenues which shall be submitted by the secondary electrical supplier at the time the taxes are paid. 
(b)  Tax payable monthly; tax to be in lieu of certain other taxes. The taxes set out in subsection (a) of this section shall be due and payable to the city on the 20th day of each month, calculated on gross revenues as prescribed in subsection (a) of this section. Such taxes shall be in lieu of all other license and business or occupation taxes, but shall not at any time be considered to interfere with or in any way prevent the collection of ad valorem taxes upon the property of the secondary electric supplier in the same manner as all other property, real and personal, in the city is taxed. 
(c)  Suppliers without franchise agreement with city. Secondary electric suppliers distributing and selling electric power within the city, and which do not have a franchise agreement with the city, do not acquire any additional rights by the payment of the tax levied under this section other than those rights granted under the Georgia Electric Territorial Service Act, O.C.G.A. tit. 43, ch. 4, art. 1 (O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq.). 
(d)  Administration and enforcement. 
(1)  The city clerk shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this section, and shall have the power to prepare and provide the necessary forms for the collection of the tax levied in this section. 
(2)  The city clerk shall issue execution for the collection of all outstanding and unpaid taxes imposed and assessed by this section. The unpaid taxes and execution shall be collected in the manner provided by law for the collection of other taxes due the city. 
(Ord. No. 94-9, §§ I—IV, 9-6-1994) 
Sec. 26-4. - Compensation applicable to telephone or telegraph companies. 
(a)  Due compensation for telephone companies with end user retail customers within the city. 
(1)  The city hereby requires due compensation of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues, as defined in O.C.G.A. §§ 46-5-1(b)(8) and (9); provided, however, that any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues pursuant to an existing franchise agreement shall continue to pay in accordance with the agreement until the expiration of the franchise agreement or December 31, 2012, whichever occurs first, and any company which pays in excess of three percent of actual recurring local service revenues in accordance with an occupational license tax arrangement shall continue to pay in accordance with such payment schedule until December 31, 2012. 
(2)  Regarding any telephone company that does not have retail, end user customers located within the city's municipal boundaries, the payment by such company to a municipal authority in accordance with the rates set by regulations promulgated by the department of transportation for the use of its rights-of-way shall be considered the payment of due compensation. 
(b)  Authorized designee. The city clerk shall, on behalf of the city, exercise day-to-day administrative duties necessary to fulfill the regulatory authority of the city under O.C.G.A. § 46-5-1, et seq. and shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Review application information submitted by a telephone company to the city and, if an application is incomplete, notify the telegraph or telephone company within 15 business days of the receipt of such application, identifying in such notice all application deficiencies. 
(2)  Report the receipt of a completed application to the council within 60 calendar days of the receipt of such completed application. 
(3)  Review payments of due compensation submitted by the company to ensure compliance with the provisions of the amended law and this chapter. 
(4)  Provide a coordination function between a telephone company and all city departments on any matter relating to the amended law and this chapter. 
(5)  Arrange and evaluate, no more than once a year, a comprehensive review of the records of a company which is reasonable related to the calculation and payment of due compensation. 
(6)  Provide to all telegraph and telephone companies located in its rights-of-way written notice of annexations and changes in municipal corporate boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 2008-19, §§ 1, 2, 12-15-2008) 
Secs. 26-5—26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Business taxes, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, that the greatest amount of income is derived from. 
Location and office include any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession. 
Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes. 
Person includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations which utilize 80 percent of their proceeds for charitable purposes. 
Practitioner of profession or occupation means one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. Practitioners of professions and occupations do not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined in O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2 or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 2, 12-18-1995) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-32. - Conflicting provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention thereof that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 28, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-33. - Enforcement. 
The city clerk and the city police department will enforce the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes and summon all violators of this article to appear before the court. The city clerk, the chief of police, the members of the police department and their assistants will inspect all registrations issued by the city, as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 24, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-34. - Amendments. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the city council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the city of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 22, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-35. - Payment of tax, fee or assessment imposed under prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereafter passed as provide for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinance, or that impose fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinance, or failure to comply with any other provisions thereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 23, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-36. - Provisions to remain in effect until changed by city council and until taxes have been paid in full. 
This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the city council. All provisions of this article relating to any form of tax shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 25, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-37. - Excluded businesses. 
The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local laws: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355 (businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls). 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 18, 12-18-1995) 
State Law reference— Excluded businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-16. 
Sec. 26-38. - Due date for payment of occupation tax, regulatory fee and registration fee; interest on unpaid tax or fee; delinquency penalty; proration of tax. 
(a)  Existing businesses. 
(1)  Each occupation tax or regulatory fee shall be for the calendar year unless otherwise specifically provided. The regulatory fee or occupation tax shall be payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by February 1 of each year, be delinquent and subject to an interest charge of 1.5 percent per month until paid. 
(2)  Should such regulatory fee or occupation tax not be paid before April 1, an additional penalty of ten percent of the tax or fee shall also be due. 
(b)  New businesses. 
(1)  On any new profession, trade, or calling begun in the city, the owner, proprietor, manager of executive officer of the business liable for the occupation tax shall estimate the number of employees from the commencing date of the new business through the end of the first year and such tax shall be paid as follows: 
a.  The occupation tax is due within 30 days of January 1 of each year or within 30 days following commencement of a new business, whichever first occurs. 
b.  Registration and regulatory fees shall be delinquent if not paid to the city immediately upon beginning business. 
c.  However, the regulatory fees may be paid after commencing business or the practice of a profession when: 
1.  The work done or service provided is necessary for the health or safety of one or more individuals; 
2.  The work done or service provided has no adverse effect on any other person; and 
3.  Regulatory fees are tendered within two business days after commencing business or the practice of a profession. 
(2)  If the occupation tax or regulatory fee is not paid, it shall be subject to an interest charge of 1.5 percent per month until paid. Additionally, should such occupation tax not be paid within 90 days of the first date the business transacted business in the city, an additional penalty of ten percent of the tax shall also be due. 
(3)  Any new profession, trade or calling beginning business in the city on or after July 1 shall be taxed at 50 percent of the annual rate pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-22. 
State Law reference— Determining amount of occupational tax due, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-10; payment of fees and taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-20; penalty for failure to pay tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21; amount of tax due from business commencing business on or after July 1, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-22; issuance of execution against delinquent taxpayer, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26. 
Sec. 26-39. - Collection of delinquent occupation tax or regulatory fee; transacting business when tax or fee delinquent. 
(a)  The tax registration provided for in this article shall be issued by the city clerk, and if any person whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after the registration or occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact in the city any of the kinds of profession, trade, or calling subject to this article without having first obtained such registration, such person shall, upon conviction, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-8. 
(b)  In addition to the other remedies available to the city for the collection of occupation taxes and regulatory fees due from persons subject to the tax or fee who fail or refuse to pay the tax or fee, the city clerk shall issue executions against the delinquent taxpayers for any or all of the following: 
(1)  The amount of the taxes or fees due when the taxes or fees become due; 
(2)  Any penalty imposed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21(a); and 
(3)  Any interest imposed by local ordinance in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21(b). 
(c)  The municipal court may impose a civil fine for failure to pay the occupation tax or regulatory fee. Such a civil fine shall not exceed $350.00 and may be enforced by the contempt power of the court. 
(d)  No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. 
(e)  No occupation tax shall be required from those real estate brokers, real estate agents or real estate companies whose offices are located outside the city and that sell property inside the city. 
State Law reference— Penalty for failure to pay tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-21; amount of tax due from business commencing business on or after July 1, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-22; issuance of execution against delinquent taxpayer, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-26. 
Sec. 26-40. - Veterans' exemption. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-12-2, veterans of the armed forces applying for licenses and claiming exemption as a veteran shall comply with all requirements of the state concerning veterans' licenses, including the requirement that the applicant be a veteran of one of the wars, that he be disabled to the extent of ten percent or more, that he has not paid any state income tax for the previous taxable year, and that he has been living in the state for six months or more next preceding the date of his application. Veterans holding veterans' licenses and certificates of exemption shall exhibit the license or certificate to, and register with, the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 14-58) 
State Law reference— Disabled veterans operating businesses, O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1 et seq. 
Secs. 26-41—26-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OCCUPATION TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 86. 

Sec. 26-61. - Registration required; responsibility of agents to obtain registration. 
All persons subject to the occupation tax levied pursuant to this article shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for the business as described in this article, and in default thereof any agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration provided for in this section before commencing the business, and any person transacting in the city any kind of business, trade, profession, or occupation without first having so obtained such registration shall be subject to penalties provided therefor. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 15, 12-18-1995) 
State Law reference— Amount of tax due from business commencing after July 1, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-22. 
Sec. 26-62. - Evidence of state registration; display of state registration. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the secretary of state pursuant to O.C.G.A. tit. 43 (O.C.G.A. § 43-1-1 et seq.) shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 13, 12-18-1995) 
State Law reference— Posting of state license, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-23. 
Sec. 26-63. - Evidence of permits, bonds, certificates or other qualifications. 
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence that such requirements have been met. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 14, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-64. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
The occupation tax levied in this article is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5—48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 10, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-65. - Payment of tax required; display of registration. 
Each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city or, in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state, exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for such business, trade, profession, or occupation, which tax receipt and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city clerk's office or to any police officer of the city upon request. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-66. - Tax rate. 
(a)  An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city and/or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the number of employees of the business or practitioner. 
(b)  The tax rate determined by the number of employees for each business, trade, profession, or occupation will be developed and updated from time to time by the city. Each qualified nonprofessional or nonregulated business doing business in the incorporated limits of the city will be assessed a base occupation tax in the amount to be set by periodic resolution of the city council plus an additional per-employee charge also set by resolution. The fee assessed will be based on the number of employees who work 40 hours per week and receive a W-2 form from an employer. Part-time employees' hours will be divided by 40 to determine the number of full-time equivalents for the prior year as of December 1 each year. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 4, 12-18-1995; Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1, 6-17-2002) 
Sec. 26-67. - Businesses with no location in state. 
Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 5, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-68. - Dominant line of business to be identified on registration. 
The business registration of each business operated in the city shall identify the dominant line of business that the business conducts. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 6, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-69. - Each location to be considered separate business. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of the occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 7, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-70. - Option to pay on per-practitioner basis. 
(a)  The following professionals as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18) are subject to the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Lawyers. 
(2)  Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. § 43-34-1 et seq. 
(3)  Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. § 43-34-1 et seq. 
(4)  Chiropractors. 
(5)  Podiatrists. 
(6)  Dentists. 
(7)  Optometrists. 
(8)  Psychologists. 
(9)  Veterinarians. 
(10)  Landscape architects. 
(11)  Land surveyors. 
(12)  Practitioners of physiotherapy. 
(13)  Public accountants. 
(14)  Embalmers. 
(15)  Funeral directors. 
(16)  Civil, mechanical, hydraulic, or electrical engineers. 
(17)  Architects. 
(18)  Marriage and family therapists, social workers, and professional counselors. 
(b)  Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on number of employees. 
(2)  A fee charged per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service as set by the city council in periodic resolution. The fee is to be paid at the practitioner's office or location. A practitioner paying according to this subsection (2) shall not be required to provide information to the city relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by January 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 8, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-71. - Exemption for practitioners employed exclusively by government agency. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 9, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-72. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. 
No business for which a business registration is required or on which an occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from the registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose unless 80 percent or more of the entire proceeds from the business are devoted to such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 12, 12-18-1995) 
State Law reference— Exceptions from gross receipts tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5. 
Sec. 26-73. - Tax inapplicable where levy prohibited or exempted by other law. 
An occupation tax shall not apply to the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the law of the state or of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 19, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-74. - Tax on businesses with more than one place or line of business. 
Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, the business will pay an occupation tax in accordance with the prevailing taxing method and tax rate for the dominant line at each location. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 21, 12-18-1995) 
State Law reference— Classification rule for business with more than one type service or product, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-12(1). 
Sec. 26-75. - Public hearing required before adoption of tax increase. 
The city council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 26, 12-18-1995) 
Sec. 26-76. - Right to establish exemption or reduction for certain businesses. 
The city council may by ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax for one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in the minutes of the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 27, 12-18-1995) 
Secs. 26-77—26-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGULATORY FEES 

Sec. 26-101. - Applicability; fee schedule. 
(a)  A regulatory fee will be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on those applicable businesses. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. 
(b)  The regulatory fee schedule for persons in the following occupations and professions will be provided in periodic resolution passed by the city council: 
(1)  General contractors. 
(2)  Electricians and electrical contractors. 
(3)  Plumbers and plumbing contractors. 
(4)  HVAC technicians or HVAC contractors. 
(5)  Gas technicians or gasfitters. 
(6)  All other subcontractors. 
(7)  Peddlers. 
(8)  Pawnbrokers. 
(9)  Carnivals and circuses. 
(10)  Taxicabs and limousine operators. 
(11)  Traveling and itinerant dealers in precious metals and jewelry. 
(Ord. No. 95-11, § 3, 12-18-1995; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 5-17-2010) 
DIVISION 4. - LICENSE FOR TEMPORARY FIREWORKS STAND OPERATORS 

Sec. 26-102. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Consumer fireworks: Any small fireworks devices containing restricted amounts of pyrotechnic composition, designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, that comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations of the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission as provided for in Parts 1500 and 1507 of Title 16 of the Code of Federal Regulations, the United States Department of Transportation as provided for in Part 172 of Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations, and the American Pyrotechnics Association as provided for in the 2001 American Pyrotechnics Association Standard 87-1, and additionally shall mean Roman candles. 
Distributor: Any person, firm, corporation, association, or partnership which sells consumer fireworks. 
Fireworks: Any combustible or explosive composition or any substance or combination of substances or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration, or detonation, including blank cartridges, firecrackers, torpedos 1 , skyrockets, bombs, sparklers, and other combustibles and explosives of like construction, as well as articles containing any explosive or flammable compound and tablets and other devices containing an explosive substance. 
Pyrotechnics: Fireworks. 
Proper identification: Any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person or such person's photograph, or both, and giving such person's date of birth and includes without being limited to a passport, military identification card, driver's license, or other identification card authorized by the State of Georgia. 
Temporary shall be a period of time not exceeding two months in a calendar year and not exceeding 30 days in a row in any one period. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1(Exh. A), 1-4-2016) 
Sec. 26-103. - License required. 
Any business selling consumer fireworks from a temporary consumer fireworks retail sales stand must apply for a license from the City of Sylvester. The license fee for a retail fireworks temporary stand license shall be $500.00 per each stand within the city. 
(1)  Requirements for license. 
a.  An applicant for a fireworks retail license from the City of Sylvester shall offer proof that the applicant maintains public liability and product liability insurance with minimum coverage limits of $2,000,000.00 to cover any loses, damages or injuries that might ensue to persons and property as a result of the sale of consumer fireworks. 
b.  The applicant must demonstrate that they have obtained a license from the Georgia Safety Fire Commissioner. The license fee for a retail fireworks license shall be $500.00 per location within the city. 
c.  A license will only be granted to applicants who agree to operate their stand in accordance with the National Fire Protection Act Provision 1124. 
(2)  Locations. A stand shall only be permitted to be located within 1,000 feet of either a fire hydrant or a fire department connection belonging to the City of Sylvester unless the Fire Chief of the City of Sylvester provides in writing that the stand may operate further than 1,000 feet from a fire hydrant or other fire department connection. 
(3)  Number of stands permitted. 
a.  When a distributor is a retail chain license by the safety fire commission pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-10-5.1(d), the retailer may operate two temporary consumer firework stands for every retail chain store located in the county. 
b.  If at the time of the application for a stand, no distributors licensed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-10-5.1(b) or O.C.G.A. § 25-10-5.1(d) are doing business in Worth County, any distributor licensed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 25-10-5.1(b) or O.C.G.A. § 25-10-5.1(d) that maintains a retail sales facility within 75 miles of the border of Worth County, may choose to place one of their two retail stands in Worth County. 
c.  A fireworks distributor who is not a retailer may operate two retail stands for each license obtained from the safety fire commissioner. 
d.  Any licensee shall notify the city clerk and the fire chief of the location of the temporary retail stand no later than ten days prior to the opening of the stand so that the fire chief can inspect the hydrant or fire connection located near or closest to the location of the stand in ensure its proper functioning. 
(4)  The sale of fireworks may only be conducted through in person face to face sales. Any licensee selling fireworks within the City of Sylvester shall ensure that all customers purchasing fireworks from this stand show proper identification verifying that they are over the age of 18. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1(Exh. A), 1-4-2016) 
Secs. 26-104—26-130. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - FRANCHISES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal franchises, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(7). 

Sec. 26-181. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
