Fees means the costs incurred by the city in the process of awarding, renewing, enforcing, and/or terminating a franchisee's service agreement for, but not limited to, payment for bonds, security funds, letters of credit, insurance, indemnification, penalties, or liquidated damages, the costs of consultants, experts, and outside counsel, and certain government costs without any deduction from other permissible fees, taxes, charges, and/or assessments the city has previously and lawfully entered into with the franchisee; and, in addition, costs incurred by the city to initiate, engage, or otherwise direct outside contractors to remove, demolish and/or salvage any equipment or facilities owned or used or formerly owned or used by a franchisee. 
Franchisee means a business or service engaged in regularly supplying the public with electric, gas, water, transportation, telephone or telegraph service, television service, or entertainment or any other business or service requiring the city to issue a franchise in order to allow the business to conduct operations. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, §§ 2, 3, 7-20-1987) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-182. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 11, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-183. - Purpose. 
This article is adopted to provide for the assessment of fees of general applicability on all franchise operations and for the provision of establishing procedures for the removal, demolition or salvage of the franchisee's equipment and facilities. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-184. - Reimbursement of city for certain expenses. 
It shall be the responsibility of the franchisee to reimburse the city for all costs and expenses incurred by the city incidental to the award, enforcement, renewal, and/or termination of the franchisee's service agreement and the removal, demolition or salvage of the franchisee's equipment and facilities within the corporate city limits. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 1, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-185. - Submission of plan for removal of equipment and facilities. 
(a)  A written plan for the removal, demolition or salvage of any equipment or facilities owned or used or formerly owned or used by a franchisee shall, prior to any removal, demolition or salvage, be presented to the city for examination and approval. The written plan shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner of the facilities and equipment to be removed, demolished or salvaged. 
(2)  An itemized list of all facilities and equipment which the owner intends to have removed, demolished or salvaged. 
(3)  The owner's designated on-site representative. 
(4)  The name and address of all employees of the owner to be engaged in the work. 
(5)  The name and address of all independent contractors which the owner intends to employ. 
(6)  The name and address of all employees of any independent contractor which the owner intends to employ. 
(7)  A list of major equipment to be used either by the owner or its independent contractors, for example, trucks, tractors, forklifts or other heavy machinery. 
(8)  A proposed daily schedule of work to be done, which shall include the following: 
a.  Location of work to be done. 
b.  Personnel involved in the work to be done, by location. 
c.  Facilities and equipment to be removed, demolished or salvaged. 
(b)  No work shall proceed except in accordance with such written plan for removal, demolition or salvage, except that minor variations may be made with the permission of the city's on-site representative. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 4, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-186. - Modification of plan for removal of equipment and facilities; finalization of daily work schedule. 
(a)  The written plan for removal, demolition or salvage required by section 26-185 may be changed in any reasonable manner at any time by the owner of the facility and equipment subject only to the city's approval prior to work proceeding in accordance with the modified plan. 
(b)  Finalization of the proposed daily work schedule must be made in writing and submitted to the city no later that 4:30 p.m. prior to the next working day. The daily work schedule may be reasonably modified at any time during a particular day by notifying the city's on-site representative of the change in work scheduling. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 5, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-187. - Designation of owner's representative. 
The owner of the facility shall have on the work site a designated representative who shall have the responsibility of finalizing the proposed daily work schedule and who shall represent the owner with respect to contracts with the city and who shall be primarily responsible to ensure that work is done in accordance with the requirements of this article. If the owner's designated representative cannot be present at the work site at all times, the owner will appoint a substitute who will have the same authority and responsibility as the designated representative. The owner shall immediately notify the city's on-site representative of any change in the owner's representative. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 6, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-188. - Safety requirements. 
All federal, state, county and city safety laws, rules and procedures will be complied with by the owner and its agents or employees. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 7, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-189. - Restoration of city property; cleanup of work areas. 
All real property owned by the city shall be returned to it in the same condition that it was prior to the installation of the facility or equipment. All work areas shall be thoroughly policed and cleaned up daily to ensure the total removal of all scrap pieces, hardware, bolts, nuts, wire, fittings and any other equipment being removed, demolished or salvaged, or trash shall be removed from the work site at the owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 8, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-190. - Proof of financial responsibility. 
No work shall begin by the owner or the person responsible for removal, demolition or salvage until there has been filed with the city proof of ability of the person responsible for removal, demolition, or salvage to respond in damages for liability on account of accidents arising out of the removal, demolition or salvage, in an amount set by periodic resolution of the city council because of bodily injury to or death of one person resulting from any one accident, and, subject to such limit for one person, in an amount set by periodic resolution of the city council because of bodily injury to or death of two or more persons resulting from any one incident, and in an amount set by periodic city council resolution because of injury to or destruction of property of others resulting from any one incident. The proof of responsibility may be given by filing with the city a certificate of insurance or a bond in the required amount. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 9, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-191. - Abandonment of facilities and equipment. 
All facilities and equipment formerly owned or used by a franchisee shall be removed, demolished, or salvaged within 90 days from the termination of service pursuant to the service franchisee agreement. Upon good cause shown, the owner may apply to the city council for an extension of time for removal. If the facilities and equipment have not been removed within the 90-day period and no application for an extension of time has been made by the owner, the facilities and equipment will be considered abandoned and shall become the property of the city. The fact that the owner elects to abandon its property within the city does not relieve the owner of its responsibility of removing its property and the city may pursue appropriate legal action against an owner for the failure to remove facilities and equipment. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 10, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-192. - Collection of expenses incurred by city. 
If the city is impelled to incur expenses in the administration of the terms of this article, the expenses shall be billed to the owner and the owner shall pay the city the amount billed within 30 days from the date of invoice. 
(Ord. No. 87-3, § 12, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 26-193. - Franchise fee for state issued cable or video franchise. 
(a)  Franchise fee specified. The city hereby requires a franchise fee of five percent of gross revenues generated within the city for any cable or video state franchise issued in its corporate boundaries by the State of Georgia. 
(b)  Authorized designee. The city hereby authorizes the city clerk, upon receipt of notice to the city of its right to designate a franchise fee for an applicant for or holder of an existing state franchise, to provide written notice to the secretary of state and each applicant for or holder of a state franchise within a service area that is wholly or partially located within the city limits of the five percent franchise fee rate applicable to such applicant or holder of a state franchise. 
(Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 1-22-2008) 
Secs. 26-194—26-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Local business tax on depository financial institutions, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 et seq. 

Sec. 26-221. - Tax levied; minimum tax. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations, and state building and loan associations at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of such institutions. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. 
(Ord. No. 83-4, § 1, 12-19-1983) 
Sec. 26-222. - Calculation of gross receipts. 
For purposes of this article, the term "gross receipts," pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-95, shall mean the total amount of revenue generated from the following sources during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax imposed by this article is due: 
(1)  Banks. Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: 
a.  Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; 
b.  Interest on balance with other depository financial institutions; 
c.  Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold securities purchased under agreements of resale; 
d.  Interest on other bonds, notes, and debentures, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; 
e.  Dividends on stocks; 
f.  Income from direct lease financing; 
g.  Income from fiduciary activities; 
h.  Service charges on deposit accounts; 
i.  Other service charges, commissions, and fees; and 
j.  Other income. 
(2)  Savings and loan associations. Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: 
a.  Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold in service for others; 
b.  Interest on mortgages, participations, or mortgage-backed securities; 
c.  Interest on real estate sold on contract; 
d.  Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; 
e.  Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; 
f.  Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; 
g.  Loan fees; 
h.  Loan servicing fees; 
i.  Other fees and charges; 
j.  Gross income from real estate owned operations; 
k.  Net income from office building operations; 
l.  Gross income from real estate held for investment; 
m.  Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; 
n.  Miscellaneous operating income; 
o.  Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans and other assets; and 
p.  Miscellaneous nonoperating income. 
(3)  Deductions. The following items shall be deducted from gross receipts calculated pursuant to subsection (1) or (2) of this section: 
a.  An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period; 
b.  An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to the Domestic International Banking Facility Act (O.C.G.A. § 7-1-730 et seq.); 
c.  An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons located outside of the United States or its territories or possessions; and 
d.  An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than Georgia. 
To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subsections (3)b, c, and d of this section, any deductions taken under subsection (3)a of this section shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subsections (3)b through d of this section bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subsections (3)a through d of this section. 
(Ord. No. 83-4, § 2, 12-19-1983) 
State Law reference— Elements of tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-95. 
Sec. 26-223. - Due date for payment of tax; filing of return. 
(a)  Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city by March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. The returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the state revenue commission and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. 
(b)  The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be April 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 83-4, § 3, 12-19-1983) 
Secs. 26-224—26-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - INSURERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Insurance fees and taxes, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 26-251. - Company license fee. 
An annual license fee is levied upon each insurer doing business within the city in the amount of $50.00. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 26-252 which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, a license fee is levied in the amount of $50.00. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. 
(Ord. No. 94-14, § 1, 12-19-1994) 
State Law reference— Municipality license fee imposed, O.C.G.A. § 38-8-8. 
Sec. 26-252. - License fee for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. 
For each separate business location, not otherwise subject to a license fee under this article, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales offers, solicits or takes applications for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, such insurer shall pay an additional license fee of $17.50 per location yearly. 
(Ord. No. 94-14, § 2, 12-19-1994) 
State Law reference— Additional site license fee imposed, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. 
Sec. 26-253. - License fee for independent agencies or brokers. 
An annual license fee is levied upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by section 26-251 in the amount of $50.00 for each such location within the city. 
(Ord. No. 94-14, § 3, 12-19-1994) 
Sec. 26-254. - Gross premiums tax on life insurers. 
An annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums is levied upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the state in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 26-251. 
(Ord. No. 94-14, § 4, 12-19-1994) 
State Law reference— Municipal tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; amount and method of computing tax, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. 
Sec. 26-255. - Gross premiums tax on all other insurers. 
An annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums is levied upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the state, in an amount equal to 2.5 percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year, in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums" as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 26-251. 
(Ord. No. 94-14, § 5, 12-19-1994) 
State Law reference— Municipal tax on other than life insurers, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2; amount and method of computing tax, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. 
Sec. 26-256. - Due date for payment of fees and taxes; reports. 
(a)  License fees imposed in sections 26-251 and 26-252 shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year. Payments shall be deemed delinquent if not received by February 15 of each year. 
(b)  The gross direct premiums tax set and levied by section 26-253 shall be due and payable on January 1 of each year. Payment shall be deemed delinquent if not received within 45 days from the due date. 
(c)  Payment of the company license fee and gross direct premiums tax levied by this article shall be made to the city and shall be accompanied by a report showing the name and home office address of the insurance company seeking the license, the location and person in charge of each and every business location within the city operated and maintained by such company, the names and addresses of the agents representing the insurance company in the city, the classes of insurance written and the premiums received for each class from policies insuring persons residing within the municipal corporate limits, and such other reasonable information as may be required. Such report shall be made on forms prescribed by the city and filed over the affidavit of an officer of the company. 
(d)  Payment of the agency license fee levied by section 26-252 shall be made to the city and shall be accompanied by a report showing the name and address of the person responsible for each business location subject to the license fee imposed, the address of each business location, the classes of insurance written at each business location, the names of the companies represented, and such other reasonable information as may be required. Such report shall be made on forms prescribed by the city and filed over the affidavit of the person in charge of the agency seeking the license. 
(Ord. No. 80-1, § 4, 1-7-1980; Ord. No. 94-14, § 6, 12-19-1994) 
State Law reference— Collection of license fees by municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. 
Sec. 26-257. - Submitting false information. 
It is a violation of this article for any person or the agent thereof knowingly to give false or incomplete information on any report required to be filed under this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-1, § 5, 1-7-1980) 
Sec. 26-258. - Confidentiality of information. 
All reports filed under the authority of this article shall be confidential and the information contained therein shall be used solely by the officers of the city responsible for the administration of this article. 
(Ord. No. 80-1, § 6, 1-7-1980) 
State Law reference— Confidential treatment of tax information, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-10. 
Sec. 26-259. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any person who shall conduct business within the municipal corporate limits without having obtained a license as required by this article or who shall violate any other provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(b)  The gross direct premiums tax levied by this article may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-1, § 7, 1-7-1980) 
State Law reference— Issue of execution for delinquent fees or taxes, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-11. 
Sec. 26-260. - Fees and taxes to be in lieu of certain other fees and taxes. 
The license fees and taxes levied in this article on insurance businesses shall be in lieu of all other business or occupation license fees or taxes levied on such businesses. 
(Ord. No. 80-1, § 8, 1-7-1980) 
Secs. 26-261—26-269. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ITINERANT DEALERS IN PRECIOUS METALS AND JEWELRY 

Sec. 26-270. - Definitions. 
A "traveling and itinerant dealer, salesman, or buyer," for purposes of this chapter, is hereby defined as a person, association or corporation that does not have a business license in the City of Sylvester and/or shall enter the City of Sylvester for any period of time and advertise by any form of media communication to the public that it will buy, sell or otherwise trade in and receive precious metals, gold, silver coins and jewelry. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-271. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-272. - Enforcement. 
The Sylvester Police Department shall enforce this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-273. - Applicability. 
This chapter shall be applicable to all traveling and itinerant dealers, salesmen and buyers of gold, silver, jewelry, coins and other precious metals, whether their sales, trades and purchases are at retail or wholesale or by any form of pawn. Specifically excluded are wholesalers, buyers and sellers who sell, trade and deal only with mercantile establishments. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-274. - Notice of intent to conduct business/fee. 
(a)  Prior to advertising any buying, selling, trading or otherwise dealing in precious metals, gold, silver, coins, jewelry, the traveling and itinerant dealer, salesman or buyer shall, at least 72 hours prior to the initial advertising, file with the chief of police a written notice of intent to conduct business in the City of Sylvester. 
(b)  Such notice shall include the following: 
(1)  Full name of the person, group or association, and its address; 
(2)  The name of the person who will be in the City of Sylvester and his address; 
(3)  The length of the stay in the City of Sylvester, including the dates of opening and closing; 
(4)  The thumbprint of the person or persons who will be conducting such business in the City of Sylvester; and 
(5)  Where the business will be conducted and during what hours. 
(c)  Each traveling and itinerant dealer, salesman, or buyer shall pay an initial registration fee of $25.00 to be retained by the City to cover the cost of registering such person. The registration shall be renewed annually by payment of a renewal fee of $10.00. 
(d)  Traveling and itinerant dealers, salesmen or buyers shall be subject to a regulatory fee pursuant to section 26-101 of the City Code of the City of Sylvester. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-275. - Records. 
All traveling and itinerant dealers, salesmen and buyers of gold, silver, coins, jewelry and other precious metals shall keep books wherein shall be entered an accurate description of all property pledged, traded or sold by them. Such description shall include to the extent possible the name or the make of the article, any identifying mark or number, and a statement of the kind of material of which it is made. In such books there shall be entered also the full name and address of the person by who same was deposited or sold, and the time when the same was done, and the name, address, date of birth, and drivers' license number of seller. In the event the seller does not have a drivers' license, other adequate and positive identification shall be required. These entries shall be made as soon after the transaction as is possible but in no event more than four hours thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-276. - Report to police. 
Every traveling and itinerant dealer, salesman or buyer shall make a written report to the police department, no more than 24 hours after completion of its business in the City of Sylvester. The report shall be in such form as may be prescribed by the chief of police, of all property pledged, traded, bought or sold during the period or operation in the City of Sylvester, and shall show the name and address of any person who bought, sold, traded or otherwise disposed of or received any item; the date and time of the transaction the amount paid or advanced, or the item traded; the full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design, kind and number of stones in jewelry; and all identifying names, marks, and numbers; and a description of persons trading, buying, selling or pawning, including the name, address, race, weight, height and thumbprint of said person. Such report shall be delivered to the police department no more than 24 hours after completion of its business and shall be legible. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-277. - Surrender of stolen property. 
In the event it is determined that any item bought, sold, or traded to, or received by the traveling or itinerant dealer, salesman or buyer is the subject of any theft or crime, the dealer, salesman or itinerant buyer shall, upon demand of the chief of police surrender the same to the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Sec. 26-278. - Holding period. 
Every item covered by this chapter which is purchased from one seller shall be separately packaged, or kept separately, and not intermingled or confused with items purchased from another seller, for a period of five days following the purchase of such item. No person engaging in the purchase of precious metals or items as defined in this chapter shall sell or otherwise dispose, permit the sale or disposal, remove or permit to be removed from the license holder's place of business, intermingle with other jewelry or stones, alter, change, deface or permit the same of any such precious metals or stones purchased, until after the expiration of five days from the date of purchase. 
Sec. 26-279. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any traveling or itinerant dealer, salesperson, or buyer to receive in pawn, trade, or to buy from minors or to sell to minors, goods of any character or description. A minor, for the purposes of this section, is an individual 17 years of age or under. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1(Exh. A), 5-17-2010) 
Chapter 30 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Law reference— Dead bodies, O.C.G.A. § 31-21-1 et seq.; interment of deceased indigents, O.C.G.A. § 36-12-5; receipt of cemetery or burial lots in trust, annual returns, commissions, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-4; municipal corporation as trustee of funds donated to cemetery, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-5; authority of coroners, etc., to disinter bodies, O.C.G.A. § 45-16-45. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Private (family) cemetery means those which are held strictly for private family use and in which no lots for burial or burial spaces are offered to the public. 
Public cemetery means any cemetery or plot of ground in which burial spaces are made available or sold to the public, whether owned or operated by a governmental entity or strictly by private ownership. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 1, 3-19-1984) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 30-2—30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC CEMETERIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-31. - Vaults. 
(a)  There shall be no burial of any human corpse in any public cemetery without the use of a vault. 
(b)  No vault shall be buried in any public cemetery without being leveled and sealed or weatherproofed against unreasonable moisture penetration. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, §§ 2, 11, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-32. - Slab, headstone or metal marker required on grave sites. 
There shall be no burial of any human corpse in any public cemetery without placement at the grave site of a cement slab, headstone or metal marker bearing the name, year of birth, and year of death of the deceased. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 3, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-33. - Marking of lot corners. 
All lots in a public cemetery shall be marked with corner posts of a permanent nature. The tops of the posts are to be flush with the ground. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 5, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-34. - Foundation for slabs and monuments. 
No permanent slab or monument shall be erected on any lot in any public cemetery without cement foundations. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 6, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-35. - Responsibilities of funeral directors. 
Funeral directors in charge of burial shall be responsible for proper conduct and installation of vaults, slabs and markers at the time of burial by vault or monument companies in any public cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 9, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-36. - Deportment. 
All persons visiting a public cemetery shall, while within the enclosure, conduct themselves in an orderly and correct manner. 
(Code 1965, § 6-4) 
Sec. 30-37. - Trespassing on lots. 
No person shall enter upon the lot of another in a public cemetery unless it be in the presence of the owner thereof, or by special permission from the owner, or for the purpose of making such improvements as may be necessary from time to time, or as public necessity may require. 
(Code 1965, § 6-5) 
Sec. 30-38. - Defacing or removing property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to remove, deface or in any manner injure any monument, railing, enclosure, ornament, tree or plant within a public cemetery. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to pass over or cut or in any way damage any fence or gate in any public cemetery. 
(Code 1965, § 6-6) 
State Law reference— Criminal damage to property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-22 et seq. 
Sec. 30-39. - Discharging firearms. 
It shall be unlawful to discharge any gun, pistol or other firearm within a public cemetery, unless it be a military firing salute at a funeral in honor of the dead. 
(Code 1965, § 6-7) 
Secs. 30-40—30-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CEMETERIES OPERATED BY CITY 

Sec. 30-61. - Administrative rules and regulations. 
The city clerk or other designated agent of the mayor and council, with the leave and approval of the mayor and council, shall promulgate and keep on file in the office of the city clerk rules and regulations for the administration of the cemeteries in the city, which rules and regulations may be added to or amended from time to time with leave and approval of the mayor and council, and which rules and regulations shall apply to all persons engaged in the business of funeral directors, florists, monument sales and installation, grave preparation, and any and all other such activities related to burial and maintenance of burial sites in such cemeteries, and which rules shall have the force of law and the violation of which shall be punishable as is provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1965, § 6-01) 
Sec. 30-62. - Payment for lot prerequisite to interment. 
No person shall be buried in a public cemetery operated by the city unless and until the price for the lot in which such person is interred has been paid. 
(Code 1965, § 6-2) 
Sec. 30-63. - Schedule of lot prices and charge for recording deed. 
The schedule of prices for lots in a public cemetery operated by the city and the charge for recording the deed for such lots shall be set by periodic resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 6-3; Ord. No. 2006-05, § 1, 4-17-2006; Ord. No. 2006-13, § 1, 9-5-2006) 
Sec. 30-64. - Permits. 
No digging of graves, burials, installation of monuments, or exhumation of bodies shall be done in any public cemetery operated by the city without first obtaining a permit and approval of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 10, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-65. - Location and orientation of grave sites. 
Reasonable care shall be taken to ensure that grave sites are centered and equally placed in a lot with the head of the deceased pointing toward the west in any public cemetery operated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 12, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-66. - Coping on lots prohibited; leveling and sodding of lots. 
There shall be no coping of any kind placed around or on any lot in a public cemetery operated by the city. Such lots may be filled with dirt, leveled and sodded with grass. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 4, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-67. - Planting trees, shrubs or other plants. 
No person shall plant, or have planted, any trees, shrubs, bushes or other plants on any lot in any public cemetery operated by the city. Any such plantings may be removed from any lot by the city or its agents as have been appointed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 6-9; Ord. No. 84-5, § 7, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-68. - Removal of floral arrangements. 
In public cemeteries operated by the city, all dead flowers, wreaths, flower stands and like floral offerings shall be carried off and disposed of in trash bins located in the cemetery, within seven days after burial services. 
(Ord. No. 84-5, § 8, 3-19-1984) 
Sec. 30-69. - Use of water. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain water from a public cemetery operated by the city except for legitimate purposes within the cemetery. 
(Code 1965, § 6-8) 
Chapter 34 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; courts, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; law enforcement, ch. 62. 
State Law reference— Georgia Mutual Aid Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-69-1 et seq.; Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; state militia, O.C.G.A. § 38-2-1 et seq.; authority to adopt temporary or experimental traffic regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(19); emergency funds for local government, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - National Incident Management System adopted. 
The city hereby adopts the National Incident Management System (NIMS) as established under HSPD 5 and the Unified Command System as established under O.C.G.A. 38-3-57 as its system of preparing for and responding to disaster incidents and directs all incident managers and response organizations in the city train and exercise and use these systems in their response operations. 
(Ord. No. 2005-10-B, 10-17-2006) 
Secs. 34-2—34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Local organizations for emergency management, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27; Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 34-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Emergency management includes measures necessary to provide for the mobilization, organization and direction of the civilian populace and necessary support agencies to prevent or minimize the effects of fire, flood, storm, earthquake and epidemic as well as the effects of enemy or subversive activities directed against the populace, community, industrial plants, facilities and other installations. 
(Code 1965, § 7-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-3. 
Sec. 34-32. - Emergency management council. 
(a)  Established; membership. The city emergency management council is hereby created and shall include the following members: 
(1)  The mayor; 
(2)  The director of emergency management, as appointed; 
(3)  The police chief; 
(4)  The fire chief; 
(5)  The superintendent of public works; 
(6)  The county or city welfare officer; 
(7)  An American Red Cross representative; and 
(8)  Others, including representatives of business, labor, civic and patriotic organizations, appointed by the council. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the duty of the emergency management council and it is hereby empowered to: 
(1)  Develop a city emergency management plan, which plan shall provide for the effective mobilization of all the resources of the city, both private and public. 
(2)  Prepare and recommend for consideration by the city council ordinances necessary to implement the emergency management plan. 
(3)  Consider and recommend to the city council for approval mutual aid plans and agreements. 
The emergency management council shall have such additional duties as are determined by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7-2, 7-3) 
Cross reference— Boards and commissions, § 2-251 et seq. 
State Law reference— Local mutual aid agreements, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-29. 
Sec. 34-33. - Emergency management director. 
The office of emergency management director is hereby created, such officer to be appointed by the mayor. The emergency management director shall: 
(1)  Represent the mayor on all matters pertaining to emergency management. 
(2)  Require and direct cooperation of city officials in the preparation and implementation of emergency management plans. 
(3)  Direct the services of any city officers or employees during periods of emergency. 
(4)  During periods of emergency, obtain vital supplies and equipment lacking, needed for the protection of life and property of people, and bind the city for the value thereof, and, if required immediately, requisition such supplies and equipment. 
(Code 1965, § 7-4) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Local director, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-27. 
Sec. 34-34. - Emergency management corps. 
(a)  Composition. Officers and employees of the city, with volunteer forces enrolled to aid them during an emergency and all groups, organizations and persons who make the agreements on operation of law and who are charged with duties necessary for the protection of life and property in the city during an emergency, shall constitute the emergency management corps. 
(b)  Divisions. 
(1)  Organization; purpose. The functions and duties of the emergency management corps shall be distributed among the divisions as listed in this section. Each division shall be under the direction of a chief and deputy chief appointed by the emergency management council. The chiefs of divisions shall include the chiefs of the police and fire departments and heads of agencies dealing with transportation, communications, and other sundry services, as well as persons in private business who through their profession, knowledge and experience are particularly qualified to head divisions requiring specialized knowledge and experience. 
(2)  Designation. The divisions are established as follows: 
a.  Law enforcement division. 
b.  Fire services division. 
c.  Transportation division. 
d.  Medical and health division. 
e.  Communications division. 
f.  Welfare division. 
g.  Information and education division. 
h.  Others, as determined. 
(Code 1965, §§ 7-5, 7-6) 
Sec. 34-35. - Volunteers. 
All persons other than officers and employees of the city volunteering in service under this article shall serve without compensation. While engaged in such service they shall have the same immunities as employees of the city performing similar duties. 
(Code 1965, § 7-7) 
Sec. 34-36. - Prohibited acts during emergency. 
It shall be unlawful, during an emergency, to: 
(1)  Willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency management corps in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article or in the performance of any duty imposed upon him by the virtue of this article. 
(2)  Do any act forbidden by any lawful rules or regulations issued pursuant to this article if such act is of such nature as to give assistance to the enemy or to imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of the city, or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof. 
(3)  Wear, carry or display without authority any mark or identification specified by the emergency management council. 
(Code 1965, § 7-8) 
Sec. 34-37. - Radioactive fallout protection requirements for city buildings. 
(a)  Every officer, board, department, commission or agency of the city charged with the duty of preparing specifications or awarding or entering into contracts for the design, erection, or construction of buildings or other structures, including additions to existing structures, for the city shall incorporate or cause to be incorporated in such buildings or other structures protection from radioactive fallout for at least its normal anticipated occupancy, which shall meet or exceed the minimum space and protection criteria recommended by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, unless exempted from such shelter requirements in accordance with subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The city council may exempt buildings or other structures from the requirements of this section where it finds that the addition of fallout protection will create, in the building or other structure, an additional net cost in excess of two percent in the construction of such building, or that other factors make it unnecessary or impracticable to incorporate fallout protection in the design of construction of such building or structure. 
(c)  It shall be the policy of the city council that fallout shelter protection shall be incorporated into all city buildings or structures to the fullest extent practicable in order to provide protection against the effects of radioactive fallout for the greatest possible number of people in the event of nuclear attack upon the United States, or an accidental nuclear explosion. 
(Code 1965, § 7-9) 
Secs. 34-38—34-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DECLARATION AND RESPONSE 

Sec. 34-61. - Regulations continued in effect. 
All ordinances, resolutions, motions and orders pertaining to civil defense, emergency management and disaster relief, which are not in conflict with this chapter, are continued in full force and effect. Such ordinances, etc., are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 34-3-101, 4-16-2012) 
Sec. 34-62. - Emergency management and response powers. 
(a)  Declaration of local emergency. 
(1)  Grant of authority. In the event of an actual or threatened occurrence of a disaster or emergency, which may result in the large-scale loss of life, injury, property damage or destruction or in the major disruption of routine community affairs, business, or governmental operations in the city and which is of sufficient severity and magnitude to warrant extraordinary assistance by federal, state and local departments and agencies to supplement the efforts of available public and private resources, the mayor may declare a local emergency for the City of Sylvester. The form of the declaration shall be similar to that provided in subsection (b) of this Code section. 
(2)  Request for state assistance. Consistent with a declaration of local emergency, the mayor may request the governor to provide assistance, provided that the disaster or emergency is beyond the capacity of the city to meet adequately and state assistance is necessary to supplement local efforts to save lives and protect property, public health and safety, or to avert or lessen the threat of a disaster. 
(3)  Continuance. The declaration of local emergency shall continue until the mayor finds that the emergency conditions no longer exist, at which time, the mayor shall execute and file with the city clerk a document marking the end of the state of emergency. No state of local emergency shall continue for longer than 30 days, unless renewed by the mayor. The city governing authority may, by resolution and in accordance with the city charter, end a state of local emergency at any time. 
(4)  Effect of declaration of local emergency. 
a.  Activation of emergency operations plan. A declaration of emergency by the governor or a declaration of local emergency by the mayor shall automatically activate the local emergency operations plan and shall be authority for the deployment of personnel and use of any forces to which the plan applies and for use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, materials, and facilities assembled, stockpiled or arranged to be made available pursuant to the Georgia Emergency Management Act or any other laws applicable to emergencies or disaster. 
1.  The mayor and/or the city emergency management director (hereinafter sometimes referred to in article III as ("city EMD") shall have the legal authority to exercise the powers and discharge the duties conferred by law, including the implementation of the local emergency operations plan, coordination of the emergency responses of public and private agencies and organizations, coordination of recovery efforts with county, state and federal officials, and inspection of emergency or disaster sites. 
2.  In responding and conducting necessary and appropriate investigations, the Mayor and/or the "city EMD" is authorized to enter at a reasonable time upon any property, public or private, for the purpose of investigating and inspecting sites involved with emergency management functions. The mayor and/or the "city EMD" is authorized to execute a right of entry and/or agreement to use property for these purposes on behalf of the city; however, any such document shall be later presented for ratification by the city governing authority. 
3.  No person shall refuse entry or access to any authorized representative or agent of the city who requests entry for purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials. Nor shall any person obstruct, hamper or interfere with any such representative while that individual is in the process of carrying out his or her official duties. 
b.  Emergency powers. Following a declaration of emergency and during the continuance of such state of emergency, the mayor is authorized to implement local emergency measures to protect life and property or to bring the emergency situation under control. In exercising this authority, the mayor may cause to become effective any of the following sections of this chapter as appropriate: section 34-65 (overcharging prohibited); section 34-66 (registration of building and repair services), and section 34-67 (closed or restricted areas and curfews). If any of these sections is included in a declaration of local emergency, the same shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be in effect until the declaration of local emergency has terminated. 
c.  Authority to waive procedures and fees. Pursuant to a declaration of emergency, the city governing authority is authorized to cause to be effective any of the subsections of section 34-64 of this chapter as appropriate. The implementation of such subsections shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
d.  Additional emergency powers. The mayor and/or the "city EMD" shall have and may exercise for such period as the declared emergency exists or continues, the following additional emergency powers: 
1.  To direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population from any stricken or threatened area, for the preservation of life or other disaster mitigation, response or recovery. 
2.  To prescribe routes, modes of transportation and destinations in connection with evacuation. 
3.  To suspend or limit the sale, dispensing or transportation of alcoholic beverages, firearms, explosives, and flammable liquids and substances. 
4.  To make provision for the availability and use of temporary emergency housing, emergency shelters and/or emergency medical shelters. 
5.  To transfer the direction, personnel or functions of any city departments and agencies or units thereof for the purpose of performing or facilitating emergency services. 
6.  To utilize all available resources of the city and subordinate agencies over which the city has budgetary control as reasonably necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster. 
7.  To commandeer or utilize public or private property when necessary to cope with the emergency or disaster or when there is compelling necessity for the protection of lives, health and welfare; and/or the property of citizens, but only to the extent permitted under the Constitution of the State of Georgia, the Constitution of the United States of America, and applicable law. 
8.  To suspend any law, code provision or regulation prescribing the procedures for conduct of city business, or the orders, rules or regulations of any city agency, if strict compliance with any ordinance, resolution, order, rule or regulation would in any way prevent, hinder, or delay necessary action in coping with the emergency or disaster, provided, that such suspension shall provide for the minimum deviation from the requirements under the circumstances and further provided that, when practicable, specialists shall be assigned to avoid adverse effects resulting from such suspension. 
9.  To provide welfare benefits to citizens upon execution of an intergovernmental agreement for grants to meet disaster-related necessary expenses or serious needs of individuals or families adversely affected by an emergency or disaster in cases where the individuals or families are unable to meet the expenses or needs from other means, provided that such grants are authorized only when matching state or federal funds are available for such purposes. 
10.  To perform and exercise such other functions, powers, and duties as may be deemed necessary to promote and secure the safety and protection of the civilian populations, including individuals with household pets and service animals prior to, during, and following a major disaster or emergency. 
(b)  Form of declaration. Upon the declaration of local emergency, an official "Declaration of Local Emergency," in substantially the same form set forth below, shall be signed and filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be communicated to the citizens of the affected area using the most effective and efficient means available. The declaration shall state the nature of the emergency or disaster, the conditions that require the declaration and any sections of this chapter which shall be in effect. 
DECLARATION OF LOCAL EMERGENCY 
WHEREAS, the City of Sylvester, Georgia, has experienced an event of critical significance as a result of ____________ on ____________ 20 ____________ , and 
WHEREAS, in the judgment of the Mayor of the City of Sylvester, there exist emergency circumstances located in the City of Sylvester requiring extraordinary and immediate corrective actions for the protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the City of Sylvester, including individuals with household pets and services animals; and 
WHEREAS, to prevent or minimize injury to people and damage to property resulting from this event; 
NOW, THEREFORE, pursuant to the authority vested in me by local and state law; IT IS HEREBY DECLARED that a local state of emergency exists and shall continue until the conditions requiring this declaration are abated. 
WHEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED: 
(1)  That the City of Sylvester emergency operations plan is hereby activated. 
(2)  That the City of Sylvester Code of Ordinances Chapter 35, Article III be implemented. 
(3)  That the following measures also be implemented: 
ENTERED on this ____________ day of ____________ , 20 ____________ . 
____________  Mayor, City of Sylvester 
(c)  Contracts with local governments. In addition to the normal agreements embodied in the local emergency operations plan for mutual emergency assistance, the city may contract with any municipality or county for the administration of a local emergency response program. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 34-3-102, 4-16-2012) 
Sec. 34-63. - Enforcement and remedies. 
(a)  Law enforcement. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-4, the city police department shall be authorized to enforce the orders, rules and regulations contained in this chapter and/or implemented by the mayor (see section 34-62) or local governing authority during a declared emergency. 
(b)  Penalties. Failure to comply with any of the requirements or provisions of the regulations contained in this chapter, or with any code section, order, rule or regulation made effective by the mayor and/or the "city EMD" (see subsection 34-62(a)(4)a.1.) or local governing authority upon or after the declaration of an emergency shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this chapter. Any person who violates any provision in this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00, imprisonment for a term not exceeding 120 days, or both such fine and imprisonment, for each violation. The owner of land upon which a violation occurs, and each person assisting in the commission of a violation, shall be guilty of separate offenses. Each day during which a violation or failure to comply continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  Injunctive relief. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-5, in addition to the remedies prescribed in this section, the mayor and/or the "city EMD" (see subsection 34-62(a)(4)a.1.) is authorized to obtain an injunction to restrain violation of laws, code sections, orders, rules and regulations which are contained in the Georgia Emergency Management Act and/or this Code, and/or which are implemented by the local governing authority during a declared emergency. 
(d)  Enforcement. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, this article may be enforced by the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 34-3-103, 4-16-2012) 
Sec. 34-64. - Authority to waive procedures and fee structures. 
(a)  City business. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the affairs and business of the city may be conducted at places other than the regular or usual location, within or outside the city, when it is not prudent, expedient or possible to conduct business at the regular location. When such meetings occur outside of the city, all actions taken by the city governing authority shall be as valid and binding as if performed within the city. Such meetings may be called by the presiding officer or any two members of the governing body without regard to or compliance with the time-consuming procedures and formalities otherwise required by law. 
(b)  Public works contracts. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city may contract for public works without letting such contract out to the lowest, responsible bidder and without advertising and posting notification of such contract for four weeks; provided, however, that the emergency must be of such nature that immediate action is required and that the action is necessary for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare. Any public works contract entered pursuant to this subsection shall be entered on the minutes of the city as soon as practical and the nature of the emergency described therein in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-91-22(e). 
(c)  Purchasing. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the purchasing ordinances, regulations or policies may be suspended. City officials shall continue to seek to obtain the best prices during the state of local emergency. 
(d)  Code enforcement. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city governing authority may temporarily suspend the enforcement of the ordinances of the city, or any portion thereof, where the emergency is of such nature that immediate action outside the code is required, such suspension is consistent with the protection of the public health, safety, and welfare, and such suspension is not inconsistent with any federal or state statues or regulations. 
(e)  Fees. Upon declaration of an emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city may temporarily reduce or suspend any permit fees, application fees or other rate structures as necessary to encourage the rebuilding of the areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" include fees or rates charged by the city for building permits, land disturbance permits, zoning applications, special land use permits, temporary land use permits and other fees relating to the reconstruction, repair, and clean up of areas impacted by the disaster or emergency. The term "fees" does not include fees collected by the city on behalf of the state or federal government or fees charged by the city pursuant to a state or federal statute or regulation. 
(f)  Temporary dwellings. Upon declaration of a state of emergency or disaster by the governor or mayor, the city or its designees may issue temporary mobile home, trailer, recreational vehicle or other temporary dwelling structures or parks in any zoning district, even though not otherwise permitted by development code, while the primary dwelling is being repaired. The temporary permit shall not exceed six months in duration. Upon expiration of the temporary permit and/or extension, the temporary dwelling must be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 34-3-104, 4-16-2012) 
Sec. 34-65. - Overcharging prohibited. 
To preserve, protect or sustain the life, health, or safety of persons or property within a designated area upon the declaration of emergency or disaster, it shall be unlawful, during the duration of the emergency or subsequent recovery period, for any person, firm, or corporation located or doing business in the city to overcharge for any goods, materials, foods, equipment, supplies, services, labor, motel rooms, temporary lodging or houses sold or rendered within the county. 
(1)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Overcharging means charging prices for goods, materials, foods, equipment, supplies, services, labor, motel rooms, temporary lodging, or houses, which exceed the customary charges by at least 25 percent or, in applicable cases, which exceed by at least 25 percent the suppliers' or providers' costs for such goods, materials, foods, equipment, supplies, services, labor, motel rooms, temporary lodging or houses. The existence of overcharging shall be presumed from a 25 percent or greater increase in the price at which the merchandise or rate, fee or cost/rental of housing was offered in the usual course of business immediately prior to the onset of the emergency or disaster, but shall not include increases in cost to the supplier directly attributable to the higher cost of material, supplies, and labor costs resulting from the emergency. 
Subsequent recovery period means that period during which the emergency or disaster continues to cause disruptions in the area designated in the declaration of emergency, but shall not exceed three months after the declaration has been terminated, unless extended by action of the city governing authority. 
(2)  Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. Unless otherwise specified in the declaration of emergency or otherwise extended by the governing authority of the city, the provisions of this Code section shall remain in effect during the state of emergency and for a subsequent recover period of three months. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 34-3-105, 4-16-2012) 
Sec. 34-66. - Registration of building and repair services. 
(a)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 38-3-56, before building, constructing, repairing, renovating or making improvements to any real property, including dwellings, homes, buildings, structures or fixtures within an area in the city designated in a declared emergency or disaster, any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity must register with the city clerk and secure a building permit that is posted at the work site. Each day any such entity does business in the city without complying with this article constitutes a separate offense. 
(b)  The cost of registration fees in a declared emergency or disaster is fixed at $50.00 per annum. Registration is nontransferable. The cost of the emergency building permit shall be equal to the cost for a building permit under existing regulations. The permit shall only be authorized for repairs. 
(c)  When registering, any person, partnership, corporation or other entity making application must, under oath, complete an application, providing the following information: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Permanent address and phone number of applicant; 
(3)  Applicant's social security number of federal employer identification number; 
(4)  If application is a corporation, the state and date of incorporation; 
(5)  Tag registration information for each vehicle to be used in the business; 
(6)  List of cities and/or counties where the applicant has conducted business within the past 12 months; 
(7)  Georgia sales tax number or authorization; 
(8)  Georgia business license number, if required. 
(d)  Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. Unless otherwise specified in the declaration of emergency or otherwise extended by the city governing authority, the provision of this Code section shall remain in effect during the state of emergency and for a subsequent recovery period of three months. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 34-3-106, 4-16-2012) 
Sec. 34-67. - Closed or restricted areas and curfews during emergency. 
(a)  To preserve, protect or sustain the life, health, welfare or safety of persons, or their property, within a designated area under a declaration of emergency, it shall be unlawful for any person to travel, loiter, wander or stroll in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, lanes, parks or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any other place during a declared emergency between hours specified by the mayor until the curfew is lifted. 
(b)  To promote order, protect lives, minimize the potential for looting and other crimes, and facilitate recovery operations during an emergency, the mayor shall have discretion to impose reentry restrictions on certain areas. The mayor shall exercise such discretion in accordance with the local emergency operations plan, which shall be followed during emergencies. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to persons acting in the following capacities: 
(1)  Authorized and essential law enforcement personnel; 
(2)  Authorized and essential health care providers; 
(3)  Authorized and essential personnel of the city; 
(4)  Authorized National Guard or federal military personnel; 
(5)  Authorized and essential firefighters; 
(6)  Authorized and essential emergency response personnel; 
(7)  Authorized and essential personnel or volunteers working with or through an emergency management agency (EMA); 
(8)  Authorized and essential utility repair crews; 
(9)  Citizens seeking to restore order to their homes or businesses while on their own property or place of business; 
(10)  Other authorized and essential persons as designated on a list compiled by the mayor and/or fire chief (see subsection 34-62(a)(4)a.1.). 
(d)  Enforceability. This section shall be enforced by officers of the law enforcement personnel approved to provide aid and assistance during the emergency. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit a law enforcement officer from bringing other charges under state law. 
(e)  Effective date. This section shall become effective only upon the signing of a declaration of emergency, stating this section is in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 34-3-107, 4-16-2012) 
Chapter 38 - COURTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 62; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Disposition of criminal offenders by the court of a municipal corporation, O.C.G.A. § 17-7-22; exemplifications of municipal records as evidence, O.C.G.A. § 24-7-21; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq.; administration of municipal government, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; trial of misdemeanor traffic violations, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21; attesting instruments, O.C.G.A. § 44-2-15. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1—38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COURT 

Sec. 38-31. - Appointment of judge; presiding officer. 
The mayor and council shall at the first meeting each year elect a judge, and he shall be the presiding officer of the municipal court. In case of the absence or disability of the judge, or in case of vacancy, the mayor, the mayor pro tem or in his absence or disability any member of the council designated by the mayor pro tem shall preside. 
(Code 1965, § 19-1) 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Required training for judges of municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-11; appointment of judges, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-2. 
Sec. 38-32. - Dates and time of regular sessions; special sessions. 
(a)  The municipal court shall hold regular monthly sessions at the municipal courtroom; provided, however, that the presiding officer of the court may, in his discretion, adjourn any session to any other hour or day that he may deem proper. 
(b)  The judge, or other person acting in his stead, may at any time, in his discretion, call and order a special session of the court for the trial of any case or dispatch of any business before the court. 
(Code 1965, § 19-2) 
Sec. 38-33. - Convening and adjourning sessions. 
All adjournments of any session of the municipal court shall be announced in open court by the judge or other presiding officer, and in the event of failure of any presiding officer to appear at such session within one hour after the opening of the session, unless ordered otherwise, the chief of police, or any police officer designated by him, at the hour set for such session, shall announce the adjournment of the session until the next regular session. The court shall always be formally opened by a police officer, by a call to order and a statement that the court is opened. 
(Code 1965, § 19-3) 
Sec. 38-34. - Returns of summonses and warrants. 
All summonses or warrants issued relative to cases in the municipal court shall be returnable to the next session of the court, regular or special. 
(Code 1965, § 19-4) 
Sec. 38-35. - Continuances. 
If it shall be made to appear to the presiding officer at any session of the municipal court that the defendant has been, for sufficient reason, unable to prepare his defense, the case or trial of the defendant may be continued to such future hour or date as the court may deem proper. 
(Code 1965, § 19-5) 
Sec. 38-36. - Police officers to attend court. 
The chief of police, or some officer he appoints for that purpose, shall attend every session, both regular and special, of the municipal court and make certain that all witnesses and parties and a sufficient number of police officers to assist in the dispatch of the court's business are present. 
(Code 1965, § 19-6) 
Sec. 38-37. - Entry of attorney's name on docket; arguments by attorneys. 
All attorneys at law appearing in behalf of any person summoned or being brought into the municipal court shall notify the presiding officer of the fact and have their names entered on the docket as counsel. Any failure or refusal on the part of any attorney so to do shall deprive him of the right to have any writs served upon him as such counsel. Counsel shall be given full opportunity to be heard in behalf of their clients, provided no argument, whether of one counsel or more, shall exceed in the aggregate 30 minutes to each side. 
(Code 1965, § 19-7) 
Sec. 38-38. - Privileges of accused regarding witnesses. 
On application of the accused, it shall be the duty of the chief of police, or any member of the police force of the city, to summon by subpoena any and all witnesses residing within the city to appear on behalf of the accused at the time of his trial, and it shall be his or their duty to serve such subpoena on the witnesses so applied for. Any failure or neglect so to do, after request, shall entitle the defendant or accused to a continuance of his case. 
(Code 1965, § 19-8) 
Sec. 38-39. - Conduct of trials. 
All trials in the municipal court shall be conducted in the manner prescribed by the presiding officer; provided, however, that in all cases the city or the accuser shall first be required to make out or substantiate the charges brought, and the accused then shall have full opportunity to present his defense, with the right of the city or the accuser to follow the defense with any testimony, which shall be only in rebuttal of such defense. After the announcement that the case is closed by either side the case will not be reopened, except in the discretion of the court, for the purpose of introducing further testimony. In the event of argument in the trial of any case, the city or accuser shall have the opening and closing argument, except where the accused offers no defense other than his statement, in which event the accused shall be allowed the opening and closing arguments. 
(Code 1965, § 19-9) 
Sec. 38-40. - Issuance, contents and service of subpoenas. 
All subpoenas shall be issued by the judge. They shall be directed to the witness, and shall contain a brief statement of the case, the time set for trial, and the time the witness shall appear. Subpoenas shall be served personally. 
(Code 1965, § 19-10) 
Sec. 38-41. - Issuance of arrest warrants in cases of contempt. 
In all cases of contempt by disobedience of summons or subpoenas, the judge shall issue a warrant for the arrest of the person offending, to be brought before the court to show cause why he should not be punished for contempt. 
(Code 1965, § 19-11) 
Sec. 38-42. - Issuance, contents and disposition of summons or copy of charges. 
A summons or copy of charges, when employed, may be issued by the chief of police, any member of the police force, or the city clerk. It shall be directed to the defendant, state the date and hour he is to appear, and contain a summary or simple statement of the offense charged. Summons shall be in duplicate, with the original to be returned by the officer or police officer issuing the summons and filed with an entry of service thereon with the chief of police, who shall have the charge thereon entered on the docket and safely keep the same. The duplicate shall be served on the defendant. 
(Code 1965, § 19-12) 
Sec. 38-43. - Dockets. 
(a)  Records of cases shall be kept on dockets. 
(b)  In all cases, the arresting officer shall report the case as early as practicable, and have the case entered on the docket in conformity with the law, and the chief of police shall see that all cases are promptly reported. He shall be charged with the keeping of the court dockets and with the entering, either by himself or by some member of the police force appointed for that purpose, of all cases reported, on the dockets, as required by law. 
(Code 1965, § 19-13) 
Sec. 38-44. - Amendment of subpoenas, summonses, writs and docket entries. 
In all cases pending, the presiding officer in the municipal court shall have the authority at any time to amend and have properly executed or served all subpoenas, summonses or other writs, and docket entries, issued or entered in such cases, in order to have the same conform to city ordinances, and to this end he shall have the authority to have the same reissued, re-served or re-entered as the case may be; provided, however, that such authority conferred in this section shall not be exercised after a case is regularly called and one or more witnesses have testified therein; and provided further that no such amendment or alteration shall contain or amend any charge or offense other than the original charge or offense upon which the defendant is brought or summoned before the court. 
(Code 1965, § 19-14) 
Sec. 38-45. - Appearance bonds. 
(a)  All persons arrested by authority of the city under warrant, attachment or other writ shall, before being released from custody, be required to give a bond, in such amount and with such solvent security, either personal or cash, as shall be approved by the mayor or chief of police, conditioned for the appearance of the accused at the session of the municipal court to which the case may be returnable, and from session to session thereafter, until the case is disposed of. 
(b)  Upon call of the case where bond for personal appearance has been given and the defendant, after being called into court, does not appear, the chief of police in open court shall warn the sureties to present the body of their principal, and, receiving no response, shall notify the court of the default, whereupon it shall be the duty of the city attorney to have the bond adjudged forfeited, and a writ of scire facias issued. 
(c)  A bond forfeiture occurs at the end of the court day upon the failure of appearance of a principal of any bond or recognizance given for the appearance of that person. 
(d)  An appearance bond shall not be forfeited unless the clerk of the court gave the surety at least 72 hours' written notice, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays, before the time of the required appearance of the principal. Notice shall not be necessary if the time for appearance is within 72 hours from the time of arrest, provided the time for appearance is stated on the bond, or where the principal is given actual notice in open court. 
(e)  The bond shall be filed with the city clerk to be safely kept, and upon a breach thereof the bond shall be forfeited pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 17-6-71 and 17-6-72. No cash deposit shall be returned to the principal or the owner except upon written order of the mayor, and any officer who, without such order, refunds such deposit shall be personally liable therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 19-15) 
State Law reference— Authority of municipality to order forfeit of bond, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-4; procedure for forfeiture of bond, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-70; judgments and scire facias, O.C.G.A. § 9-12-61. 
Sec. 38-46. - Sentences. 
All sentences shall be entered and signed by the presiding officer of the municipal court. 
(Code 1965, § 19-16) 
Sec. 38-47. - Collection of fines. 
The chief of police shall promptly collect all fines. When a fine shall have been imposed by the municipal court, the offender shall remain in the custody of the chief of police or in confinement until the fine is paid or such person is discharged by due course of law. 
(Code 1965, § 19-17) 
Sec. 38-48. - Execution for fines. 
All executions for fines shall be issued and collected as provided for the issuance and collection of tax executions for the city. 
(Code 1965, § 19-18) 
State Law reference— Tax executions, O.C.G.A. § 48-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 38-49. - Disposition of fines. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to turn over to the city clerk all fines and costs collected. 
(Code 1965, § 19-19) 
Sec. 38-50. - Court fee. 
There shall be a fee of $10.00 assessed against all fines and forfeitures ordered by the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 2003-11, § 1, 6-2-2003) 
Secs. 38-51—38-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RECORDER'S COURT 

Sec. 38-76. - Indigent defense counsel. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established for the recorder's court of the city the office of indigent defense counsel. Said position shall be filled each year by the mayor and council at their first regular official meeting of the calendar year, for a term of one year and until a successor has been appointed. All persons appointed to this position shall be members in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia, and shall be licensed and qualified to practice law in the State of Georgia. Should the mayor and council fail to appoint a successor, the incumbent shall continue to serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council, and until a successor is appointed. The compensation of such appointee shall be fixed by the mayor and council by agreement with the appointee. 
(b)  Duties. It shall be the duty of indigent defense counsel to attend each session of recorder's court at which there will be arraignments and/or trials of cases involving the violation of city ordinances and/or state laws, and to represent and defend the accused person in all cases and/or arraignments where appointed and directed by the court to do so. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, §§ 1, 2, 1-18-2005) 
Sec. 38-77. - Prosecutor. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established for the recorder's court of the city the office of prosecutor. Said position shall be filled each year by the mayor and council at their first regular official meeting of the calendar year, for a term of one year, and until a successor has been appointed. All persons appointed to this position shall be members in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia, and shall be licensed and qualified to practice law in the State of Georgia. Should the mayor and council fail to appoint a successor, the incumbent shall continue to serve at the pleasure of the mayor and council, and until a successor is appointed. The compensation of such appointee shall be fixed by the mayor and council by agreement with the appointee. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the prosecutor to attend each session of the recorder's court at which there will be trials of cases involving the violation of city ordinances and/or state laws, and to prosecute the trial of said cases where directed by the court to do so. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, §§ 3, 4, 1-18-2005) 
Sec. 38-78. - Counsel appointed. 
In every criminal proceeding in the recorder's court, both at arraignments and at trial, in which imprisonment is provided by law as a possible punishment, where the accused is not otherwise represented by counsel, and where the judge determines that the accused is financially unable to employ counsel, the court shall appoint and direct indigent defense counsel to represent such accused. 
(Ord. No. 2005-03, § 5, 1-18-2005) 
Sec. 38-79. - Fees. 
At their first regular official meeting of each calendar year the mayor and council shall, by the method hereinafter set forth, establish a fee to be added as costs in every criminal case disposed of by the court, whether by trial or by plea, and in every bond forfeiture declared by the court, and it shall be the duty of the judge of the recorder's court to add said costs in every case as above provided in addition to all other costs, fines, fees and forfeitures.
