(b)  No restaurant shall be operated within the city unless it conforms with the requirements of such code, insofar as it may be applicable. 
(Code 1965, § 10-1) 
Sec. 58-32. - Milk and milk products. 
(a)  Milk ordinance adopted. The production, transportation, processing, handling, sampling, examination, grading, labeling and sale of milk and milk products sold for ultimate consumption within the city, the inspection of dairy herds, dairies and milk plants, and the issuing and revocation of permits to milk producers, haulers and distributors shall be regulated in accordance with the terms of the unabridged form of the U.S. Public Health Service Grade A Pasteurized Milk Ordinance, 2001 revision, insofar as it may be applicable; provided, however, that all parenthetical expressions therein referring to degrading shall be understood to be deleted. 
(b)  Sales restricted. No milk or milk products shall be sold to the final consumer, or to restaurants, soda fountains, grocery stores, or similar establishments, except grade A pasteurized. 
(Code 1965, § 10-2) 
State Law reference— Milk and milk products, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-230 et seq. 
Sec. 58-33. - Food establishments to be screened. 
All commercial food establishments shall have substantial screens securely placed in all doors, windows or other openings to effectively prevent the ingress of flies or other insects. 
(Code 1965, § 10-3) 
Sec. 58-34. - Display of food in food establishments. 
All persons dealing in food of any description at such person's place of business shall keep the food for display in flyproof and dustproof showcases or like receptacles. 
(Code 1965, § 10-4) 
Sec. 58-35. - Keeping articles of food outside food establishment. 
No article of food, except fruit and except live articles such as chickens, ducks, etc., shall be kept outside any place where food is sold or offered for sale, or upon the sidewalks in front of such establishments, for any purpose except the receipt and delivery of such articles to and from such establishments. 
(Code 1965, § 10-5) 
Sec. 58-36. - Transport of food. 
(a)  All peddlers of fruits and vegetables licensed by the city or granted permission to conduct such business shall have their vehicles effectively screened to prevent the ingress of flies or access by flies to articles of food contained in such vehicles and peddled therefrom. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person dealing in food of any description to carry or cause to be carried the food through the streets unless transported in a flyproof and dustproof receptacle. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to use, for transporting food, any vehicle unless the vehicle shall be furnished with flyproof and dustproof compartments that shall contain shelves on which the food shall be placed, and such shelves shall be covered with clean paper, which shall be changed at least every 24 hours. 
(Code 1965, § 10-6) 
Secs. 58-37—58-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MEAT MARKETS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Meat inspection, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-60 et seq.; ordinances dealing with meats, poultry, dairy products, etc., O.C.G.A. § 26-2-212. 

Sec. 58-61. - Approval of premises prerequisite to issuance of license. 
Every person wishing to operate a meat market must apply to the city to have the place and location of the market inspected and approved before obtaining license. 
(Code 1965, § 10-18) 
Sec. 58-62. - Screening of counters. 
All counters whereon meat is laid for sale shall be properly screened to prevent handling by customers. 
(Code 1965, § 10-19) 
Sec. 58-63. - Removal of waste. 
No proprietor shall allow scraps and trimmings and waste to accumulate in his meat market, but he shall have all such waste removed every day between 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(Code 1965, § 10-20) 
Sec. 58-64. - Cleanliness of equipment, utensils and personnel. 
All knives, meat hooks, meat choppers and counters in a meat market must be cleansed every day, and all employees must have suitable aprons and must keep their aprons and hands as clean as possible. 
(Code 1965, § 10-21) 
Sec. 58-65. - Health of personnel. 
No person shall be employed in any meat market who is suffering from any contagious, infectious or venereal disease, or from any loathsome skin disease. 
(Code 1965, § 10-22) 
Sec. 58-66. - Health examination of personnel. 
All proprietors and employees of meat markets shall present themselves before the health officer once a month for examination, and obtain certificates of health from such officer. 
(Code 1965, § 10-23) 
Sec. 58-67. - Water and lavatory facilities. 
Proprietors of meat markets must keep at least one water faucet and a suitable sanitary lavatory with sewer connections for the convenience of employees. 
(Code 1965, § 10-24) 
Sec. 58-68. - Live animals or fowl or hides prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for a proprietor to keep or allow to be kept any living animal or fowl, or the hide of any animal, in a meat market in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 10-26) 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 18. 
Secs. 58-69—58-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WELLHEAD PROTECTION 

Sec. 58-101. - Short title and purpose. 
(a)  This article shall be known as the "wellhead protection ordinance". 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to insure the provision of a safe and sanitary drinking water supply for the city by the establishment of wellhead protection zones surrounding the wellheads for all wells and springs which are the supply sources for the city water system, and by the designation and regulation of property uses and conditions which may be maintained within such zones. 
(Ord. No. 2008-13, § 1, 10-20-2008) 
Sec. 58-102. - Definitions. 
When used in this article the following words and phrases shall have the meanings given in this section: 
(1)  Hazardous waste or material: Any waste or material which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may: 
a.  Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or 
b.  Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or to the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
(2)  Sanitary landfill: A disposal site where solid wastes, including putrescible wastes, or hazardous wastes, is disposed of on land by placing earth cover thereon. 
(3)  Wellhead: The upper terminal of a well, including adapters, ports, seals, valves, and other attachments. 
(Ord. No. 2008-13, § 2, 10-20-2008) 
Sec. 58-103. - Establishment of wellhead protection zone. 
There is hereby established a use district known as a wellhead protection zone, identified and described as all the area within a circle, the center of which is the center of any city water supply wellhead and the radius of which is 100 feet. 
(Ord. No. 2008-13, § 3, 10-20-2008) 
Sec. 58-104. - Permitted uses. 
The following uses shall be permitted within wellhead protection areas: 
(1)  Any use permitted within existing agricultural or single-family residential districts, except that the minimum residential lot size for a lot portion of which lies within the wellhead protection zone shall not be less than one acre; and 
(2)  Any open land use where any building located on the property is incidental and accessory to the primary open land use. 
(Ord. No. 2008-13, § 4, 10-20-2008) 
Sec. 58-105. - Prohibited uses. 
The following uses or conditions shall be and are hereby prohibited within wellhead protection zones, whether or not such use or condition may otherwise be ordinarily included as a part of a use permitted under section 58-104: 
(1)  Surface use or storage of hazardous material, expressly including commercial use of agricultural pesticides; 
(2)  Septic tanks or drain fields appurtenant thereto; 
(3)  Impervious surfaces other than roofs of buildings and street and driveways and walks serving building permitted under section 58-104 of this article; 
(4)  Sanitary landfills; 
(5)  Hazardous waste disposal sites; 
(6)  Stormwater infiltration basins; 
(7)  Underground storage tanks; 
(8)  Sanitary sewer lines within 150 feet of a wellhead. 
(Ord. No. 2008-13, § 5, 10-20-2008) 
Sec. 58-106. - Administration. 
The policies and procedures for administration of any wellhead protection zone established under this article, including without limitation those applicable to nonconforming uses, exceptions, enforcement, and penalties, shall be the same as provided in the existing zoning ordinance for the city, as the same is presently enacted or may from time to time be amended. 
(Ord. No. 2008-13, § 6, 10-20-2008) 
Secs. 58-107—58-118. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TATTOO ARTISTS AND OPERATORS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, adopted May 16, 2011, supplied provisions to be added as §§ 58-69—58-82. In order to maintain the existing numbering system of this Code, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 58-119—58-132 to read as set out herein. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-119. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Tattoo means to mark or color the skin by pricking in coloring matter so as to form indelible marks or figures or by the production of scars; provided, however, the term "tattoo" shall not mean a tattoo placed upon the skin by a physician for medical identification purposes. 
Tattoo artist means any person who actually performs the work of tattooing. 
Tattoo establishment means any room or place where tattooing is practiced or where the business of tattooing is conducted or any part thereof. 
Tattoo operator means any person who controls, operates, conducts or manages any tattoo establishment, whether actually performing the work of tattooing or not. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-69), 5-16-2011) 
Sec. 58-120. - Tattooing certain persons prohibited. 
No tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall tattoo any person who is under 18 years of age, any person who is under either the influence of alcohol, drugs, or other stimulants or depressants or any person of unsound mind. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-70), 5-16-2011) 
Secs. 58-121—58-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 58-126. - Required. 
No person shall operate a tattoo establishment or engage in the practice or business of tattooing as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist unless the person has first secured a permit from the city and paid a regulatory fee to the city in the amount of $125.00. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-76), 5-16-2011) 
Sec. 58-127. - Application; minimum age; fingerprinting, photographing, medical certificate required. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a tattoo establishment or desiring to operate as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall make application for a permit to the city clerk on forms supplied by the clerk. 
(b)  The minimum age of each applicant shall be 18 years. 
(c)  Fingerprints of all applicants shall be taken by the Worth County Sheriff's Department. 
(d)  An applicant for a permit shall also furnish the city clerk two photographs showing a front and side picture of the full face of the applicant, size two and one-half inches by two and three-quarter inches. 
(e)  An applicant for a permit shall present to the city clerk a medical certificate from a medical doctor certifying that the person is sound physically and mentally, has good eyesight, and is not infected with a disease which can be communicated through openings in the human skin. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-77), 5-16-2011) 
Sec. 58-128. - Approval of health authorities required. 
A condition precedent to the issuance of a permit by the city under this division shall be satisfactory proof that the tattoo establishment has secured from the Worth County Health Department a permit or license to operate the establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-78), 5-16-2011) 
Sec. 58-129. - Location restriction. 
No permit shall issue for the operation of a tattoo establishment or to any person engaged as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist in any area other than those districts zoned Commercial, C-1 Conditional Use, C-2 Conditional Use, C-PUD pursuant to the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-79), 5-16-2011) 
Sec. 58-130. - Contents, transferability. 
Every permit granted under this division shall be issued in the name of the individual person applying therefor, shall contain the location of the tattoo establishment where the applicant shall operate and shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-80), 5-16-2011) 
Sec. 58-131. - Effect. 
The permits issued under this division shall be cumulative and not in lieu of any business license issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-81), 5-16-2011) 
Sec. 58-132. - Revocation. 
Any person who shall conduct a tattoo establishment or engage in the business as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist without first securing a permit therefor or who shall knowingly violate any of the sections of this article shall subject the permit to revocation upon appropriate notice of hearing. Additionally, revocation of a license or permit procured by the Worth County Health Department shall, upon notice of hearing, constitute grounds for revocation of the permit issued by the city. An artist's or operator's permit shall be subject to the revocation upon proof that the holder of the permit has become infected with a disease which can be communicated through openings in the skin. 
(Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1(58-82), 5-16-2011) 
Chapter 62 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq.; civil emergencies, ch. 34; courts, ch. 38; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 90. 
State Constitution reference— Police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1). 
State Law reference— Obstruction or hindering of law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24; arrest, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-1 et seq.; appropriation for training of police officers, O.C.G.A. § 35-4-7; special police, O.C.G.A. § 35-9-1 et seq.; salary of law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-9; peace officers' annuity and benefit fund, O.C.G.A. § 47-17-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 62-1—62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-31. - Size of force. 
The police force of the city shall consist of a chief of police, an assistant chief of police, and such extra or supernumerary and ex officio police officers as the city council may from time to time by ordinance prescribe. 
(Code 1965, § 18-1) 
Sec. 62-32. - Compliance with orders and rules of mayor and council. 
All members of the police force shall, in addition to the duties imposed upon them by ordinance, perform all duties and comply with all orders and rules of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 18-2) 
Sec. 62-33. - General duties. 
It shall be the duty of every police officer to guard the city by day and by night, to enforce obedience to all laws and ordinances of the city, to preserve peace and order at all hours of the day or night, and to make arrests when the arrests may be necessary for that purpose or when the needs of justice demand. The time and place of their duty shall be designated by the chief of police, subject to the control of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 18-3) 
Sec. 62-34. - Members deemed continuously on duty. 
Each member of the police force will be deemed always on duty, subject to relief therefrom as shall be allowed by proper authority, and the same responsibility as to the suppression of disturbance, arrest of offenders and violation of the rules and regulations of the police department shall rest upon him when not in uniform as when in uniform and at post of duty. 
(Code 1965, § 18-4) 
Sec. 62-35. - Conduct and deportment of members. 
Each member of the police force must be quiet, orderly and civil in his conduct and deportment. He must at all times refrain from violent or profane language in the performance of his duty, and must always maintain full command of his temper. Whenever a question is put to him by any person, he shall not answer in a short or abrupt manner, but with the greatest possible attention, and at the same time he is to avoid, as much as possible, engaging in unnecessary conversation with anyone. He shall, in a respectful manner, give his name and number to any person who may inquire of him such name and number, and shall not use his club or pistol except in self-defense or in case of forcible or violent resistance of him in the discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1965, § 18-5) 
Sec. 62-36. - Relations between officers. 
Members of the police force must be civil and respectful to their officers and to each other on all occasions, and shall obey all orders from their superior officers or fellow members, when the latter are empowered to direct the other members of the force. 
(Code 1965, § 18-6) 
Sec. 62-37. - Obedience to superior officers. 
All police officers must readily obey the orders and instructions of their superior officers. If such orders and instructions appear either unlawful or improper, he nevertheless shall not refuse or neglect to obey them. 
(Code 1965, § 18-7) 
Sec. 62-38. - Members to be neat in appearance and carry all necessary equipment. 
Every member of the police force at all times when entering upon duty must be neat in person, with his badge, clothes, boots or shoes clean, and his dress in conformity to the rules and regulations. No member shall go on duty unless he has in his possession and on his person all the necessary equipment to be used by him in the discharge of his duty. 
(Code 1965, § 18-8) 
Sec. 62-39. - Drinking alcoholic beverages. 
Members of the police force are prohibited from drinking alcoholic beverages while on duty or at any time while in uniform, and no officer shall become intoxicated, whether in uniform or not, at any time during his employment as a police officer in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 18-9) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10. 
Sec. 62-40. - Use of office to obtain credit. 
No member of the police force shall obtain credit by virtue of his being employed as a police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 18-10) 
Sec. 62-41. - Use of violence; use of office with malice. 
No member of the police force shall willfully maltreat or use unnecessary violence to a prisoner or citizen. He must never use his club or firearm except in the most urgent cases of self-defense. No police officer shall use his office with malice to oppress or persecute or annoy any person. 
(Code 1965, § 18-11) 
Sec. 62-42. - Accepting fees or rewards. 
No member of the police force shall receive any present, fee or reward for police service other than his regular pay. 
(Code 1965, § 18-12) 
Sec. 62-43. - Political activities. 
No member of the police force shall advocate the claims of any citizen for any municipal office, to the neglect of his official duties as a police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 18-13) 
Sec. 62-44. - Knowledge of city rules and ordinances. 
(a)  All police officers must acquire a full knowledge of the requirements of the rules and regulations of the mayor and council, and of all ordinances requiring special duty of them, and of ordinances of a general nature, and full knowledge of such rules, regulations and ordinances is hereby charged such police officers. Ignorance of such rules and regulations shall not be entertained as an excuse for a breach of any of such rules and regulations. 
(b)  Every member of the police force shall read and study this Code, that he may become familiar with all city ordinances, thereby fitting himself to act intelligently on all occasions where his services are needed. 
(Code 1965, § 18-14) 
Sec. 62-45. - Arms and uniforms to remain city property. 
Arms and uniforms furnished to the police force by the city shall be and remain the property of the city, and when a change in personnel is ordered, or on retirement or removal from office, shall be returned to the city. The members of the force shall be liable on their bond for any loss, careless destruction of or damage to their arms and uniforms. 
(Code 1965, § 18-15) 
Sec. 62-46. - Violations by police officers. 
A police officer shall be punished, as prescribed in section 62-47, against whom any of the following complaints shall be substantiated: 
(1)  Any act of insubordination or disrespect toward a superior officer. 
(2)  Neglect of duty. 
(3)  Acts of oppression or tyranny against those under his command. 
(4)  Neglect or disobedience of orders. 
(5)  Absence without leave. 
(6)  Immoral conduct, or conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman. 
(7)  Any state offense. 
(8)  Conduct injurious to public peace or welfare. 
(9)  Incapacity, mental or physical. 
(10)  Absence from his post of duty during his hours on duty, when not necessary and not in the performance of duty. 
(Code 1965, § 18-16) 
Sec. 62-47. - Disciplinary actions. 
Any police officer violating any of the rules of the mayor and council, upon complaint being filed and conviction therefor, or upon plea of guilty, shall be reprimanded, fined, suspended or dismissed pursuant to personnel policies of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 18-17) 
Secs. 62-48—62-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHIEF OF POLICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Administration of municipal government generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2. 

Sec. 62-71. - Authority over police department. 
The chief of police shall be the chief executive officer of the police department, subject to the orders and regulations of the mayor and council, and it shall be his duty to promulgate such orders and regulations, and it shall be the duty of the police force to respect and obey all orders of the chief not in conflict with such rules and regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 18-28) 
Sec. 62-72. - Compensation. 
The chief of police shall receive for his services such salary as may be prescribed by ordinance of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 18-29) 
Sec. 62-73. - General duties. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police at all times of the day or night to preserve the public peace, to prevent the commission of crime and arrest offenders, to protect the rights of persons and property, to protect the public health, to provide proper police at fires, to protect the firefighters and property thereat, to protect strangers and travelers at railway stations, to enforce obedience to all ordinances of the city council which are applicable to police or health, to attend meetings of the mayor and council when requested to do so, and to see that the ordinances, rules and regulations of the mayor and council are carried into effect. 
(Code 1965, § 18-30) 
Sec. 62-74. - Responsibility for good order of city and conduct of police. 
The chief of police shall be responsible for the good order of the city and the general conduct of the officers of the police force. He shall pay frequent visits to various parts of the city, at uncertain hours, and thus be able to supervise the conduct of the police officers. 
(Code 1965, § 18-31) 
Sec. 62-75. - Supervision of personnel. 
The chief of police shall superintend, direct and control all persons placed under him by the mayor and council, and see that they faithfully and punctually discharge their duties. 
(Code 1965, § 18-32) 
Sec. 62-76. - Preservation of order. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to suppress all riots or public outbreaks within the city, and for this purpose he shall be and is hereby empowered with authority to call upon any or all citizens capable of bearing arms, to aid in suppressing such riots or outbreaks, and upon their neglecting or refusing to render such aid, he shall report all such offenders to the mayor. It shall be his duty to quell all disturbances, and to preserve the peace and good order of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 18-33) 
State Law reference— Immunity from criminal liability of persons rendering assistance to law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-3-22. 
Sec. 62-77. - Removal of nuisances. 
The chief of police shall remove or cause to be removed all nuisances from the city. 
(Code 1965, § 18-34) 
Sec. 62-78. - Investigation of disorderly houses. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police, upon the information of any citizen supported by affidavit, that a disorderly house is being kept within the city, or one which tends to the corruption of the morals of the people, to apply for a warrant against such person so that the charge may be investigated and such proceedings had as city ordinances and laws direct. 
(Code 1965, § 18-35) 
State Law reference— Maintaining a disorderly house, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-44. 
Sec. 62-79. - Response to fire alarms. 
Upon an alarm of fire being sounded in the city, the chief of police shall repair thereto forthwith or shall dispatch his deputy, with a sufficient force of police officers to give such assistance as the chief of the fire department may require. 
(Code 1965, § 18-36) 
Sec. 62-80. - Prosecution of violations of state law. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to prosecute violations of state law within the city, and when any person is bound over to the superior court he shall cause all necessary witnesses for the state to be subpoenaed. 
(Code 1965, § 18-38) 
Sec. 62-81. - Custody of property. 
The chief of police shall take proper care of and be accountable for all city property that shall be put in his charge, and report to the council on the condition of such property at such times as it may require. 
(Code 1965, § 18-40) 
Sec. 62-82. - Execution of warrants; collection of fines, costs and taxes. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to execute all warrants, to serve all summons, subpoenas, citations, notifications, or rules placed in his hands by the mayor and council, or clerk, in accordance with the requirements of city ordinances, to collect all fines and costs imposed by the mayor and council or municipal court, and to levy all tax executions placed in his hands, paying into the city treasury all funds collected by him for the city and taking a receipt therefor, and the clerk shall credit his account with the amount of such receipt. 
(Code 1965, § 18-41) 
Sec. 62-83. - Reports of execution sales. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make a full return to the mayor and council, at their next meeting, of all property sold under execution by him, specifying the property, on whose account the property was sold, the amount of the sale, and the purchaser. 
(Code 1965, § 18-42) 
Sec. 62-84. - Additional duties. 
In addition to the duties prescribed in this article, the chief of police shall perform such other duties as may be from time to time prescribed by rule or order of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 18-43) 
Sec. 62-85. - Liability. 
If it shall appear to the mayor and council that the chief of police has failed to collect money due the city, as required of him, from inattention, carelessness or neglect, he shall be liable for the amount of the money as though he had collected it. If it shall appear to the council that the chief of police has not used the proper diligence in the care and preservation of city property or effects placed in his hands, and that such property has been lost, injured or destroyed thereby, or the city in any way damaged in consequence of such carelessness, neglect or inattention, he and his sureties shall be liable therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 18-44) 
Sec. 62-86. - Supervision of animal pound. 
The chief of police shall have charge of the city pound, in accordance with provisions relating to animals running at large. 
(Code 1965, § 18-40) 
Secs. 62-87—62-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ARREST 

Sec. 62-111. - Generally; duties of chief of police. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police for any violation of the ordinances of the city to arrest or see to the arrest of all persons so offending, and hold them in custody until a trial is had in the manner prescribed for the trial of offenders; provided, nevertheless, that any such person may be discharged from arrest upon giving bond for his appearance before the municipal court. 
(Code 1965, § 18-39) 
Sec. 62-112. - Procedure. 
(a)  Generally. Police officers shall arrest offenders against municipal ordinances and bring or have them brought before the municipal court. A police officer may, in his discretion, according to the exigencies of the case, hold such offender until proper bond be given for such offender's appearance for trial, or serve written summons as provided by law upon such offender, requiring him to be and appear at the next regular session of the municipal court. 
(b)  Warrants. In all cases where the offense is not committed in the presence of the arresting officer, and there is no danger of the offender escaping or attempting to escape, or there will be no violation of the public peace, welfare and security, the arresting officer shall apply to the judge and procure a warrant for such offender's arrest; in other cases the warrant shall not be necessary. 
(c)  Holding defendant. Where any offender is brought before the judge or in his absence on a warrant, and court is not in session, the judge shall, if in his judgment by a preliminary investigation the facts authorize it, bind the defendant over to the next session of the court, and on failure to give a bond approved by the judge for appearance, which the defendant shall be entitled to do, shall commit the defendant, verbally or in writing, to be held until the next session of the court. 
(Code 1965, § 16-64) 
Sec. 62-113. - Resisting arrest. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to resist or invite resistance to lawful arrest by, or lawful orders from, any police officer of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 16-65) 
Sec. 62-114. - Assisting escape from arrest. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to assist or attempt to assist another person to escape or resist any officer, while arrested by the city authorities. 
(Code 1965, § 16-66) 
Secs. 62-115—62-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DETENTION 

Sec. 62-141. - Places of detention. 
All persons sentenced to imprisonment by the municipal court or other authority of the city shall be confined at such place or in such building as may be designated by the mayor and council, and for this purpose the mayor and council may make appropriate arrangements with the officials of the county for the use of county facilities. 
(Code 1965, § 16-68) 
Chapter 70 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Courts, ch. 38; law enforcement, ch. 62; traffic and vehicles, ch. 90. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Acting in disorderly manner or committing acts against public safety, morality or decency. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be found in the streets or any public place acting in a disorderly, riotous or tumultuous manner, or committing any act against the public safety, morality or decency not specified in this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 16-3) 
Sec. 70-2. - Disorderly conduct. 
Disorderly conduct within the city is prohibited. A person shall be guilty of disorderly conduct by either fighting or quarreling, or by using any indecent, vulgar, obscene or abusive language in or near a public place, or by making any unnecessary noise, or by cursing or swearing in or near public places, or by striking or attempting to strike another, or by insulting any person by word or action, or by any act which does, or which tends to, disturb the peace and quiet of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 16-4) 
State Law reference— Offenses against public order, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-30 et seq.; disorderly conduct, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39. 
Sec. 70-3. - Disturbing public entertainment. 
No person shall make any noise or in any way conduct himself at any public hall, public entertainment or public game within the city in a way that will disturb any of the audience participants, spectators or guests. 
(Code 1965, § 16-5) 
Sec. 70-4. - Discharge of firearms. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fire a gun, pistol or any other firearms within the city, except that this prohibition shall not apply to military companies on drill or parade or at a funeral. 
(Code 1965, § 16-6) 
State Law reference— Discharge of firearms, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-103 et seq. 
Sec. 70-5. - Slingshots, airguns and similar devices. 
No person shall be allowed to shoot a slingshot, Alabama sling, crossbow, airgun or blow gun, or any similar instrument that is dangerous within the city. 
(Code 1965, § 16-13) 
Sec. 70-6. - Camping in lot, street or alley. 
It shall be unlawful to encamp upon any open or unenclosed lot, street or alley in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 16-2) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 70-7. - Vagrants. 
Vagrants or persons of suspicious character shall not loiter or loaf or lounge in and upon the streets or other public places of the city, or upon the premises of another. 
(Code 1965, § 16-15) 
Sec. 70-8. - Loitering. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, after first being warned by a police officer, to be in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
(b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with such procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall subject an individual, upon conviction, to penalties as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1965, § 16-8; Ord. No. 2002-16, § 1, 10-7-2002) 
State Law reference— Loitering, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36. 
Sec. 70-9. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definition shall apply: 
Public place shall mean any street, highway, alley, or right-of-way, to include sidewalks, any park, playground, mall, or other place or building open to the public; any cemetery, school yard, body of water or watercourse, any privately or publicly owned place of amusement, entertainment, or public accommodation, including parking lots and other areas adjacent thereto; and any vacant lot or land. 
(b)  Curfew established; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of 18 years to loiter, wander, stroll, or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds, or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots, or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and provided further that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: 
(1)  When a minor is accompanied by his/her parent, guardian, or other adult person 21 years of age or older having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(2)  When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his/her parent, guardian, or other adult person 21 years of age or older having the lawful care and custody of the minor; 
(3)  When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above-referenced places during the prescribed period of time; 
(4)  When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; and 
(5)  When the minor is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal travel with interstate and intrastate travel through the city being excepted in all cases from this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any child under the age of 18 years to permit or by insufficient control, to allow such child to be in or upon the public streets or any other places listed in subsection (b) above within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. of any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day, or on Fridays and Saturdays between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. the following day except in circumstances set out in subsections A through E of subsection (b) hereof. A person charged with violation of this section for the first time shall be given a warning citation. Upon a subsequent violation, the person shall be charged with such violation and, if found guilty, such person shall be subject to punishment as provided in the Charter and Code of Ordinances of the City of Sylvester, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2001-12, §§ 1—3, 7-16-2001; Ord. No. 2004-07, §§ 1—3, 6-21-2004) 
State Constitution reference— Limitations on local legislation, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ IV. 
State Law reference— Crimes and offenses, O.C.G.A. tit. 16; ordinances prohibiting loitering for prostitution, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-24; adoption of municipal ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3(a); municipal action duplicating state criminal offenses prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2)(A). 
Sec. 70-10. - Pound-breaking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to break into the city pound and take therefrom any dog, cow, horse, mule, fowl or other animal, or to break down the pound so that any animal placed therein may escape therefrom. 
(Code 1965, § 16-9(d)) 
Sec. 70-11. - Noise from steam, electric or mechanical whistles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating or managing any steam or electric engine, mill or factory within the city, in connection with which any steam or other whistle is used, to blow such whistle, or to have the whistle blown for any purpose; except, however, that such whistles may be blown in case of fire. 
(Code 1965, § 16-11(b)) 
Sec. 70-12. - Excessive, unnecessary and unusually loud noise. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any excessive, unnecessary, or unusually loud noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others within the limits of the city. The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing, and unnecessary noises in violation of this ordinance, but said enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive, namely: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, street car, or other vehicle on any street or public place of the city, except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. The use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle, or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up. 
(2)  Radios, phonographs, etc. The using, operating, or permitting to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room, vehicle, or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine, or device between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 50 feet from the building, structure, or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(3)  Loud speakers, amplifiers for advertising. The using, operating, or permitting to be played, used, or operated of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is case upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any office or in any dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(5)  Animals, birds, etc. The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
(6)  Steam whistles. The blowing of any locomotive steam whistle or steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper city authorities. 
(7)  Exhausts. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor boat, or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(8)  Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded, or in such other manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling, or other noise. 
(9)  Loading, unloading, opening boxes. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates, and containers. 
(10)  Construction or repairing of buildings. The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration, or repair of any building other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on week days, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit from the building inspector, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three days or less while the emergency continues and which permit may be renewed for periods of three days or less while the emergency continues. If the building inspector should determine that the public health and safety will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, alteration, or repair of any building or the excavation of streets and highways within the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., and if he shall further determine that loss or inconvenience would result to any party in interest, he may grant permission for such work to be done within the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., upon application being made at the time the permit for the work is awarded or during the progress of the work. 
(11)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church, or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital, or court street. 
(12)  Hawkers, peddlers. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers, and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(13)  Drums. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise to any performance, show, or sale. 
(14)  Metal rails, pillars, and columns, transportation thereof. The transportation of rails, pillars, or columns of iron, steel, or other material, over and along streets and other public places upon carts, trays, cars, trucks, or in any other manner so loaded as to cause loud noises or as to disturb the peace and quiet of such streets or other public places. 
(15)  Street railway cars, operation thereof. The causing, permitting, or continuing any excessive, unnecessary, and avoidable noise in the operation of a street railway car. 
(16)  Pile drivers, hammers, etc. The operation between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist, or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise. 
(17)  Blowers. The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. 
(b)  Application for special permit. Applications for a permit for relief from the noise level designated in this ordinance on the basis of undue hardship may be made to the city council. Any permit granted by the city council hereunder shall contain all conditions upon which said permit has been granted and shall specify a reasonable time that the permit shall be effective. The city council may grant the relief as applied for if they find: 
(1)  That additional time is necessary for the applicant to alter or modify his activity or operation to comply with this section; or 
(2)  The activity, operation, or noise source will be of temporary duration, and cannot be done in a manner that would comply with other subsections of this section; and 
(3)  That no other reasonable alternative is available to the applicant; and 
(4)  The city council may prescribe any conditions or requirements they deem necessary to minimize the adverse effects upon the community or the surrounding neighborhood. 
(c)  Violation, a misdemeanor. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined an amount not to exceed $1,000.00 or imprisoned in the city jail for up to 180 days, or shall be punished by both such fine and such imprisonment. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as provided hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2004-04, § 1, 5-15-2004) 
Sec. 70-13. - Recreational vehicles prohibited. 
The operation of recreational vehicles powered by internal combustion engines including motorcyles, dirt bikes, off road vehicles or any other vehicle not authorized to operate on the public streets of the City of Sylvester shall be prohibited in the city parks of the City of Sylvester. 
(Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1, 6-21-2010) 
Sec. 70-14. - Excessive noise in public parks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued excessive or unnecessary or unusually loud noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the quiet enjoyment of the public park. 
(b)  The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio, musical instrument, or other machine or device for reproducing sound in a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and enjoyment of the public park shall be prohibited. Provided however, applications for a permit for relief from the noise level provided in this ordinance may be granted by the city council pursuant to an application for a special permit as provided in subsection 7-12(b). 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-21-2010) 
Secs. 70-15—70-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority of mayor and council to enact ordinances and resolutions for general welfare, § 6-2.

Sec. 70-41. - Gambling. 
(a)  Keeping pool or billiard table for purpose of gambling. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any pool or billiard table in the city for the purpose of gambling, and proof of gaming thereon shall be considered prima facie evidence that such tables were kept in violation of this section. 
(b)  Assembling for purpose of gambling. It shall be unlawful for any person to assemble with another, or others, in the city, for the purpose of gambling. 
(Code 1965, § 16-7)

Sec. 70-42. - Indecent exposure. 
No person shall make an indecent exposure of his person in any public place within the city. 
(Code 1965, § 16-48)
