ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46. 

Sec. 70-81. - Smoking prohibited in city buildings and vehicles. 
(a)  Findings and purpose. The city, having received an increasing number of complaints from employees and citizens of the city concerning tobacco smoke in city buildings and city-owned vehicles, hereby finds and declares that: 
(1)  Numerous studies, including those performed by the American Lung Association, the World Health Organization, the United States Surgeon General, the National Research Council, the Environmental Tobacco Smoke, and other organizations, have established that the breathing of secondhand tobacco smoke or environmental tobacco smoke by nonsmokers is detrimental to their health. 
(2)  It is the obligation of all employers and providers of public services to furnish a safe environment for employees and citizens. 
(b)  Prohibited activity. Effective July 14, 2003, the smoking of tobacco in all buildings owned or independently operated by the city is hereby prohibited, and the smoking of tobacco in all city-owned or city-operated vehicles is hereby prohibited. 
(c)  Enforcement. Any authorized law enforcement officer shall issue a summons for any violation of this section, except that they may arrest for instances when: 
(1)  The alleged violator refuses to provide the officer with such person's name and address and any proof thereof as may be reasonably available to the alleged violator; 
(2)  The alleged violator refuses to cease such illegal activity after being issued a citation. 
(d)  Penalty. Violations of this section shall constitute offenses punishable by a fine of not greater than $100.00 or no more than 15 days incarceration. 
(e)  Other remedies. No provision of this section shall be construed to impair or replace any common law or statutory cause of action or any other legal remedy of any person for injury or damage arising from any violation of this section or from the privacy rights of such individuals. 
(Ord. No. 2003-16, §§ 1-5, 7-7-2003) 
Chapter 74 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environment, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Constitution reference— Local authority for parks and recreational areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5). 
State Law reference— Parks, historic areas, memorials, etc., and recreation, O.C.G.A. § 12-3-1 et seq.; local recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq. 

Sec. 74-1. - Conduct at parks, playgrounds and recreational facilities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do or cause to be done any of the following acts and things in or upon any park, playground, ballfield or other recreational facility owned or operated by the city: 
(1)  Throw, deposit or place upon the premises of such recreational facility any litter, trash, garbage or refuse of any kind whatsoever unless placed or deposited in a receptacle or container designed and placed upon the premises for the collection of such trash, litter or refuse. 
(2)  Possess, consume or carry upon the premises of such recreational facility any alcoholic beverage of any kind whatsoever or container for any such alcoholic beverage. 
(3)  Use or cause to be used any recreational facility designed for baseball or softball games, in any manner whatsoever and for any purpose, without the express permission of the Sylvester-Worth County Recreational Board. 
(4)  Use or be upon any area of any park, playground or outdoor recreational facility between sunset and sunrise; provided, however, organized events may be conducted on those parks, playgrounds, or recreational facilities which are lighted and intended for use after sunset. Each such organized event must first be approved by the city manager or his designated agent upon receipt of an application containing information adequate to determine the management and security for the event. Events that endanger the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city shall not be approved. Any applicant denied approval by the city manager may appeal to the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Individuals who violate the provisions of this section, upon conviction, shall be punished pursuant to section 1-8. 
(Code 1965, § 16-16; Ord. No. 2002-13, § 1, 10-7-2002) 
State Law reference— Local ordinances regulating and controlling litter, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48. 
Chapter 78 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Removal of dead animals from right-of-way, § 18-8; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 58; mobile homes and mobile home parks, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 94. 
State Constitution reference— Local garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2). 
State Law reference— Local solid waste management regulations, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.9; local comprehensive solid waste management plan, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; cost reimbursement fees and surcharges, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39; reduction of amount of solid waste generated in city, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39.1; local restrictions on disposal of tires, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.1; local and regional solid waste management authorities, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-50 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Authority and duties of superintendent of public works. 
The superintendent of public works shall have exclusive control of all facilities and equipment for the collection of garbage by the city, and shall see that all garbage and trash regulations are enforced. 
(Code 1965, § 11-1) 
Sec. 78-2. - Placing garbage on ground. 
It shall be unlawful to place garbage on the ground. 
(Code 1965, § 11-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Depositing filth, slops or garbage in street. 
No person shall throw, sweep or deposit any filth of any kind, or any slops or garbage, into any street, lane or thoroughfare within the city, unless such material is in proper receptacles. 
(Code 1965, § 11-3) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 78-4. - Sweeping refuse into street, sidewalk or alley. 
It shall be unlawful to sweep into the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the city, trash, paper or rubbish of any kind. 
(Code 1965, § 11-4) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 78-5. - Depositing cans or bottles on street or sidewalk. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw any cans or bottles upon the public streets or sidewalks in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 11-5) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 78-6. - Depositing boxes, barrels or similar obstructions on street or sidewalk. 
No person shall place in or on any street or sidewalk in the city any empty boxes, barrels, or other similar obstructions of any kind. 
(Code 1965, § 11-6) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 78-7. - Accumulations of combustible refuse in certain buildings. 
It shall be unlawful to store, or to allow to accumulate, in any box, barrel or otherwise, in any building situated within the first fire district of the city, or in any church or school building, or in any basketball shell, or in any other public building in the city, any loose paper, rubbish, straw, hay, or other combustible materials; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the storing of baled hay by merchants for sale or consumption. 
(Code 1965, § 11-7) 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 46. 
Sec. 78-8. - Accumulations of leaves or other trash on roofs. 
It shall be unlawful for any person occupying any building in the city to allow to accumulate or remain for more than 48 hours any leaves, twigs or other trash upon the roof of any building of any kind in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 11-8) 
Sec. 78-9. - Junk on private property. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning set forth in this subsection: 
Abandoned and discarded. An article of machinery, an appliance, a vehicle, an article of equipment and other material shall be deemed to have been abandoned or discarded when it has remained upon the property in an inoperable condition for more than 60 days, or when it has become inoperable and the owner does not intend to repair it and place it back into operation. 
Appliance means any type of machine or device used in and about the home or premises, and shall include, but shall not be limited to, refrigerators, iceboxes, freezers, stoves, washing machines, televisions and radio sets, lawn mowers, and other devices of like nature. 
Junk means any abandoned or discarded machinery, appliance, vehicle, equipment, or material of any kind whatsoever. 
Vehicle means any device in, upon, or by means of which any person or property is or may be transported. 
(b)  Prohibition. It is unlawful for the owner, lessee, tenant, or other person having possession and/or control of private property to deposit, collect, store, maintain, or permit to be deposited, collected, stored, or to remain upon such private property any junk. 
(c)  Abatement. 
(1)  Before any person shall be convicted of violating this section, he shall be given notice in writing that he is required, within 30 days from the receipt of the notice, either to: 
a.  Repair such junk and put it into operation; 
b.  Remove the junk from his property; or 
c.  Furnish satisfactory proof that the property has not in fact been abandoned, and is being held for some useful purpose. 
(2)  If the superintendent of public works determines that no action has been taken after the 30-day notice has been given, the superintendent may initiate public nuisance abatement procedures as authorized in chapter 46, article II, division 2. 
(d)  Exemptions. This section shall not be applicable to the operation of any junkyard, salvage yard, car lot or other similar business licensed by the city where the storage and accumulation of such items are incident to the operation of such regularly licensed businesses. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1965, § 11-10) 
Secs. 78-10—78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Apartment complex means at least two buildings located on common premises, each of which contains at least six dwelling or occupancy units. 
Commercial wastes means all waste byproducts from manufacturing or commercial establishments, cinders and ashes from commercial boilers, cardboard and wooden boxes, crates and barrels. 
Garbage means domestic wastes composed of meat, vegetables and fruit scraps, cans, bottles, paper, cardboard, rags, ashes and other such waste matter normally to be disposed of from residences, churches, schools, small business establishments and similar places. 
Premises means land, buildings or other structures, vehicles, watercraft or parts thereof, upon or in which refuse is stored. 
Superintendent of public works means the officer of the city, or his authorized representative, charged with the enforcement of this article. 
Trash means yard wastes, such as weeds, grass and hedge trimmings, leaves, brush, tree limbs and similar items. 
(Code 1965, § 11-20; Ord. No. 89-1, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 91-2, § 4, 7-1-1991; Ord. No. 94-2, § 4, 6-20-1994; Ord. No. 95-03, 2-20-1995; Ord. No. 2000-09, 12-18-2000; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 4, 6-18-2001) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-32. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
The superintendent of public works shall enforce this article in addition to his other duties prescribed by the mayor and council. He may also avail himself of the assistance of the county health department in the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 11-21) 
Sec. 78-33. - Persons deemed occupants and agents for purposes of enforcement. 
For the purpose of enforcing this article, any person living on any premises shall be deemed an occupant and any person receiving the rent in whole or in part of any premises shall be deemed an agent. On any premises where construction of any kind is in progress and where employees or workers eat their dinner or lunches in or about such premises or scatter lunch or food in or about such premises, the contractor or foreman or other person in charge over such workers shall be deemed an occupant. The person in charge of any market or stall in any market shall be deemed an occupant. 
(Code 1965, § 11-22) 
Sec. 78-34. - Single-family residences. 
(a)  Each single-family residence within the city shall purchase and maintain at curbside of the premises an approved polycart for the collection of household garbage and solid waste products generated within that household. The monthly fee to be paid to the city by the occupant of such single-family residence for the pickup and removal of contents of the polycart shall be set from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  Except for apartment complexes, each unit of a multifamily building shall be included in the term "single-family residence" for purposes of this section. 
(c)  Any residence which requires a greater quantity than one polycart shall pay a monthly fee to be set from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 89-1, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 91-2, § 1, 7-1-1991; Ord. No. 94-2, § 1, 6-20-1994; Ord. No. 97-3, § 1, 3-17-1997; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 1, 6-18-2001) 
Sec. 78-35. - Business establishments using polycarts. 
(a)  The occupier, owner, or operator of each office or business establishment shall purchase and maintain at curbside of the premises a polycart approved by the city for the deposit and removal of garbage or other nontoxic waste material (not resulting from any manufacturing or shipping operation). The monthly fee to be paid by the occupant, owner, or operator to the city for the pickup and removal of contents of the polycart shall be set from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  Any office or business premises requiring the use of a commercial dumpster as set forth in section 78-36 shall be exempt from this requirement. 
(c)  Any office or business establishment which requires a greater quantity than one polycart shall pay a monthly fee set from time to time by the city council for each additional cart. 
(Ord. No. 89-1, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 91-2, § 2, 7-1-1991; Ord. No. 94-2, § 2, 6-20-1994; Ord. No. 97-3, § 2, 3-17-1997; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 2, 6-18-2001) 
Sec. 78-36. - Business establishments using commercial dumpsters. 
All business establishments involved in operations which generate either in quantity or in kind solid waste materials which cannot be reasonably accommodated by the approved polycart shall employ at the premises a commercial dumpster, which may be served on an as-needed basis. The fee for such commercial dumpster shall be per cubic yard (or equivalent) of the dumpster for the first pickup each month, and all additional pickups or dumps each month shall require an additional fee per yard per dumpster. Each fee is to be set from time to time by the city council 
(Ord. No. 89-1, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 91-2, § 3, 7-1-1991; Ord. No. 93-4, 6-23-1993; Ord. No. 95-07, 7-17-1995) 
Sec. 78-37. - Apartment complexes. 
The garbage/household refuse receptacles in an apartment complex shall be located upon the premises as provided by the city. These shall be dumpsters, whose number and frequency of dumping shall be determined by the city. Occupants of each family unit of the apartment complex shall be required to pay a monthly fee for the use of the dumpster facility, to be established by the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 91-2, § 4, 7-1-1991; Ord. No. 94-2, § 4, 6-20-1994; Ord. No. 95-03, 2-20-1995; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 4, 6-18-2001) 
Sec. 78-38. - Use of boxes or bins as containers. 
It shall be unlawful to place garbage for collection in a box, tub, crate or other container, except such containers as specified in this article. Boxes or bins may be provided at the rear of business establishments for the storage of waste paper, etc., provided the location, construction and use of such bin meets with the approval of the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 11-24(c)) 
Sec. 78-39. - Condition of containers. 
The owner shall maintain containers used for the collection of garbage and trash in good condition, and free from holes or other defects. If a container is not so maintained in good condition and free from holes or other defects, it shall be hauled away and destroyed by the city garbage collectors. 
(Code 1965, § 11-25) 
Sec. 78-40. - Platforms for containers at commercial establishments. 
Wherever approved garbage containers from commercial establishments remain outside, a suitable platform, preferably of concrete, not less than 18 inches in height, must be provided As a base for the garbage containers. 
(Code 1965, § 11-31) 
Sec. 78-41. - Location of containers placed for collection. 
Garbage containers shall be placed for garbage collection at the rear of property wherever an alley or street open to motor vehicles exists, and at other places garbage containers shall be placed at the property front or side as authorized by the superintendent of public works. In every case, containers must be secured in such a manner as to prevent the container from being overturned by persons or animals. Garbage thrown on the ground will not be collected by the garbage vehicles. 
(Code 1965, § 11-26) 
Sec. 78-42. - Containers to be kept covered. 
Garbage containers shall be tightly covered at all times except when opened momentarily to receive garbage or to have the contents thereof removed. 
(Code 1965, § 11-27) 
Sec. 78-43. - Interfering with containers; handling of containers by collectors. 
When a garbage container is placed outside of any premises, it shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the removal of garbage or for any other person to remove the cover from such garbage container except for the purpose of emptying its contents into a duly authorized garbage container. It shall be unlawful to throw such garbage container on the street or sidewalk. All persons engaged in the removal of garbage shall, after emptying the container, place the cover tightly thereon. 
(Code 1965, § 11-28) 
Sec. 78-44. - Disturbing contents of containers. 
It shall be unlawful to pick from or disturb the contents of a garbage container, vessel or other container provided for in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 11-34) 
Sec. 78-45. - Collection of trash; placement of trash for collection. 
Trash shall be collected by city trucks or contractors. Collections shall be made at a time and in a manner prescribed by the superintendent of public works. At no time shall trash be placed in such manner as to obstruct gutters, drains, walkways or streets. 
(Code 1965, § 11-29) 
Sec. 78-46. - Boxes and crates from commercial establishments. 
Such commercial wastes as cardboard boxes or wooden crates shall be flattened and stacked in bundles, and such bundles shall be tied. 
(Code 1965, § 11-30) 
Sec. 78-47. - Yard trimmings. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. 
Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. 
Leachate collection system means a system at a landfill for collection of the leachate which may percolate through the waste and into the soils surrounding the landfill. 
Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash and sanitary waste in septic tanks, and includes solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. 
Municipal solid waste disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of any amount of municipal solid waste occurs, whether or not mixed with or including commercial or industrial solid waste, including, but not limited to, municipal solid waste landfills. 
Municipal solid waste landfill means a disposal facility where any amount of municipal solid waste, whether or not mixed with or including commercial waste, industrial waste, nonhazardous sludges or small quantity generator hazardous waste, is disposed of by means of placing an approved cover thereon. 
Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance, other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(c)  Disposal restricted; mixing with other waste. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with municipal solid waste within the city. 
(2)  Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any municipal waste disposal facility having a liner and leachate collection system or requiring vertical expansion located within the city. 
(d)  Sorting. Yard trimmings shall be sorted in the following manner: 
(1)  Residents are required to separate typical yard trash (such as leaves, straw, prunings, lawn clippings, and limbs) from solid waste materials and from other litter (such as rubbish, toys, paper, plastics, furniture, appliances, and other bulky items). 
(2)  At no time shall yard trimmings be collected when they are placed in in-ground containers, commercial dumpsters, or commercial barrels. 
(e)  Storage prior to collection. Yard trimmings shall be stored in the following manner: 
(1)  On streets with curb and gutter, trimmings should be placed immediately behind the curb on the street right-of-way and abutting the property upon which the waste was generated. 
(2)  On streets without curb and gutter, trimmings shall be placed between the edge of the pavement and the edge of the ditch, in so far as practical from the pavement so as not to impede traffic flow. 
(3)  In alleyways, yard trimmings shall be placed adjacent to the alley immediately upon the property from which such yard trimmings were generated. Where available, alleyways shall be utilized rather than the places designated in subsections (e)(1) and (2) of this section. 
(4)  In all such areas where collection is practical as listed in subsections (e)(1)—(3) of this section, all yard trimmings shall be placed in front of the property from which such waste was generated in the specified locations designated in subsections (e)(1)—(3). 
(5)  At no time shall yard trimmings be placed in ditches, gutters, drains, walkways, alleys or streets of the city. 
(f)  Collection; preparation of tree trimmings and shrubbery cuttings. Yard trimmings will be collected in the following manner: 
(1)  City trash crews will collect yard trimmings once a week. 
(2)  Tree trimmings and shrubbery cuttings must be in lengths of three feet or less and not more than four inches in diameter. When placed in bundles, the bundles shall not exceed 35 pounds and shall be placed in an orderly manner in areas specified in subsection (e) of this section so as to be readily handled and collected. No other materials shall be mixed with the bundles. 
(g)  Composting. Although it is not a requirement, composting is encouraged where applicable. Residents are encouraged to compost yard waste generated on their own property and utilize that compost in their landscape. 
(h)  Trees and tree limbs cut by contractors. No trees or tree limbs cut by contractors will be disposed of by the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-14, §§ 1—3, 11-18-1996) 
Sec. 78-48. - Authorized disposal sites. 
Every person who disposes of any garbage, trash or commercial wastes, whether required to do so by this article or otherwise, shall make such disposal at the city solid waste/collection center, or as specified otherwise by the superintendent of public works or by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 11-33) 
Secs. 78-49—78-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOLID WASTE AND SCRAP TIRE MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 78-71. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, or other combustible materials. 
Building material means any material defined as but not limited to lumber, brick, block, stone, carpet, plumbing materials, plaster, concrete, roofing, floor tile, gutters or other substances accumulated as a result of construction of, repair of, or additions to structures or accessory structures or the demolition of such structures. 
City council means the legally designated governing body of the city composed of the council and mayor. 
Commercial recyclables includes cardboard and noncoated corrugated boxes. 
Commercial solid waste means all types of solid waste generated by stores, offices, restaurants, warehouses and other nonmanufacturing activities, excluding residential and industrial wastes. 
Complex means an apartment complex, mobile home park, or similar type of residential complex. 
Complex management means the official person or entity charged with overseeing and managing a complex. 
Composting means the controlled biological decomposition of organic matter into a stable, odor-free humus. 
Disposal facility means any facility or location where the final deposition of solid waste occurs, and includes, but is not limited to, landfilling and solid waste thermal treatment technology facilities. 
Dump means to throw, discard, place, deposit, discharge, bury, burn, or dispose of a substance. 
Garbage means the byproduct resulting from the growing, harvesting, processing, handling, preparation, cooking, or consumption of animal or vegetable food or other matter which is subject to decomposition, decay, and putrefaction, or the generation of noxious or offensive gases or odors, or which during or after decay may serve as breeding areas or feeding material for flies, insects, or animals. Ashes and dead animals weighing 100 pounds or less shall be classed as garbage. 
Hazardous waste means materials which constitute a hazard to health or safety, such as poison, acids, caustic matter or solutions, chemicals, infected materials, offal, fecal matter, explosives, radioactive materials, and highly flammable substances. 
Household debris means large discardable items, other than industrial, hazardous, or sanitary waste, which cannot be inserted into a garbage container. Household debris includes, but is not limited to, large household furniture, such as sofas and chairs, and large household appliances, such as stoves and refrigerators. 
Industrial waste means solid waste generated by manufacturing or industrial processes or operations. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, waste resulting from the following manufacturing processes: electric power generation; fertilizer and agricultural chemicals; food and related products and byproducts; inorganic chemicals; iron and steel products; leather and leather products; nonferrous metal and foundry products; organic chemicals; plastics and resins; pulp and paper; rubber and miscellaneous plastic products; stone, glass, clay, and concrete products; textiles; transportation equipment; and water treatment. This term does not include mining waste or oil and gas waste. 
Inert waste means wastes that will not or are not likely to cause production of leachate of environmental concern. Such wastes are limited to earth and earth-like products, concrete, cured asphalt, rock, bricks, yard trimmings, stumps, limbs, and leaves. This definition excludes industrial and demolition waste not specifically listed. 
Litter means all discarded sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, waste material, tin cans, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, dead animals or other discarded materials of every kind and description which are not waste as such term is defined in this section. 
Municipal solid waste means any solid waste derived from households, including garbage, trash, and sanitary waste in septic tanks, and means solid waste from single-family and multifamily residences, hotels and motels, bunkhouses, campgrounds, picnic grounds, and day use recreation areas. The term includes yard trimmings and commercial solid waste, but does not include solid waste from mining, agricultural, or silvicultural operations or industrial processes or operations. 
Open dump means a disposal facility at which solid waste from one or more sources is left to decompose, burn or otherwise create a threat to human health or the environment. 
Person means the State of Georgia or any other state or agency or institution thereof, and any municipality, county, political subdivision, public or private corporation, solid waste authority, special district empowered to engage in solid waste management activities, individual, partnership, association or other entity in Georgia or any other state. This term also includes any officer or governing or managing body of any municipality, political subdivision, solid waste authority, special district empowered to engage in solid waste activities, or public or private corporation in Georgia or any other state. This term also includes employees, departments, and agencies of the federal government. (See section 391-3-4-.01 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge, or conservation or recreation area; and residential or farm properties, timberlands, or forests. 
Public works means the public works department of the city. 
Recovered materials means those materials which have known use, reuse, or recycling potential, can be feasibly used, reused or recycled, and have been diverted or removed from the solid waste stream for sale, use, reuse or recycling, whether or not requiring subsequent separation and processing. 
Recovered materials processing facility means a facility engaged solely in the storage, processing, and resale or reuse of recovered materials. Such term shall not include a solid waste handling facility; provided, however, any solid waste generated by such facility shall be subject to all applicable laws and regulations relating to such solid waste. 
Refuse means solid waste accumulations consisting of any combination of ashes, building material, garbage, household debris, rubbish, litter, yard trimmings, and other approved waste or discarded materials. 
Residential recyclable includes newspapers, glass bottles, metal cans, aluminum cans, plastic bottles, cardboard, and non-coated corrugated boxes. 
Retail tire dealer means a person actively engaged in the business of selling new replacement tires. (See section 391-3-4-.19 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Rubbish means combustible and noncombustible solid waste, other than garbage, household debris, yard trimmings, hazardous waste, industrial waste, and sanitary waste, not subject to rapid decomposition, derived from residential, commercial, and institutional areas, and shall include paper, rags, plastics, cartons, boxes, metals, minerals, crockery, packaging materials, discarded clothing, and similar materials. 
Sanitary waste means sewage waste materials, including solids, semisolids, sludges, liquids, or any other form of sewage created by or resulting from septic tanks, wastewater treatment plants, or other facilities. 
Scrap tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage, or defect. (See section 391-3-4-.19 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Scrap tire carrier means any person engaged in picking up or transporting scrap tires, not otherwise exempted in the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management, for the purpose of removal to a scrap tire processor, end user, or disposal facility. (See section 391-3-4-.19 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Scrap tire generator means any person who generates scrap tires. Generators may include, but are not limited to, retail tire dealers, retreaders, scrap tire processors, automobile dealers, private company vehicle maintenance shops, garages, service stations, and city, county, and state governments. (See section 391-3-4-.19 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Scrap tire processor means any person who is approved by the state environmental protection division to receive scrap tires from scrap tire generators or scrap tire carriers for the purpose of scrap tire processing. (See section 391-3-4-.19 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Scrap tire sorter means any person, other than the original scrap tire generator, who handles mixed tires by separating used tires and retreadable casings from scrap tires. (See section 391-3-4-.19 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Solid waste means any garbage or refuse, sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility, and other discarded material including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material resulting from industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations and from community activities, but does not include recovered materials, solid or dissolved materials in domestic sewage, solid or dissolved materials in irrigation return flows or industrial discharges that are point sources, or source, special nuclear, or byproduct material, as defined by the federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended (68 Stat. 923). (See section 391-3-4-.01 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Solid waste handling means the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposal of solid waste, or any combination of such activities. (See section 391-3-4-.01 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Tree trimmings means tree leaves or needles, branches, limbs and parts of trees. 
Tire retailer means any person engaged in the business of selling new, retreaded or used replacement tires. 
Waste means all discarded substances and materials whatsoever exceeding ten pounds in weight or 15 cubic feet in volume, or any such substance in any weight or volume if biomedical waste, hazardous waste (subject to permit under 33 USC 1342), a hazardous substance, or any such substance or material dumped for commercial purposes. With the exception of non-hazardous, low-impact animal byproducts classified by the state department of natural resources, the term "waste" includes, without limitation, sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, waste material, tin cans, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, dead animals, bottles, boxes, containers, papers, tobacco products, tires, appliances, mechanical equipment or parts, building or construction materials, tools, machinery, wood, motor vehicles and motor vehicle parts, vessels, aircraft equipment, waste oil, batteries, antifreeze, sludge from a wastewater treatment facility, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility, air contaminants from any source or facility, and any other discarded material or substance of every kind and description resulting from domestic, industrial, commercial, mining, or governmental operations. (See section 391-3-4-.01 of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management.) 
Yard trimmings means leaves, brush, grass clippings, shrub and tree prunings, discarded Christmas trees, nursery and greenhouse vegetative residuals, and vegetative matter resulting from landscaping development and maintenance other than mining, agricultural, and silvicultural operations. Yard and garden trimmings must not exceed three feet in length or 35 pounds in weight. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § I, 10-21-2002) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Waste control, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-51; waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22; littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42. 
Sec. 78-72. - Penalties; payment of costs of cleanup and enforcement actions; enforcement by state or federal agencies. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction in the municipal court, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(b)  In the sound discretion of the judge of the court with jurisdiction, the person may also be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway and/or other public right-of-way, for a distance not to exceed one mile, any litter the person has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution of sentence. 
(c)  In the sound discretion of the judge of the court with jurisdiction, the person may be directed to pick up and remove from any public park, private right-of-way, or, with the prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that the person has deposited litter, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence. 
(d)  The court may order the publication of the names and photographs of persons convicted of violating this article. 
(e)  The court may order the person to repair or restore property damaged, or pay damages resulting from such violations, or perform public service related to the repair or restoration of property damaged by the violation. 
(f)  In case of an open dump or improper solid waste, litter or waste disposal site, the property owner, contractor, developer, builder or other person responsible for the property shall cause the property to be cleaned and to come into full compliance with this article. The city shall not be responsible for any costs of cleanup or remediation. 
(g)  The expenses incurred by the city for cleanup, enforcement and penalties shall be chargeable to the violator, including, but not limited to, court costs, filing fees, special investigations, mutual aid assistance from other agencies and other costs necessary for the reasonable enforcement of this article. 
(h)  In addition to actions filed by the city for violations of this article, any state or federal agency may independently file separate or concurrent charges within their respective applicable authority and seek conviction within a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § XI, 10-21-2002) 
State Law reference— Littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-43; penalties for dumping, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-53. 
Sec. 78-73. - Responsibility for enforcement; right of entry; appeals. 
(a)  Enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the city manager or his designated agents, to include the city police officers, the superintendent of public works and the environmental education and enforcement officer. 
(b)  Any person authorized to enforce this article shall be empowered to enter any property, upon reasonable cause, at reasonable or necessary times, in order to properly inspect for violations of this article, subject to the condition that, to allow entry onto private property for inspection, the alleged violation of this article must be visible from a public road or right-of-way, or upon such person having received a valid complaint alleging a violation of this article, or by a judge's order upon such person having received information or allegations that constitute reasonable suspicion that a serious unlawful act or threat to the health and safety of the community and/or the environment has occurred or is about to occur. 
(c)  Appeals for the violation of this article may be made to the municipal court of the city, or higher court if the person so chooses. The person always has the right to consult his attorney at any time before the hearing is scheduled for court. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § XII, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-74. - Civil remedies; abatement of nuisances. 
(a)  If the superintendent of public works of his designee or other public official determines the location of solid waste to be a nuisance, procedures identified in chapter 46, article II, division 2 shall be used. 
(b)  In addition, the city may immediately revoke or suspend any and all business, building, development or any and all other city-issued permits related to the property involved with the violation until such time that compliance is met, or until the ruling of a court of competent jurisdiction is obtained, at which time respective permits may be reissued. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § XIII, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-75. - Evidence of violation involving unlawful dumping. 
(a)  Whenever litter, or any type of waste as defined in this article, is thrown, deposited, dropped, or dumped by any person or from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane, or other conveyance in violation of this article, it shall be prima facie evidence that such person or the operator of the conveyance has violated this article. 
(b)  Whenever any litter, or any type of waste as defined in this article, which is dumped, deposited, thrown, or left on public or private property in violation of this article is discovered to contain any article, including, but not limited to, letters, bills, publications, or other writings, which displays the name of a person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this article. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § XIV, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-76. - Waste disposal generally. 
(a)  Responsibility of property owners and occupants. The owner or occupant of any premises shall be responsible for the sanitary handling and disposal of all litter, waste, scrap tires, and municipal, commercial or industrial solid waste on the premises used or occupied by such person. 
(b)  Illegal dumping. It shall be unlawful to dump, open dump, or permit the dumping of litter, waste, scrap tires, municipal, commercial, or industrial solid waste or recyclables at any place in the city, including, without limitation, in or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, any public or private property in the city or any waters in city unless such litter or waste originates in the city or other areas authorized by the city council and: 
(1)  The property is designated by the city council or its duly designated agent for the disposal of litter, waste, municipal, commercial or industrial solid waste, scrap tires or recovered materials and the person is authorized to use such property; 
(2)  The litter, waste, municipal, commercial or industrial solid waste, recyclables or scrap tires are placed into a receptacle or container installed specifically for such property; and 
(3)  The property has a valid solid waste handling permit issued by the state environmental protection division when required. 
(c)  Scrap tires. All persons defined as scrap tire generators, scrap tire carriers, scrap tire processors, including scrap tire sorters, and retail tire dealers shall be subject to rules as defined in chapter 391-3-4 et seq. of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management and handle scrap tires in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. and the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management, chapter 391-3-4 et seq., applicable to solid waste. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § II, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-77. - Transporting waste; improper disposal of recyclables by waste transporter. 
(a)  All vehicles, driving or stationary, within the city shall be so constructed, loaded, covered, or securely fastened so as to prevent municipal, commercial, or industrial solid waste or any load, contents, litter, or other such waste or materials from flowing freely, being blown, scattered, leaked, spilt, or in any manner being deposited in or upon any highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, sidewalk, other motor vehicles, pedestrians, or other public places, or upon private property within the city. However, this section shall not prohibit the necessary and permitted spreading of any substance in public road maintenance or public road construction operations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a business or private person engaged in waste hauling or transportation for hire from businesses or private residences to dispose of materials as solid waste that have been intentionally sorted as recyclables by the business or private residence to a lawfully permitted disposal facility rather than placing the materials in the location designated by the city or appropriate authority for such recyclables. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or move any vehicle within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry unto or deposit in or upon any highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, sidewalk, or other public place or upon private property within the city, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § III, 10-21-2002) 
State Law reference— Secured loads, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-254. 
Sec. 78-78. - Use of containers. 
(a)  Maintenance of containers and surrounding area. All solid waste or litter containers or receptacles and their surrounding area shall be maintained in as sanitary a manner as is reasonably possible consistent with their use for solid waste and litter disposal. 
(b)  Use generally. Persons using solid waste and litter containers or receptacles shall deposit only authorized solid waste and refuse in the appropriate container or receptacle. 
(c)  Scrap tires. No person shall deposit a scrap tire in any container or receptacle unless authorized by the owner of the receptacle or the city council or its designee. 
(d)  Burning or smoldering material. No person shall deposit any burning or smoldering material in such container or receptacle, or set fire to the contents of any such container or receptacle. 
(e)  Bulky items. No person shall deposit large noncompatible articles in containers or receptacles, such as, but not limited to, stoves, refrigerators, bedsprings, automobile parts, boat parts, large tree limbs or air conditioning units, except containers or receptacles designated for that purpose only. 
(f)  Flammable or explosive materials. No person shall deposit any flammable or explosive materials in any such container or receptacle. 
(g)  Dead animals. No dead animals shall be deposited in any such container or receptacle, except containers or receptacles designed for such purpose and so designated by the city council. 
(h)  Damaging or moving containers. No person shall willfully damage or alter the location of such container or receptacle without the written consent of the city council. 
(i)  Scavenging. No salvage or scavenging operations shall be conducted in or around such containers or receptacles except by written consent of the city council. 
(j)  Scattering contents of containers. No person shall indiscriminately scatter or disperse the contents of any containers or receptacles. 
(k)  Use of containers at city collection and recycling center. No person shall deposit any solid waste at a city solid waste collection and recycling center unless such solid waste is contained in a manner that it can be handled by the attendant, and waste shall be deposited only during the official hours of operation unless express written permission is given by the city council or its designee. 
(l)  Improper use of receptacles designated for recyclable materials. No person shall deposit solid waste, litter or liquid of any kind at any city solid waste collection and recycling center into city-owned receptacles or containers designated for the collection of recovered materials. Only authorized materials, such as glass, aluminum, newspaper, cardboard, plastic, and tin or other accepted material, may be deposited in the appropriate container designated for such material. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § IV, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-79. - Ownership of refuse. 
All refuse, including refuse deposited in approved refuse containers, shall remain the property of the owner, occupant, or agent owning, holding or occupying the property on which the refuse was generated or accumulated until the refuse has been placed in a public works department or approved private hauler vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § V, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-80. - Noncollectible refuse. 
Certain types of refuse shall not be collected by the public works department, but shall be removed by the applicable resident, commercial customer, contractor, or approved private hauler. These types of refuse include the following: 
(1)  Tree trimmings shall not be collected where trees are trimmed or cut for compensation, whether the compensation be in cash or in the wood from the trees trimmed or cut, except in the case of a natural disaster. 
(2)  Yard trimmings and debris from the original development of a lot shall not be collected. However, where the city requires the cleaning of a vacant lot by a person, whether the owner, occupant, or agent owning, holding, or occupying the property, the debris therefrom, excluding stumps, shall be collected for the applicable fee. 
(3)  Building material waste generated whereby the construction was done for compensation shall not be collected. However, building material waste generated whereby the construction was done by the owner on the residence in which he resides shall be collected for the applicable fee. 
(4)  Hazardous waste shall not be collected. 
(5)  Industrial waste shall not be collected. 
(6)  Sanitary waste shall not be collected. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § VI, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-81. - Prohibited acts. 
The following activities are declared to be unlawful and in violation of this chapter: 
(1)  Unlawful deposit of refuse; burying refuse. No person shall deposit on or bury in or cause to be deposited on or buried in any public land, park, street, alley, vacant or unoccupied lot or drainage ditch, any garbage, household debris, building materials, rubbish, litter, scrap tires, filth, carrion, weeds, undergrowth, brush, yard trimmings, or other refuse. No person shall deposit or bury any such materials on or in the property of another without the prior consent of the owner, and then not in violation of other sections of this chapter or any other state or federal laws. 
(2)  Disturbing container or contents. No person, other then the owner, occupant, or agent owning, holding, or occupying the property whereon refuse is generated, a city employee, or an approved private hauler, shall disturb any refuse container or remove its cover or any of the contents thereof, or cause such refuse container or its contents to be strewn or scattered on the lawns, sidewalks, or streets. 
(3)  Disposal of certain materials restricted. No smoldering ashes or other smoldering combustible materials residue, building materials, household debris, yard trimmings, or scrap tires shall be placed inside any refuse container or be mixed with any other refuse. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § VII(A)—(C), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-82. - Time for placing containers on right-of-way and removal of containers from right-of-way. 
A residential customer shall place household debris for collection no earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day before the day of collection and roll back the container from the street right-of-way on the day of collection. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § VII(D), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-83. - Operation of city collection center. 
(a)  The city will operate a solid waste/scrap tire center within the public works area located at 256 W. Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive. 
(b)  No landfill shall be operated in the city. 
(c)  No person shall deposit solid waste of any kind outside the gate of a city solid waste/scrap tire collection center. 
(d)  No scavenging operation of any kind shall be allowed at a solid waste/scrap tire enter. 
(e)  No person shall move, remove, or cross any fence, gate, barrier, or sign at a solid waste/scrap tire center. 
(f)  The price on scrap tires brought to the center will be set to defray the total cost of solid waste and recycling operations. 
(g)  Hours of operation of such centers will be set to maximize convenience to residents of that area. 
(h)  The attendant on duty will have full authority over the center consistent with this article. 
(i)  Residents may dispose of scrap tires in the following categories: 
(1)  Passenger tires. 
(2)  Truck tires. 
(3)  Tractor tires. 
Disposal fees shall be set for each category from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § VIII(A)—(G), (H)(1), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-84. - Collection of white goods and appliances. 
Residents may have personal white goods (washers, dryers, refrigerators, air conditioning units, etc.) disposed of by contacting the superintendent of public works. An appointment pickup time will be provided. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § VIII(H)(2), 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-85. - Recovered materials. 
Recovered materials and recovered materials processing facilities are subject to rules as defined in chapter 391-3-4 et seq. of the Georgia Rules for Solid Waste Management. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § IX, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-86. - Burying or burning waste; accumulations of waste causing hazard or nuisance. 
(a)  No owner or occupant of any property shall bury or burn litter or waste without prior authorization and written consent from the applicable regulatory agency, including but not limited to the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the state environmental protection division and/or the state forestry commission, and the city fire department. Nothing in this section shall authorize or be construed to permit the burial or burning of any material which is otherwise prohibited by state and/or federal law. 
(b)  No owner or occupant of any property shall cause, suffer or allow the accumulation, on his premises, of garbage, litter or waste where such material creates or causes a health hazard to neighbors or other citizens, or which is unsightly or emits foul or obnoxious odors. 
(c)  The conduct described in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall constitute a separate violation of this article for each day the garbage, litter or waste material remains or continues to unlawfully pollute, contaminate or burn on such premises. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § X, 10-21-2002) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 46-31 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. 
Sec. 78-87. - Yard trimmings. 
Yard trimmings shall not be placed in or mixed with solid waste. Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any solid waste disposal facility having liners and leachate collection systems or requiring vertical expansion within the city. Yard trimmings shall be sorted and stockpiled or chipped, composted, used as mulch or otherwise beneficially reused or recycled to the maximum extent feasible. Any yard trimmings to be collected by any entity other than the property owner shall be sorted and stored in such a manner as to facilitate collection, composting, or other handling. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § XV, 10-21-2002) 
Sec. 78-88. - Recycling policy. 
The city council hereby finds that it is in the best interest of citizens of the city, in order to promote the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city, to recycle as many waste materials as possible in order to reduce the accumulation of litter and garbage and solid waste materials which must be properly disposed of; therefore, it is the policy of the city to encourage recycling whenever practicable. 
(Ord. No. 2002-18, § XVI, 10-21-2002) 
Chapter 82 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-13(7); any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, sidewalk or alley saved from repeal, § 1-13(8); public possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages, § 10-2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; cemeteries, ch. 30; environment, ch. 46; smoking in places of public entertainment, § 50-6; floods, ch. 54; gutters draining into streets, § 58-4; mobile homes and mobile home parks, ch. 66; camping in lot, street or alley, § 70-7; parks and recreation, ch. 74; depositing filth, slops or garbage in street, § 78-3; sweeping refuse into street, sidewalk or alley, § 78-4; depositing cans or bottles on street or sidewalk, § 78-5; depositing boxes, barrels or similar obstructions on street or sidewalk, § 78-6; traffic and vehicles, ch. 90; riding bicycles in and out of alleys, § 90-10; riding bicycle, tricycle or motorcycle on sidewalk, § 90-11; encroaching on street, alley, crossing or crosswalk, § 90-153; utilities, ch. 94; zoning, app. A; subdivision regulations, app. B; required improvements, design and construction standards for subdivisions, app. B, § 400.1 et seq.; dedication of streets in subdivisions, app. B, § 500. 
State Constitution reference— Street construction and maintenance, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4). 
State Law reference— Obstruction of streets, sidewalks, etc., O.C.G.A. §§ 16-11-43, 32-6-1, 36-30-10; eminent domain, O.C.G.A. tit. 22; highways, bridges and ferries, O.C.G.A. tit. 32; municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; subdivision abutting on state highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-150 et seq.; streets and sidewalks generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; grants for public purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-20 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Duties of superintendent of public works. 
(a)  Inspection of streets, alleys and sidewalks. The superintendent of public works shall make regular inspections of the streets and alleys and sidewalks in the city, and make a written memorandum of such inspection, and cause all defects and obstructions to be remedied at the earliest opportunity; especially shall this be his duty after storms or heavy rainfall. Where grading or regrading is required, he shall call upon the city to perform such grading or regrading. 
(b)  Street cleaning. The superintendent of public works shall take and have charge of the street cleaning department and see that all the highways and parks of the city are kept in a clean condition. 
(Code 1965, § 20-1) 
Sec. 82-2. - Street names continued. 
The present names of the streets and alleys of the city, as platted and mapped by the mayor and council and shown on the official map of the city on file in the office of the city clerk, are hereby readopted and continued. 
(Code 1965, § 20-2) 
Sec. 82-3. - Opening, closing or altering streets. 
No street or alley shall be laid out, closed or altered without the consent of three-fourths of the members of the city council, and any person making application for such purpose shall give at least 30 days' notice thereof in one of the newspapers of the city. Such application shall be acted upon only at a regular meeting of the council. 
(Code 1965, § 20-3) 
Sec. 82-4. - Street and house numbering. 
(a)  Required. All streets of the city shall be numbered, and residences and business houses, of whatsoever kind or character they may be, shall also be numbered. 
(b)  Duty of owner. Every person owning property in the city shall number such property according to regulations and requirements established by or on behalf of the city. 
(c)  Obtaining and affixing number. All owners shall place upon each building on the street side of the building, or, if it be on an upper story, upon the place nearest the entrance from the street, a number which shall be in figures, Arabic in character, and openly display such number. The owner shall make application to the city clerk, furnishing in detail all facts regarding the location of the building for which he desires to obtain a number, and obtain from the city clerk the number he shall use on the building in accordance with the rules and regulations provided by the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 20-4) 
Sec. 82-5. - Encroachments. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any encroachment not authorized upon application to the mayor and council, in or upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-6) 
State Law reference— Obstructing, encroaching on or injuring public roads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1; grant of right to obstruct public street, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10. 
Sec. 82-6. - Franchises. 
(a)  Payment of costs of ordinance publication. Any person to whom any franchise or privilege is granted, to be exercised in and upon the streets of the city or otherwise, shall, as a condition precedent to the exercise of such franchise, pay all costs of publication of the ordinance or part of the ordinance in which such privilege or franchise is granted. Any person failing to comply with the provisions of this subsection shall forfeit any right of franchise contemplated in this subsection which he might have been granted. 
(b)  Prohibited franchises. No person shall be permitted or licensed to locate in or upon the streets of the city any tent, platform or other obstruction, for the purpose of selling any article therefrom. 
(c)  Taxation. The mayor and council shall, in every franchise granted, reserve the right at all times to tax the franchise equally with other property. 
(Code 1965, § 20-7) 
State Law reference— Power of municipalities to grant franchises, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2; taxation of special franchises, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-420 et seq. 
Sec. 82-7. - Excavations in streets or sidewalks. 
(a)  Restoration of surface. It shall be the duty of every person making excavations in and upon the streets or sidewalks of the city for any purpose whatsoever, after the completion of their work, to so fill, pack and tamp such excavation as to prevent the street or sidewalk or any portion thereof from sinking, caving or settling so as to endanger or inconvenience pedestrians or vehicles passing thereover. 
(b)  Protection of public. It shall be the further duty of all persons making such excavations, until they are pronounced safe by the superintendent of public works, to place thereon and keep placed and lighted thereon, between dark and daylight, a sufficient number of lanterns to warn the public, and during the day to protect such excavations. 
(Code 1965, § 20-8) 
Sec. 82-8. - Gasoline pumps and similar pumps prohibited on streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful to erect or to maintain any pump for gasoline or similar fluid in or on any street, alley, or sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-9) 
Sec. 82-9. - Vehicles dropping dirt, rubbish or similar substance on street or sidewalk. 
It shall be unlawful to haul or transport any dirt, soil, sand, rubbish, or like substance over or in the streets or sidewalks of the city, in any wagon, cart, wheelbarrow or other vehicle from which such dirt, sand, rubbish, or like substance escapes or leaks. 
(Code 1965, § 20-10) 
Sec. 82-10. - Gates opening onto sidewalk. 
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any gate opening upon the public sidewalk of the city to be swung so that it may become, when open, an obstruction to the sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 20-11) 
Sec. 82-11. - Cellar gratings in sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain in the city cellars having openings to the sidewalks of the public streets not covered by iron gratings, the openings of which shall not exceed one inch. 
(Code 1965, § 20-12) 
Sec. 82-12. - Cellar doors. 
No cellar door shall extend more than six feet into any sidewalk, street or alley, nor shall the outer or front part be elevated above the level of such sidewalk, street or alley, nor shall the inner part thereof attached to the building be elevated more than ten inches above the ground or pavement. 
(Code 1965, § 20-13) 
Sec. 82-13. - Embankments. 
No person shall make an embankment in any street, alley or sidewalk in the city, without the permission, first obtained, of the superintendent of public works. Such permission shall be based upon uniform city standards for street maintenance and construction. 
(Code 1965, § 20-14) 
Sec. 82-14. - Loading and unloading heavy goods or vehicles on sidewalk. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to unload upon or to load from the paved sidewalks in the city any large appliance or other heavy goods or vehicles of any description whatsoever. 
(Code 1965, § 20-15) 
Sec. 82-15. - Parades and demonstrations. 
All parades, demonstrations or public addresses on the streets or sidewalks of the city are hereby prohibited, except with the written consent of the city manager, given pursuant to uniform city standards as provided by the city council. If the permit is denied, the denial may be appealed to the city council, whose decision is final. 
(Code 1965, § 20-16) 
Sec. 82-16. - Crowds on sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for persons to congregate in such numbers on the sidewalks of the city so as to obstruct the sidewalks. 
(Code 1965, § 20-17) 
Sec. 82-17. - Display of goods or merchandise. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk, or other public place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale. 
(b)  Any adjoining property owner upon application and approval by the city council may display goods and merchandise for sale on the sidewalks immediately adjacent to their property. The display and sale of merchandise, including the sale and service of food and beverages, shall not impede the free flow of traffic 
(c)  The adoption of this section shall not confer any right to any property owner to display merchandise on the sidewalk, and any application or permit granted may be denied by the city council if in the sole judgment of the council the display of merchandise is an impediment to the free flow of traffic, is unsightly or offensive, or in any way threatens the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2003-23, §§ 1—3, 1-5-2004) 
Secs. 82-18—82-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Sign regulations, app. A, § 18.01 et seq. 
State Law reference— Street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq. 

Sec. 82-41. - Advertisement for bids. 
In all cases where street improvements of any character, amounting to $100.00 or more, are ordered to be done by contract, such contract shall be let only to the lowest and best bidder, after advertising for bids, which advertisement shall be made by at least two publications in the paper in which sheriff's advertisements are published, at least ten days before the date set for receiving bids; provided that what is the best bid shall be determined by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 20-30) 
Sec. 82-42. - Supervision of work. 
All paving, curbing, macadamizing and grading, where any of the cost is to be assessed against the abutting owners, whether the city is doing the work or the work is done by contract, shall be under the control and direction of the mayor and council by and with the advice of the superintendent of public works, whose duty it will be to advertise for bids for the work where required, to receive and act upon bids, to take general supervision of the work and make certain that the work is performed in a proper manner. 
(Code 1965, § 20-31) 
Sec. 82-43. - Inspection and acceptance required prior to payment for work. 
No paving, curbing or other street improvement made through a contractor shall be paid for until inspected and formally approved by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 20-32) 
Sec. 82-44. - Itemized estimate of cost required. 
In all cases where an ordinance is introduced providing for any street improvements, before the ordinance shall pass, it shall be accompanied by, or have endorsed thereon, an itemized estimate, to be made by the proper authority, of the cost of the improvement contemplated. 
(Code 1965, § 20-33) 
Sec. 82-45. - Ordinance directing paving, macadamizing or repair; conformance with state specifications. 
All paving, macadamizing and repairing, and all repaving, recurbing and remacadamizing, shall be ordered by ordinance only, and such work shall be performed in accordance with state specifications. 
(Code 1965, § 20-34) 
Sec. 82-46. - Improvement ordinances to specify amounts assessed. 
All ordinances providing for the improvement of streets, wherein it is contemplated that part of the cost is to be borne by the abutting owners, shall specify what portion of the cost is to be borne by the city and the abutting owners respectively. 
(Code 1965, § 20-35) 
Sec. 82-47. - Single unit plan of assessment to be followed. 
All paving, curbing, macadamizing and grading, where any of the cost is to be assessed against the abutting property owners, shall be done in units or single plans, and separate assessments made for each unit or plan, and only paving or macadamizing of the same width and quality shall be included in one unit or single plan for purposes of assessment. 
(Code 1965, § 20-36) 
Sec. 82-48. - Preparation and contents of assessment roll. 
After the completion of any paving, curbing, macadamizing, or grading or the repair of such, or any repaving, recurbing, remacadamizing or regrading, whether or not the same is by contract, if any part is to be assessed against the abutting owners, it shall be the duty of the city attorney acting with the superintendent of public works to prepare an assessment roll or sheet containing: 
(1)  The name and portion of the street improved. 
(2)  The number of lineal feet improved on the street. 
(3)  The names of the owners of the property abutting the improvement and the number of lineal or front feet owned by each. 
(4)  The total cost of the improvement. 
(5)  The city's proportionate part of the cost. 
(6)  The abutting owner's proportionate part of the cost. 
(7)  An itemized statement of the material and labor employed in the improvement and the cost thereof. 
The assessment roll shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 20-37) 
Sec. 82-49. - Due date for assessments. 
As soon as the assessment roll provided for in section 82-48 has been approved and signed by the mayor and council and the superintendent of public works, the assessment shall become due and payable. 
(Code 1965, § 20-38) 
Sec. 82-50. - Notice to abutting owners of amount due. 
As soon as the assessment roll provided for in this article shall be filed with the city clerk, it shall be his duty to render to each abutting owner a statement of the amount due by him, which statement shall show: 
(1)  The number of front feet chargeable to the abutting owner. 
(2)  The number of lineal or front feet improved. 
(3)  The total cost thereof. 
(4)  The amount chargeable to the city. 
(5)  The amount chargeable to the abutting owners. 
(6)  The cost per front foot to the abutting owners. 
(7)  The amount due from the person notified. 
(Code 1965, § 20-39) 
Sec. 82-51. - Failure to pay assessment after notice; deferred payments. 
(a)  Failure to pay assessment. If the amount due from the abutting owner for an assessment under this article is not paid within 15 days after receipt of the notice provided for in section 82-50, it shall be the duty of the city clerk immediately to issue execution for such amount. 
(b)  Deferred payments. If any property owner, against whom an assessment has been made, upon presentation of the bill for such assessment, does not desire to pay all of the bill, it shall be permissible for the clerk to issue execution, stay same and accept 25 percent of the bill, and to take such person's notes for the balance in installments equal to one-fourth of the balance, payable quarterly in the year thence next ensuing; provided, however, that such person shall agree in such notes that a default in the payment of any one of the deferred payments shall cause the entire bill to become due and payable immediately, and execution to proceed as in other cases for the payment due, and shall further agree to pay seven percent interest on all such deferred payments. It shall likewise be permissible, after execution has issued, except execution proceedings for defaults in case of deferred payments, for the chief of police to accept a like payment of the execution. It shall be agreed that in no event shall the notes given be considered payment of the bill or the execution until all are paid, nor shall the execution lose its lien on the property involved by reason of such extended settlement, but it shall remain in full force and effect until fully paid. 
(Code 1965, § 20-40) 
Sec. 82-52. - Issuance, form and enforcement of execution for assessment. 
All executions issued for sidewalk or street improvement assessments shall be issued by the city clerk, shall be directed to the chief of police, shall issue against the property abutting such improvements and the owner thereof, shall be returnable to the mayor and council after collection, shall specify clearly for what they are issued, and shall be enforced by levy and sale of the property, after advertisement, in the same manner as executions for taxes under existing ordinances. The property sold thereunder shall be subject to all incidents of purchase by the city and redemption by the owner. 
(Code 1965, § 20-41) 
Sec. 82-53. - Levy and sale under execution for assessment. 
All assessment executions immediately after issuance shall be placed in the hands of the chief of police, who shall proceed at once to collect the execution by levy on sufficient of the property designated to make the amount of the execution, and by sale of such property. 
(Code 1965, § 20-42) 
Sec. 82-54. - Transfer of execution for assessment. 
After assessment executions are issued, the execution may be transferred by the chief of police to any person desiring to acquire the execution, as provided by O.C.G.A. § 48-3-19; provided that, if the payment of the execution has been extended, such transfer shall be made subject to such extension. 
(Code 1965, § 20-43) 
Sec. 82-55. - Docketing executions for assessments. 
All executions proceedings provided for in this article shall be entered on the general execution docket in the office of the clerk of the superior court of the county, as is provided by law for other executions. 
(Code 1965, § 20-44) 
State Law reference— General execution docket, O.C.G.A. § 9-12-81. 
Secs. 82-56—82-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AWNINGS AND OTHER PROJECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes:
