Charter reference— Authority of mayor and council as to streets, alleys, sidewalks and ways in city, § 6-18. 

Sec. 82-81. - Support. 
All awnings or shelters of any character or material extending over public sidewalks from buildings shall be supported by braces extending from such buildings, from a point above the awning or shelter. 
(Code 1965, § 20-55) 
Sec. 82-82. - Clearance over sidewalk. 
No awning shall be closer to a sidewalk than eight feet. 
(Code 1965, § 20-56) 
Sec. 82-83. - Posts. 
All persons maintaining any posts for the support of awnings and shelters extending over sidewalks and streets from buildings shall remove such obstructions immediately upon being served with written notice to do so. 
(Code 1965, § 20-57) 
Sec. 82-84. - Galvanized iron awnings prohibited in first fire district. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect galvanized iron awnings anywhere within the first fire district of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-58) 
Chapter 86 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-13(1); any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-13(7); any ordinance levying, imposing or otherwise relating to taxes not codified in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-13(11); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-341 et seq.; excise tax on malt beverages and wine, § 10-101 et seq.; businesses, ch. 26; occupation tax, § 26-61 et seq. 
State Law reference— Local taxation of insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1 et seq.; revenue and taxation, O.C.G.A. tit. 48; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; local taxation of rooms, lodgings or accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 86-1—86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAX 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-31. - Fiscal year; annual budget or assessment roll required; preparation of budget; budget hearing. 
(a)  The city's fiscal year shall commence on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 of the following year. 
(b)  Each year, prior to the assessment of ad valorem tax, the mayor and council shall have prepared by the city manager a budget or assessment roll, showing briefly the estimated expenses of the city. 
(c)  The proposed budget shall, at a minimum, be an estimate of the financial requirements at the legal level of control for each fund requiring a budget for the appropriate budget period and shall be in such form and detail, with such supporting information and justifications, as may be prescribed by the city manager or the mayor and council. The budget document, at a minimum, shall provide, for the appropriate budget period, a statement of the amount budgeted for anticipated revenues by source and the amount budgeted for expenditures at the legal level of control. In accordance with the minimum required legal level of control, the budget document shall, at a minimum, provide a statement of the amount budgeted for expenditures by department for each fund for which a budget is required. This does not preclude the city from preparing a budget document or establishing a legal level of control at a more detailed level of budgetary control than the minimum required legal level of control. 
(d)  On the date established by the mayor and council, the proposed budget shall be submitted to the mayor and council for that body's review prior to enactment of the budget ordinance or resolution. 
(e)  On the day that the proposed budget is submitted to the mayor and council for consideration, a copy of the budget shall be placed in a public location which is convenient to the residents of the city. The mayor and council shall make every effort to provide convenient access to the residents during reasonable business hours so as to accord every opportunity to the public to review the budget prior to adoption by the mayor and council. A copy of the budget shall also be made available, upon request, to the news media. 
(f)  A statement advising the residents of the city of the availability of the proposed budget shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. The notice shall be published during the week in which the proposed budget is submitted to the mayor and council. In addition, the statement shall also advise the residents that a public hearing will be held at which time any persons wishing to be heard on the budget may appear. The statement shall be a prominently displayed advertisement or news article and shall not be placed in that section of the newspaper where legal notices appear. 
(g)  At least one week prior to the meeting of the mayor and council at which adoption of the budget ordinance or resolution will be considered, the mayor and council shall conduct a public hearing, at which time any persons wishing to be heard on the budget may appear. 
(h)  The mayor and council shall give notice of the time and place of the budget hearing required by subsection (g) of this section at least one week before the budget hearing is held. The notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. The statement shall be a prominently displayed advertisement or news article and shall not be placed in that section of the newspaper where legal notices appear. The notice required by this subsection may be included in the statement published pursuant to subsection (f) of this section in lieu of separate publication of the notice. 
(i)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to preclude the conduct of further budget hearings if the mayor and council deem such hearings necessary and comply with the requirements of subsection (f) of this section. 
State Law reference— Annual budget and adopted fiscal year, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-3; preparation and submission of proposed budget, election of fiscal year, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-5. 
Sec. 86-32. - Annual budget ordinance. 
(a)  On a date after the conclusion of the hearing required in section 86-31(g), the mayor and council shall adopt a budget ordinance or resolution making appropriations in such sums as the mayor and council may deem sufficient, whether greater or less than the sums presented in the proposed budget. The budget ordinance or resolution shall be adopted at a public meeting, which shall be advertised in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 86-31(f) at least one week prior to the meeting. 
(b)  The budget may be prepared in any form that the mayor and council deem most efficient in enabling them to make the fiscal policy decisions embodied in the budget, but such budget shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
State Law reference— Adoption of budget ordinance required, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-6. 
Sec. 86-33. - Due date. 
In each year, taxes shall be due and payable the day following the date of the assessment thereof by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1965, § 21-19) 
Sec. 86-34. - Assessment and levy of tax. 
An assessment of ad valorem tax must be made by the mayor and council in each year, based upon the assessed value of the taxable property within the city, as soon after such assessed value has been reported to the mayor and council by the board of assessors as is practicable. Such assessment shall be made by ordinance, which ordinance shall be the warrant or authority to the officers charged with the collection thereof to collect the tax. 
(Code 1965, § 21-20) 
Sec. 86-35. - Persons chargeable with tax. 
(a)  Generally. Taxes are to be charged against the owner of the property, if known, and against the specific property itself, if not known. Life tenants and those who own and enjoy the property are chargeable with the tax thereon. 
(b)  Agents of nonresidents. All persons who return property for persons nonresident in the city shall be personally liable for the taxes, as well as the principal and his property. 
(Code 1965, § 21-21) 
State Law reference— Taxation chargeable, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-9. 
Sec. 86-36. - Procedure when ownership of property is unknown. 
When the owners of real estate in the city are unknown, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to advertise a list of such city lots and if, after the expiration of 30 days, such real estate is not claimed and returned, the assessors of real estate shall assess a fair value thereon, as in other cases, and the clerk shall enter the same upon the digest as unknown and in default, assess a double tax thereon, issue execution for the amount of such tax and place the execution for collection with the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection; provided, nevertheless, that nothing in this section shall be so construed as to relieve the property not returned within the time prescribed from a double tax. 
(Code 1965, § 21-22) 
State Law reference— Penalty and interest on willful failure to pay ad valorem tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-2-44. 
Sec. 86-37. - Taxable property. 
(a)  Generally. All real and personal property held or owned by individuals or corporations, resident or nonresident, is liable to taxation, except such as is expressly exempt under the constitution or statutes of the state. 
(b)  Property of transient. Whenever at any time during any year any transient person shall temporarily locate in the city for the purpose of selling or disposing of goods, wares or merchandise, it shall be the duty of the city clerk or, if his tax lists have been up for the year, then of the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection, to cause such person to make a return for taxation of all his stock in trade at its fair market value to the city tax assessors, as in other cases, and in case such person shall neglect or refuse to return the same within 24 hours after such demand, it shall be the duty of the clerk, or the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection, as the case may be, to report same to the city tax assessors, who shall immediately assess and determine the same as in other cases, and the tax shall be computed thereon at the rate of assessment of the city taxes, and if a city rate has not been fixed for the current year, then the rate for the previous year shall prevail. In case such person shows that such property has been returned and the taxes assessed thereon paid, then no further tax shall be assessed for the year. 
(Code 1965, § 21-23) 
State Law reference— Taxable property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-3. 
Sec. 86-38. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Generally. Categories of property identified in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-41 are exempt from ad valorem taxation. 
(b)  Capital of banks or banking associations. No tax shall be assessed upon the capital of banks or banking associations located within the city, but the shares of the stockholders of the banks and banking associations, whether resident or nonresident owners, shall be taxed at their full market value, including surplus and undivided profit, but at the same rate as other property; provided that nothing in this subsection shall be construed to relieve such banks or banking associations from the tax on real estate owned by them, but they shall return such real estate at its fair market value; provided further that, where real estate is fully paid for, the value at which it is returned for taxation may be deducted from the value of their shares, and if such real estate is not fully paid for only the value at which the equity owned by them therein as returned for taxation shall be deducted from the market value of the shares. 
(c)  Unlawful exemptions. The mayor and council shall not exempt for taxation any manufactory or industrial enterprise or any property of any kind not exempt by law. 
(Code 1965, § 21-24) 
State Law reference— Exemptions from all ad valorem property tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-41. 
Sec. 86-39. - Appeal from assessment by tax assessors. 
(a)  Right of appeal. When the board of tax assessors of the city has assessed the taxes of any person owning property in the city, and after such person has had notice of the assessment placed on his property by the board, the person whose property has been assessed shall have the right to appeal the decision of the tax assessor pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-311. 
(b)  Filing. Such appeal shall be pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-311. 
(c)  Hearing. Hearings on appeals shall be pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-311. 
(Code 1965, § 21-25) 
Sec. 86-40. - Returns and collections for previous years. 
The city clerk shall receive returns and collect taxes thereon for former years, when any person is in default, which taxes shall be assessed according to the law in force at the time the default occurred, and shall be so specified in the digest. 
(Code 1965, § 21-26) 
Sec. 86-41. - Collection of taxes. 
The city clerk shall cause taxes to be collected in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1965, § 21-27) 
Sec. 86-42. - Tax records. 
(a)  Receipts. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep a stub book of tax receipts and enter on the receipt and stub attached thereto the name of each taxpayer and the amount of taxes assessed against him. 
(b)  Execution docket. The city clerk also shall keep an execution docket and on December 20 in each year shall issue executions against delinquent or defaulting taxpayers and enter the names of each delinquent and defaulting taxpayer on the docket, together with a description of the execution, and when the executions have been issued it shall be his duty to clip from the stub book of tax receipts the unsigned receipts of the taxpayer and attach the receipt to the execution issued and place the execution in the hands of the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection and make an entry on the execution docket of the date of delivery thereof to the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection and note on the stub disposition of the receipt. 
(c)  Digest. It shall also be the duty of the city clerk to make out two alphabetically arranged digests of the returns of the taxpayers and furnish one, on the date upon which the tax for the current year is levied by the mayor and council, to the city clerk and keep one on file in his office for the use of the mayor and council. To each of such digests he shall compile, alphabetically arranged, a list of the persons or subjects of taxation in default. The form of the digest shall be such as the clerk may deem proper, to include a substantial digest of the returns and proper entries of payments, double tax and such other entries as may be useful, and city taxes shall be collected and receipted for from these digests. 
(d)  Insolvent list. It shall be the duty of the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection to make a complete list of insolvent persons against whom he holds executions with an entry thereon of "nulla bona," and file such list with the city clerk. When the list has been allowed or approved by the mayor and council, the clerk shall then receipt the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection for the amount of executions with the "nulla bona" entries, and the receipt shall be his voucher to be credited on his account with the city. 
(e)  List of tax defaulters. The clerk shall record in books kept for the purpose, in alphabetical order, the names of all persons who have not paid their taxes, placing opposite the name of each person the amount due for such taxes, and the year due. When any tax shall be collected after such record is made, it shall be applied to the oldest tax payments due from the person paying the tax. 
(Code 1965, § 21-28) 
State Law reference— Collection of taxes of former years, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-27; tax collector execution docket, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-161. 
Sec. 86-43. - Rates of interest, costs and penalty fees. 
The following rates of interest, fi. fa. cost and penalty fees on delinquent taxes will be set by resolution of the city council from time to time: 
(1)  Compounding annual interest rate. 
(2)  Fi. fa. cost. 
(3)  Penalty. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, 10-3-1988) 
Secs. 86-44—86-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXECUTION FOR TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Tax executions, O.C.G.A. § 48-3-1 et seq.; tax sales, O.C.G.A. § 48-4-1 et seq.; sale of property for taxes due municipality, ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359; summons of garnishment against person holding property of defendant owing municipal taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-360. 

Sec. 86-61. - Issuance; form. 
All tax executions shall be issued by the city clerk or designated agent in the form of executions for state and county taxes. 
(Code 1965, § 21-53) 
State Law reference— Issue of execution, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-161. 
Sec. 86-62. - Time for issuance. 
For all taxes unpaid on December 20 in each year, execution shall immediately be issued therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 21-54) 
State Law reference— Executions of tax collectors and commissioners, O.C.G.A. § 48-3-3; time of issuance of executions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-161. 
Sec. 86-63. - Levy. 
All executions for taxes shall be levied in accordance with the levy of state and county tax executions, and all entries thereon shall be made in accordance therewith. 
(Code 1965, § 21-55) 
State Law reference— Leviers of executions, O.C.G.A. § 48-3-6; collection of executions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-161. 
Sec. 86-64. - Collection and return. 
It shall be the duty of the designated agent of the city responsible for tax collection within 90 days after the delivery of tax executions to him to collect or return the tax executions with an entry of "nulla bona" entered thereon. The amount of any execution remaining in his hands after the expiration of such time shall be charged against him and his bond. Likewise, he shall be chargeable with the amount of any execution upon which he has made an entry of "nulla bona" when it shall be made to appear to the mayor and council that such entry is not true. 
(Code 1965, § 21-57) 
State Law reference— Return of execution, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-161. 
Sec. 86-65. - Costs on execution. 
In addition to the principal and interest, the costs allowed by law on all tax executions issued by the clerk shall be collected and such costs shall be turned into the city treasury. 
(Code 1965, § 21-58) 
State Law reference— Collection of costs and expenses, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-161. 
Sec. 86-66. - Receipts on executions. 
It shall be the duty of the city representative responsible for tax collection, upon tax executions being placed in his hands, when such execution is paid by the defendant, voluntarily or by levy and sale, to detach from the execution the tax receipt and enter thereon the amount collected, including all costs, and also to make a similar entry on the execution, the receipt to be delivered by the officer to the defendant, and the execution to be returned to the city clerk with the amount of tax collected. The city clerk at once shall copy the entry of the officer on his execution docket and file the execution in his office. 
(Code 1965, § 21-59) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-161. 
Sec. 86-67. - Tax sales generally; advertisement of tax sales. 
(a)  The time, place and manner of sale of property, both real and personal, for taxes due the city, shall be the same as that provided for sheriff's sales for state and county taxes, when so advertised, and the sale shall be conducted by the chief of police, or, in his absence, by a deputy appointed therefor. 
(b)  All sales of property for taxes due the city shall be advertised the same number of times, in the same paper and in the same manner as sheriff's sales in the county for state and county taxes are advertised. 
(Code 1965, § 21-60) 
State Law reference— Judicial sales, O.C.G.A. § 9-13-140 et seq.; tax sales, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359. 
Sec. 86-68. - Conduct of tax sales. 
All property sold for city taxes shall be so offered that the smallest amount that will bring the amount of taxes and costs, if not impractical so to do, shall alone be sold. The property sold shall be sold to the highest bidder for cash, and the chief of police shall execute to the purchaser a deed thereto in the usual form of tax deeds. 
(Code 1965, § 21-61) 
Sec. 86-69. - Purchase by city at tax sale. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk and he is hereby authorized to attend all sales of property for taxes due the city, and if no one shall bid for the property put up to be sold as much as the tax for which it is proposed to sell the property and the officer's costs if any are due thereon, after such property shall have been cried a reasonable time, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to bid for such property for the city, and the chief of police shall make a deed to the property sold to the city, and deliver the deed to the city clerk; provided, however, that no property purchased by the city shall ever be sold by the city except at a public sale thereof to the highest bidder; and provided further that the city may, upon unanimous vote of the council, quitclaim the property to the owner thereof or to the owners, administrators, executors, heirs or assigns upon application by the owner and the payment to the city of all taxes, interest and costs due and for which such premises were sold. 
(Code 1965, § 21-62) 
State Law reference— Purchase and sale by municipality, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359. 
Sec. 86-70. - Sales subject to redemption. 
All sales for city taxes shall be subject to redemption by the owner as provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 21-63) 
State Law reference— Redemption of property sold for taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-4-40 et seq. 
Secs. 86-71—86-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL-MOTEL EXCISE TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Excise tax on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq. 

Sec. 86-91. - Tax levied. 
The city levies an excise tax upon the furnishing for value to the public of any room, lodging, or accommodation furnished by any person for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, or any other place in which rooms, lodging or accommodations are regularly furnished for value, in a percentage of the amount of the charge to the public for such rooms and furnishings as set by the city council from time to time, as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2000-06, 8-7-2000) 
Sec. 86-92. - Persons liable for tax. 
(a)  The excise tax levied by this article is imposed on any person licensed by the city or required to pay business or occupation tax to the city for operating a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp, tourist cabin, campground, or any other place in which rooms, lodgings, or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. If the amount of taxes collected from the hotel or motel guest is in excess of the total amount that should have been collected, the total amount actually collected must be remitted. 
(b)  The excise tax is also imposed upon every person who is a hotel or motel guest and who receives a room, lodging, or accommodation that is subject to this tax. Every such guest subject to the tax levied under this article shall pay the tax to the person providing the room, lodging, or accommodation. The person collecting the tax from the hotel or motel guest shall remit the tax to the city and the tax remitted shall be a credit against the tax imposed by subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2000-06, § 1, 8-7-2000) 
Sec. 86-93. - Collection; returns. 
(a)  Collection by operator; remittance to city. It shall be the duty of every operator of a qualifying facility within the corporate limits of the city to collect the tax imposed in this article. All taxes levied by this article shall be due and payable to the city clerk monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each month in which such taxes are collected. The clerk shall furnish the required forms for reporting the tax. 
(b)  Returns. Payment in full shall be accompanied by a return for the preceding calendar month period showing the gross rent, taxable rent, amount of tax collected and such other information as may be required by the clerk. 
(c)  Operator's collection fee; required records. A collection fee will be allowed to reporting operators collecting the tax levied. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state sales tax under O.C.G.A. tit. 48, ch. 8, art. 3 (O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.). Each operator collecting a tax under this article shall keep all records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers setting forth the rental charge for each occupancy and such other information as the clerk may require. 
(d)  Powers of city clerk or city manager. The city clerk or city manager shall administer and enforce the provisions of this section for the collection of the tax imposed in this article, and in doing this shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Examine or authorize the examination of the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any operator renting guestrooms, in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or, if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount required to be paid; 
(2)  Require the filing of reports by any person having in his possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax levied in this article; and 
(3)  Allow credit on any amount due and payable from persons who paid the tax levied in this article but who were erroneously or illegally subjected thereto. 
(e)  Withholding of tax on sale or cessation of business. If any hotel operator becomes liable for any amount required to be paid by this article and subsequent thereto sells out his business or quits the business, the successors or assignees of such operator shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price to cover such amount due. If the purchaser of the business fails to withhold the required amount, he shall become personally liable therefor to the extent of the purchase price. 
(f)  Violations. Any operator or other person who fails to register as required in this article, or who fails to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the city clerk or city manager or who renders a false fraudulent return, shall, upon conviction in the municipal court of the city, be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 2000-06, § 2, 8-7-2000) 
State Law reference— Failure to furnish return, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-61. 
Sec. 86-94. - Expenditure of revenue; accounting; commencement of tax. 
(a)  The city, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3), shall expend in each fiscal year during which the tax levied by this article is collected 60 percent of the revenue generated for the purpose of promoting tourism, conventions and trade shows. Any amounts expended as provided in this subsection shall be expended through a contract with a private sector nonprofit organization. A private sector nonprofit organization shall meet the criteria under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(8)(A). 
(b)  The city shall, prior to each fiscal year in which the tax is imposed, adopt a budget plan specifying how the expenditure requirements will be met as required in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(9)(A). The authorized entity with which the city contracts shall furnish its budget for expenditures it shall make prior to adoption of the city budget. 
(c)  The city audit each year shall reflect whether the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51 have been met. 
(d)  In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(12), levy and collection of this tax shall begin October 1, 2000. 
(Ord. No. 2000-06, § 3, 8-7-2000) 
Chapter 90 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Courts, ch. 38; law enforcement, ch. 62; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Law reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. tit. 40; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; authority of municipal courts to try cases involving state traffic laws, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Crosswalk means: 
(1)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway; or 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
Curb means the edge of the sidewalk, or the line of demarcation between the street proper and the sidewalk, whether marked or understood. 
Horse means any animal used as a conveyance, or to draw a conveyance. 
Limit lines means lines on the pavement defining parking spaces, restricted spaces, safety, danger, direction and neutral zones, and crosswalks. 
Motor vehicle means any vehicle that is self-propelled. 
Operator and driver mean a person who is in control of any vehicle. 
Owner means a person, other than a lienholder or security interest holder, having the property in or title to a vehicle. The term includes a person entitled to the use and possession of a vehicle subject to a security interest in or lien by another person but excludes a lessee under a lease not intended as security except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter. 
Park and parking mean the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or passengers. 
Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use by pedestrians. 
Stop, when required, means complete cessation from movement. 
Stop, stopping and standing , when prohibited, mean any stopping or standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
U-turn means turning a vehicle in order to proceed in the opposite direction. 
Vehicle means every device, in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1965, § 15-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Words and phrases defined for traffic purposes, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1. 
Sec. 90-2. - Rules of the road adopted. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372—40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1—40-6-397, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, are adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 15-44; Ord. No. 80-2, 4-21-1980) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372 et seq. 
Sec. 90-3. - Penalty for violation of rules of the road. 
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the rules of the road adopted by section 90-2 shall be punished by a fine of not more than $250.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days or any combination or portion of such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1965, § 15-45) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-374. 
Sec. 90-4. - Enforcement. 
The duties of enforcing the provisions of this chapter shall be upon the mayor and council, acting through the police department. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 90-5. - Authority of police to divert traffic. 
Police officers of the city may divert traffic at any time or place within the city where it may be deemed necessary to avoid accident or to promote public safety or convenience. 
(Code 1965, § 15-3) 
State Law reference— Obedience to authorized persons directing traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. 
Sec. 90-6. - Use of blue revolving dome lights by emergency vehicles; privileges of drivers of emergency vehicles. 
(a)  All police cars owned and operated by the city and all fire trucks owned and operated by the city shall use and employ and display blue revolving dome lights on roofs or other prominent and visible parts of such vehicles to designate such vehicles as an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(b)  The driver of such authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call, or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions stated in this section. 
(c)  The driver of such an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand, irrespective of any other traffic ordinance or regulation of the city. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or a stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the speed limits specified in traffic ordinances of the city, so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(d)  The exemptions granted in this section to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of any such vehicle while in motion sounds audible signal by bell, siren, or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary, and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying a blue light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that such an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a blue light visible from in front of the vehicle. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall not relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(f)  The use of blue revolving dome lights upon the roofs of vehicles to designate an authorized emergency vehicle shall be restricted to police cars owned and operated by the city and fire trucks owned and operated by the city, and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any other vehicle displaying blue revolving dome lights on the roofs of any other vehicles. 
(Code 1965, § 15-33) 
Sec. 90-7. - Minimum age of operator. 
Except as provided in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-22, it shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 16 years to operate any motor vehicle on any street or alley of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 15-43) 
State Law reference— Persons licensed, minimum age, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-22. 
Sec. 90-8. - Possession of driver's license while operating motor vehicle; failure to exhibit license to police officer. 
(a)  Every licensee shall have his driver's license in his immediate possession at all times when operating a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Every licensee shall display his license upon the demand of a law enforcement officer. A refusal to comply with such demand not only shall constitute a violation of this subsection but shall also give rise to a presumption of a violation of subsection (a) of this section and of O.C.G.A. § 40-5-20. 
(c)  A person convicted of a violation of subsection (a) of this section shall be fined no more than $10.00 if he produces in court a license theretofore issued to him and valid at the time of his arrest. 
(Code 1965, § 15-13) 
State Law reference— Failure to exhibit license, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-29. 
Sec. 90-9. - Children riding bicycles in first fire district. 
It shall be unlawful for any child under 12 years of age to ride a bicycle or tricycle upon any street, alley or highway within the first fire district. 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 90-10. - Riding bicycles in and out of alleys. 
All persons riding bicycles into or out of the public alleys of the city shall ring their bells upon approaching sidewalks, and shall not make their entrance into or exit from such alleys at a faster pace than the ordinary gait of a pedestrian. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 90-11. - Riding bicycle, tricycle or motorcycle on sidewalk. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle or tricycle or motorcycle on any of the sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 15-7) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Secs. 90-12—90-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq. 

Sec. 90-41. - Generally. 
It shall be unlawful to drive or move or to cause or knowingly permit to be driven or moved on any street or highway in the city any vehicle, or combination of vehicles, which is in such unsafe condition as to endanger any person, or which does not contain those parts or is not at all times equipped with such lamps and other equipment in proper condition and adjustment as required in O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq., or which is equipped in any manner in violation thereof, or to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required therein. 
(Code 1965, § 15-23) 
Sec. 90-42. - Lights. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any driver to use or operate on any street or alley of the city, between sunset and sunrise, any vehicle unless the vehicle shall display lights attached to such vehicle as follows: 
(1)  Motor vehicles generally. If a motor vehicle other than a motorcycle, at least two lighted lamps in front, showing white lights visible at least 100 feet ahead of the vehicle; and one light on the rear of the vehicle, showing red to the rear, and illuminating with white light the rear registration plate of such vehicle. 
(2)  Motorcycles. If a motorcycle, a front lamp showing a white light, visible at least 100 feet ahead of the motorcycle; and one light in the rear, showing red to the rear, and illuminating with white light the registration plate of such vehicle. 
(3)  Bicycles. If a bicycle, one white light attached to the front of the bicycle, and one red light or red reflector attached to the rear of the vehicle. 
(b)  Dimming device required. Each of the front lights attached to any motor vehicle shall be provided with a suitable device for dimming the light or changing the focus thereof, in order to prevent dangerous glaring or dazzling rays from the lamps in the eyes of approaching drivers. 
(c)  Use of dimming device. All front lights on motor vehicles shall be dimmed while driving within the first fire district of the city and at all times when meeting other vehicles. 
(d)  Horses. Equestrians and led horses shall not be subject to this section. 
(Code 1965, § 15-24) 
State Law reference— Lighting equipment, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-20 et seq. 
Sec. 90-43. - Brakes and horn required. 
Each motor vehicle shall at all times be properly equipped with safe and efficient brakes and with a horn or other like signalling device, all of which shall be kept in good working condition. 
(Code 1965, § 15-25) 
State Law reference— Brakes required, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-50; horns and warning devices, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-70. 
Sec. 90-44. - Authority of police officers to test brakes and horn. 
The police officers of the city shall be authorized to test brakes and horns or other signalling devices on any motor vehicle at any reasonable time, and it shall be unlawful to refuse to permit any police officer to make such test. 
(Code 1965, § 15-26) 
Sec. 90-45. - Sounding of horn restricted. 
It shall be unlawful to sound the horn or other signalling device on any motor vehicle except when its use is necessary to warn pedestrians or the operators of other vehicles. 
(Code 1965, § 15-27) 
Sec. 90-46. - Mufflers and cutouts. 
Each motor vehicle shall be equipped with a muffler for the exhaust, and shall not be operated within the city with the muffler cutout open. 
(Code 1965, § 15-28) 
State Law reference— Exhaust system, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-71. 
Sec. 90-47. - Unnecessary emission of smoke. 
It shall be unlawful for the operator of an automobile or other vehicle of like kind to operate the vehicle in such manner as will cause the vehicle to emit an unnecessary amount of smoke. 
(Code 1965, § 15-29) 
Sec. 90-48. - Noisy vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful to make any unnecessary vehicular noises by racing the motor of any motor vehicle or otherwise. 
(Code 1965, § 15-30) 
Sec. 90-49. - Vehicles with cleats, ridges or spikes. 
It shall be unlawful to operate on the paved portion of any street in the city any vehicle equipped with wooden or metal cleats, ridges or spikes on the wheels thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 15-31) 
Sec. 90-50. - Lamp or flag on projecting load. 
The driver of any vehicle with any part of its load extending beyond the body of such vehicle shall attach to the end of such protruding load a red light during the period from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise, and shall attach a red flag at all other times. 
(Code 1965, § 15-32) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-27. 
Secs. 90-51—90-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-71. - Carrying passengers in places not intended for passengers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be on or upon the hood, running board, fender or part of any motor vehicle other than on or in the usual seats or spaces provided for passengers in or on the motor vehicle, while such vehicle is being operated in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 15-50) 
State Law reference— Obstruction of driver's view or interference with control of vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-242. 
Sec. 90-72. - U-turns. 
It shall be unlawful to make a U-turn with any vehicle, anywhere in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 15-46) 
State Law reference— U-turns, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-121. 
Sec. 90-73. - Portion of Oak Street designated one-way street. 
It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to enter Oak Street at its point of intersection with the Sylvester-Cordele Highway (Georgia Highway 33), where Oak Street then runs in an easterly direction to the Sylvester-Ashburn Highway (Georgia Highway 112), and that portion of Oak Street leading from the Sylvester-Cordele Highway to the Sylvester-Ashburn Highway shall be a one-way street with flow of traffic only in a westerly direction from the Sylvester-Ashburn Highway to the Sylvester-Cordele Highway. 
(Code 1965, § 15-51) 
State Law reference— Designation of one-way highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(4). 
Sec. 90-74. - Trespass by motor vehicle. 
(a)  No person shall, after having been requested not to do so by a law enforcement officer or an authorized agent of the owner, park or stand an occupied or unoccupied motor vehicle in or repeatedly drive a motor vehicle through or within a parking area located on privately owned property and provided by a merchant, group of merchants, or shopping center or other facility for customers if: 
(1)  The parking area is identified by at least one sign as specified in this section, and if the parking area contains more than 150 parking spaces then by at least one such sign at each entrance to the parking area, each such sign containing the following information in easy-to-read printing: 
a.  Notice of this section; 
b.  Identification of the property which is reserved for customers' use only; 
c.  Identification of the merchant, group of merchants, or shopping center or other similar facility providing the parking area; and 
d.  A warning that violators will be prosecuted. 
(2)  The motor vehicle is parked, is standing, or is being operated other than for the purpose of: 
a.  Transporting some person to or from the interior of the place of business of a merchant identified by the sign in the parking area or to or from the interior of the shopping center or other facility so identified; 
b.  Making use of a telephone, vending machine, automatic teller machine, or other similar facility located in the parking area; 
c.  Meeting the requirements of a situation in which it has unexpectedly become impossible or impractical for the motor vehicle to continue to travel on the public roads; or 
d.  Carrying out an activity for which express permission has been given by the owner of the parking area or an authorized representative of the owner. 
(b)  Any person who violates subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine: 
(1)  Not to exceed $50.00 for the first such offense; 
(2)  Not to exceed $100.00 for the second such offense; and 
(3)  Not to exceed $150.00 for the third or subsequent such offense. 
(Ord. No. 89-5, § 1, 6-5-1989) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions re parking, standing or driving vehicle in private parking area after request not to do so, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252. 
Secs. 90-75—90-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPEED LIMITS 

Sec. 90-101. - Speed limits on specific streets. 
Upon the following streets or parts of streets it shall be unlawful to operate any motor vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding the speed designated therefor: 
(1)  On-system roadways. 

 
Signs are to be installed by the Georgia D.O.T. 
(2)  Off-system roadways. 

 
Signs are to be installed by the City of Sylvester. 
(Code 1965, § 15-48; Ord. No. 2001-14, 8-6-2001; Ord. No. 2010-09, 7-19-2010; Ord. No. 2010-12, 8-16-2010; Ord. No. 2010-15, 11-15-2010) 
State Law reference— Establishment of state speed zones, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-182; alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. 
Sec. 90-102. - Signs on state highways. 
Speed limit signs on state highways shall be furnished and erected by the state department of transportation. 
(Ord. No. 80-2, 4-21-1980) 
Sec. 90-103. - Violation of state highway speed limits. 
Any person convicted of a violation of a speed limit on a state highway shall be punished as provided for by law. 
(Ord. No. 80-2, 4-21-1980) 
State Law reference— Charging violations of speed regulations, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-187. 
Secs. 90-104—90-119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 90-120. - Stop signs. 
(a)  Stop signs shall be erected on Price Street at its intersection with McPhaul Street to control eastbound and westbound traffic. 
(b)  Stop signs shall be erected on Maplewood Lane at its intersection with Pendley Drive to control northbound and southbound traffic. 
(c)  Stop signs shall be erected on Maplewood Lane at its intersection with Rosewood Drive to control northbound and southbound traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1, 2-20-2006) 
DIVISION 4. - PERSONAL TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES 

Sec. 90-121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
Authorized street means a public roadway of the city by whatever name (e.g. road, alley, avenue, highway, route, boulevard, etc.) that: 
(1)  Has a posted speed limit of 35 miles per hour or less; 
(2)  Provides for no more than one lane of vehicular traffic per direction; 
(3)  Is not designated as part of either the state or federal highway system; 
(4)  Has not been designated as an unauthorized street by ordinance or resolution by the city council. 
Driver means the person driving and having physical control over a personal transportation vehicle. 
Owner means the person holding title to the PTV who has a majority ownership interest in the PTV. 
Parking area means those areas accessible to the public by motor vehicular traffic and which are designated for the temporary parking of motor vehicles, usually in places referred to as parking lots. 
Personal Transportation Vehicle (PTV) means any motor vehicle: (1) with a minimum of four wheels, (2) capable of a maximum level ground speed of less than 20 miles per hour, (3) with a maximum gross vehicle unladen or empty weight of 1,375 pounds; and (4) capable of transporting not more than eight persons. 
Unauthorized street means a public roadway of the city by whatever name (e.g. road, alley, avenue, highway, route, boulevard, etc.) that has been designated by the city council by ordinance or resolution as an unauthorized street. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 90-122. - Registration. 
Before any PTV may be operated over an authorized street or parking area of the city it shall be registered with and inspected by the Sylvester Police Department. If the PTV is compliant with local and state law, then a decal shall be issued from that department signifying its registration. The registration requirements include the following specifics: 
(1)  Only those persons 18 years of age or older may register a PTV; 
(2)  The person registering the PTV must be the Owner of the PTV; 
(3)  The decal received from the Sylvester Police Department upon Registration shall be attached and displayed upon the PTV so as to be plainly visible; 
(4)  The registration application shall be made on a form supplied by the City and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Name and address of owner. 
b.  Model, make, name and PTV identification number. 
c.  Current driver's license number of owner and all authorized drivers. 
d.  Such other information as the city may require. 
(5)  The registration application shall be accompanied by a fee of $15.00. 
(6)  The registration application shall be accompanied by evidence of personal liability insurance coverage consistent with the minimum requirements of Georgia law for operational motor vehicles. 
(7)  The registration shall be effective until such time as revoked or the PTV is transferred to a new owner. If the registered owner transfers ownership of the PTV, the registered owner must notify the Sylvester Police Department of the transfer. 
(8)  It shall be the owner of the PTV's responsibility to ensure the information on the application remains current and accurate. 
The Sylvester City Council may, at its discretion, waive registration requirements for city sponsored special events of a limited duration. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 90-123. - Revocation. 
The registration permit may be revoked if: 
(1)  The permit holder no longer has a valid driver's license. 
(2)  The owner or driver of a PTV fails to abide by the rules and regulations of this article. 
(3)  The owner or driver of a PTV fails to abide by the traffic laws in use for a PTV on an authorized street or parking area. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 90-124. - Transfer. 
Upon transfer of ownership of the PTV to a person who intends to operate it over the authorized streets and parking areas, the new owner must register the PTV as outlined herein above. Such registration by the new owner must occur within ten days of the transfer of ownership. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 90-125. - Operation regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate a PTV on any street within the City of Sylvester that is not an authorized street. 
(b)  Only those persons who holds a valid motor vehicle driver's license and who are on the approved driver's list provided by the owner to the Sylvester Police Department at the time of registration may drive a PTV on the authorized streets and parking areas of the city. 
(c)  All drivers of PTVs shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the authorized streets and parking areas of the city. 
(d)  A PTV shall not be operated on the sidewalks at any time. 
(e)  Every driver of a PTV shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all of the rules of the road and duties applicable to the driver of any other vehicle. 
(f)  All PTVs are entitled to a full use of a lane on the authorized streets and parking areas of the city and no motor vehicle shall be driven in such a manner as to deprive any PTV of the full use of a lane. 
(g)  The driver of a PTV shall not overtake and pass in the same lane occupied by the vehicle being overtaken. 
(h)  No driver shall operate a PTV between lanes of traffic or between adjacent lines or rows of vehicles. 
(i)  The driver of a PTV operating on an authorized street may cross a multi-lane road only at a signalized intersection designated for such purpose. 
(j)  The driver of a PTV operating on an authorized street may cross a state or federal route only at intersections that have been designated for such purposes by the Georgia Department of Transportation. 
(k)  A PTV may be operated over authorized streets only during daylight hours unless such PTV is equipped with functional headlights, taillights and front and back turn signals. 
(l)  All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol and its use, including open container laws, which apply to traffic on the streets of the city shall also apply to drivers and occupants of PTVs. 
(m)  All drivers and passengers must remain seated at all times during the operation of the PTV. No person may sit on the driver's lap during the operation of the PTV. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 90-126. - Equipment. 
Each PTV shall be equipped with each of the following safety devices: 
(a)  A braking system sufficient for the weight and passenger capacity of the vehicle including a parking brake; 
(b)  A reverse warning device functional at all times when the directional control is in the reverse position; 
(c)  A main power switch. When the switch is in the "off" position or the key or other device that activates the switch is removed, the motive power circuit shall be inoperative. If the switch uses a key, it shall be removable only in the "off" position; 
(d)  Head lamps; 
(e)  Reflex reflectors; 
(f)  Tail lamps; 
(g)  A horn; 
(h)  A rearview mirror; 
(i)  Safety warning labels; and 
(j)  Hip restraints and hand holds or a combination thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 90-127. - Liability. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as an assumption of liability by the City of Sylvester for any injuries to persons or property which may result from the operation of a PTV or by the failure of the city to revoke said permit. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Sec. 90-128. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates the terms of this article shall be punished as follows: 
In addition to whatever violations of the driver of a PTV may be subject to pursuant to Georgia law and or Code of Municipal Ordinances, the registered owner of the PTV shall be subject to the following civil penalties: 
(1)  For the first offense a fine of not less than $50.00; and, if not timely paid, revocation of the permit. 
(2)  For the second offense, a fine of not less than $100.00; and, if not timely paid, revocation of the permit. 
(3)  For the third offense, the registration for the PTV shall be revoked. In the event the registration is revoked under this section, the PTV cannot thereafter be re-registered by the same owner or any family member for a period of two years. 
(Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1(Exh. A), 5-18-2015) 
Secs. 90-129—90-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Off-street parking and loading requirements, app. A, § 17-01 et seq. 
State Law reference— Stopping, standing and parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq.; power of local authorities to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1). 

Sec. 90-151. - Establishment of limited or restricted parking areas. 
(a)  Signs required. When the mayor and council shall determine that parking in any area should be limited or restricted it shall by resolution direct the chief of police to have appropriate signs placed in or so near such area that any ordinarily observant person may readily see such signs, which signs shall clearly indicate the restriction imposed and the area affected by such restriction, but no one parking in such area shall be subject to prosecution until such signs have been so placed. Upon the adoption of such resolution, it shall be the duty of the chief of police promptly to have such signs prepared and placed. 
(b)  Obedience to signs. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in a restricted or limited parking area in violation of parking restrictions or regulations established by resolution of the mayor and council, when such area and the limitation or restriction is clearly indicated by appropriate signs or markings. 
(Code 1965, § 15-78) 
Sec. 90-152. - Vehicles to be parked within limit lines. 
All vehicles shall be parked within the area designated by the police department of the city for such purposes by limit lines drawn or painted upon the pavement of the streets of the city. Where no such lines have been painted or marked designating such parking spaces, then each such vehicle shall be parked in accordance with the definition of the term "parking" set out in section 90-1. No vehicle shall be parked over or astride any limit line, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 15-79) 
State Law reference— How vehicles to be parked, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200. 
Sec. 90-153. - Encroaching on street, alley, crossing or crosswalk. 
No vehicle shall be parked in such manner as to close or encroach upon any intersecting street, alley, crossing or crosswalk. 
(Code 1965, § 15-81) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Law reference— Obstructing intersection, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-205. 
Sec. 90-154. - Parking in public driveway. 
No vehicle shall be parked in any public driveway. 
(Code 1965, § 15-82) 
Sec. 90-155. - Double-parking; center-parking. 
It shall be unlawful to double-park or to center-park any vehicle in any street; that is, no vehicle shall be parked between the line of vehicles parked adjacent to the curb on one side of such street and the line of vehicles parked adjacent to the curb on the opposite side of the street. 
(Code 1965, § 15-83) 
Sec. 90-156. - Parking vehicle of excessive length. 
No vehicle having a length greater than that of a standard automobile, measured from its front bumper to the extreme rear of the body and load of such vehicle, shall be parked at an angle in any of the streets and ways of the city, but such vehicle shall be parked adjacent to and parallel with the curb on the righthand side of the street in which such vehicle is proceeding. 
(Code 1965, § 15-84) 
Sec. 90-157. - Overnight parking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park an automobile, truck or any other motor or other vehicle upon the paved streets in the city, or leave such vehicle parked upon the streets, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1965, § 15-85) 
Sec. 90-158. - Leaving vehicle while engine is running. 
It shall be unlawful for the person in charge of an automobile or other vehicle of like kind in the city to leave the vehicle upon the streets or alleys of the city while the engine is running or in motion. 
(Code 1965, § 15-86) 
Sec. 90-159. - Authority to establish loading and unloading zones, bus stops and taxicab stands. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the mayor and council from providing for parking space for unloading and loading commercial vehicles, for bus stops, for taxicab stands, or for other matters of a similar nature. 
(Code 1965, § 15-88) 
Secs. 90-160—90-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 90-191. - Noise from locomotive whistles. 
The several railroad companies doing business in the city shall not blow the whistles of locomotives or engines within the city, but the engineers of such locomotives or engines shall signal their approach to public crossings and streets by tolling the bells of such locomotives or engines. 
(Code 1965, § 16-11(a)) 
Sec. 90-192. - Trains blocking crossings. 
It shall be unlawful for any passenger or freight cars or train to obstruct any street crossing within the corporate limits for a longer time than five minutes; provided, however, that this shall not apply to moving passenger or freight cars or trains. The engineer or conductor or corporation in charge of such cars or trains shall be held responsible for such obstruction. 
(Code 1965, § 15-11) 
Sec. 90-193. - Jumping on or off moving train; unlawful boarding. 
No person except employees of the railroad shall jump off or on any moving railroad engine, car or train; nor shall any person go either in or upon any railroad engine, car or train except on business or for the purpose of taking regular passage thereon. 
(Code 1965, § 15-12) 
State Law reference— Hiding on train for purpose of stealing a ride, O.C.G.A. § 46-8-381. 
Sec. 90-194. - Maintenance of railroad crossings. 
(a)  Notice required. In all cases in which a railroad company is required to keep crossings in the city in repair, on or across streets crossed by the tracks of the railroad company, such company shall, when the repairing of such crossings is declared by the mayor and council to be necessary or proper, be notified by the chief of police to commence repairing such crossings, within ten days, and prosecute the same in good faith to completion. 
(b)  Service of notice. The notice provided for shall be in writing and served by the chief of police, on the principal officer of the railroad company in the city or at the principal office of the company. 
(c)  Noncompliance. If the company notified as provided in this section fails or refuses to commence in good faith the repairing of a crossing within the time specified in the notice and in accordance with the provisions of this section, then and in that event the city will perform such work at the charge and expense of such railroad company. Within five days after the completion of the work by the city, the chief of police shall report to the city clerk the amount and value of the work performed and expense incurred in such work, whereupon the city shall issue execution as other executions are issued by the city for such value or expense, and the cost of the proceeding against such defaulting railroad company. To this execution a defense may be made and filed as in case of illegality, on oath, to the mayor and council of the city, and heard by them on five days' notice to such railroad company, such notice to be in writing signed by the city clerk and served by the chief of police. 
(Code 1965, § 20-18) 
State Law reference— Duty of railroad to maintain grade crossings, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-190; procedure to obtain maintenance of grade separation structures, protective devices and grade crossings, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-202. 
Chapter 94 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; superintendent of public works, § 2-181 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; electricity, § 22-91 et seq.; plumbing, § 22-121 et seq.; gas, § 22-201 et seq.; businesses, ch. 26; environment, ch. 46; sanitary facilities for dwellings, buildings and structures, § 46-152; electrical systems for dwellings, buildings and structures, § 46-153; floods, ch. 54; health and sanitation, ch. 58; mobile homes and mobile home parks, ch. 66; solid waste, ch. 78; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; utility easements in subdivisions, app. B, § 502.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Permit required prior to furnishing service to new or existing buildings or change of occupancy. 
(a)  No temporary utility services shall be furnished to any new building in the city or served by it, until a building permit for the new building is applied for and obtained. 
(b)  No utility service shall be furnished to any new or existing building in the city or served by it, until a certificate of occupancy is applied for and obtained by the building owner or agent. 
(c)  No utility service shall be furnished to any existing building where there is a change of occupancy until a certificate of occupancy is applied for and obtained by the building owner or agent. Not applicable to residential structures. 
(Code 1965, § 22-1; Ord. No. 2004-13, § 1, 7-19-2004) 
Sec. 94-2. - Application for service. 
Applications for light, gas or water supply must be made to the city clerk on forms to be furnished by the clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 22-2) 
Sec. 94-3. - Inspection of consumer's equipment. 
The officers responsible for the utility services furnished by the city, or their agents and assistants, may enter the premises of any consumer at any reasonable time to examine the pipes, fixtures and apparatus, the quantity and the manner of use thereof; and in case of any fraudulent representation on the part of the consumer, or unnecessary waste of service, the payment will be forfeited and service stopped. 
(Code 1965, § 22-3) 
Sec. 94-4. - Payment of charges; penalty for late payment. 
(a)  Gas, electricity and water rents shall be paid on or before the due date at the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Bills to customers for gas, water and electrical services shall be paid on or before the tenth day of the month following the month for which service was billed. If not paid by such date a penalty to be determined by the city council from time to time, expressed as a percentage of the outstanding amount due, shall be added thereto and paid therewith. If such charges are not paid by the 15th day of the month, service shall be discontinued. 
(Code 1965, §§ 22-5, 22-6) 
Sec. 94-5. - Service charges; transfer fee. 
(a)  Service charges for electricity, gas and water will be determined from time to time by the city council. 
(b)  Service charges are nonrefundable and a transfer fee set by the city council is charged for customers with city utility services who move from one location to another with the same services. 
(Code 1965, § 22-8; Ord. No. 2001-9, 6-18-2001; Ord. No. 2004-13, § 1, 7-19-2004) 
Sec. 94-6. - Deposits. 
(a)  Deposits for electric, gas and water service will be set by majority vote of the city council from time to time. 
(b)  The city shall not waive the deposit requirement. 
(c)  Deposits will be applied against amounts owed by a customer on the customer's final bill. However, deposits may be so applied earlier than service termination or the final bill if the customer has paid on time and has incurred no late charges or cut-offs for a period of at least 24 consecutive months. 
(Ord. No. 2015-07-A, § 1, 10-19-2015) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-07-A, § 1, adopted Oct. 19, 2015, repealed the former § 94-6 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former § 94-6 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1965, § 22-8; Ord. No. 2001-9, adopted June 18, 2001; and Ord. No. 2004-13, § 1, adopted July 19, 2004. 
Sec. 94-7. - Reconnection charge after cutoff for nonpayment of charges. 
The charge for reconnection after cutoff for nonpayment of a utility account shall be set by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1965, § 22-8; Ord. No. 2001-10, 6-18-2001) 
Sec. 94-8. - Meter tampering charges. 
Meter tampering charges will be set by the city council from time to time and provide for a first and second offense penalty. 
(Ord. No. 2001-10, 6-18-2001) 
Sec. 94-9. - Utility payment extensions. 
(a)  Payment extension request. Customers may receive two extensions for payment during each calendar year. Each payment extension request is to be filed, in person, by the customer on a form available at the office of the city clerk. Each payment extension request must be filed at the office of the city clerk no later than the payment due date. 
(b)  Failure to submit payment. Utility extensions shall be payable no later than 14 calendar days after the due date. At that time, the customer shall be required to submit payment, in full, for all outstanding payment balances. Failure to submit payment, in full, will result in disconnection of utility services. 
(Ord. No. 2004-13, § 1, 7-19-2004) 
Sec. 94-10. - Temporary utility service. 
Temporary electric and/or water service shall be made available for the purposes of new construction, remodeling, and/or premise clean-up. Each temporary utility service request is to be filed, in person, by the owner, agent or contractor for the owner on a form available at the office of the city clerk. Temporary utility service charges are due and payable at the time of the request. Temporary service charges shall be set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2004-13, § 1, 7-19-2004) 
Sec. 94-11. - Same day service. 
Applications for the provision of sanitation, water, sewer, electric and gas services must be completed with all fees paid by 1:30 p.m. for same day service. Same day service is provided Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, nights, and weekends. After-hour service may be available at the rate set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2004-13, § 1, 7-19-2004) 
Sec. 94-12. - Deceased persons. 
Utility services shall not be activated or continued in the name of a deceased person. Accounts in the names of deceased persons shall be terminated by the city and deposits returned, if applicable, to the deceased person's estate minus payment for outstanding utility charges. 
(Ord. No. 2004-13, § 1, 7-19-2004) 
Sec. 94-13. - Outdoor water use. 
(a)  Definitions. 
Address means the "house number" (a numeric or alphanumeric designation) that together with the street name, describes a physical location of a specific property. "Even numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, or no house number. "Odd numbered address" means a house number ending with the number 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9. 
Declared drought response level means one of four levels of drought that can be declared based on the severity of drought conditions, with one being the least severe and four being the most severe. 
(b)  Outdoor irrigation during non-drought periods. 
(1)  Persons may irrigate outdoors daily for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not create any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: 
a.  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian productions or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
b.  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable ordinances and state guidelines; 
c.  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
d.  Use of reclaimed waste water by a designated user from a system permitted by the Environmental Production Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources to provide reclaimed waste water; 
e.  Watering personal food gardens; 
f.  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
g.  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
h.  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
i.  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
j.  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
k.  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
l.  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
m.  Hydroseeding. 
(2)  This section governs outdoor irrigation activities during non-drought periods only. As to the restrictions on all other outdoor watering activities during non-drought periods, the provisions contained in subsection 94-13(c) of article I, chapter 94 of the City Code of Ordinances shall govern. 
(c)  Outdoor non-irrigation use schedule during non-drought periods. Except as provided in subsection (a) above regarding outdoor irrigation activities, and except as exempted in subsection (e) below, outdoor water use shall occur only as follows: 
(1)  Odd-numbered addresses: outdoor water use is allowed on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. 
(2)  Even-numbered addresses: outdoor water use is allowed on Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. 
(d)  Outdoor water use schedule during declared drought response levels. The city shall enforce drought response levels as declared by the director of the environmental protection division. 
(1)  Declared drought response level one. Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. to 12:00 midnight. 
a.  Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays and Sundays. 
b.  Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. 
c.  Use of hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing is prohibited. 
(2)  Declared drought response level two. Outdoor water use may occur on scheduled days within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. 
a.  Scheduled days for odd-numbered addresses are Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Sundays. 
b.  Scheduled days for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways are Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays. 
c.  The following uses are prohibited: 
1.  Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. 
2.  Washing hard surfaces, such as streets, gutters, sidewalks and driveways except when necessary for public health and safety. 
(3)  Declared drought response level three. Outdoor water use may occur on the scheduled day within the hours of 12:00 midnight to 10:00 a.m. 
a.  The scheduled day for odd-numbered addresses is Sunday. 
b.  The scheduled day for even-numbered addresses and golf course fairways is Saturday. 
c.  The following uses are prohibited: 
1.  Using hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting, public health, safety or flushing. 
2.  Washing hard surfaces such as streets, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, except when necessary for public health and safety. 
3.  Filling installed swimming pools except when necessary for health care or structural integrity. 
4.  Washing vehicles, such as cars, boats, trailers, motorbikes, airplanes, golf carts. 
5.  Washing buildings or structures except for immediate fire protection. 
6.  Non-commercial fund-raisers, such as car washes. 
7.  Using water for ornamental purposes, such as fountains, reflecting pools, and waterfalls except when necessary to support aquatic life. 
(4)  Declared drought response level four. No outdoor water use is allowed, other than for activities exempted in subsection (e) below, or as the EPD director may order. 
(e)  Exceptions to the rules in subsections (c) and (d) of this section 94-13. 
(1)  The rules set forth in subsections (c) and (d) above shall not apply to the following outdoor water uses: 
a.  Capture and re-use of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable local ordinances. 
b.  Re-use of gray water in compliance with applicable local ordinances. 
(2)  The following established landscape water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of the rules set forth in subsections (c) and (d) above. 
a.  Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater. 
b.  Irrigation of personal food gardens. 
(3)  With respect to the rules set forth in subsections (c) and (d) above, newly (in place less than 30 days) installed landscapes are subject to the following: 
a.  Irrigation of newly installed landscapes is allowed any day of the week, but only during allowed hours for the drought response level in effect, for a period of 30 days following installation. No watering is allowed during drought response level four. 
b.  For new landscapes installed by certified or licensed professionals, commercial exemptions apply. 
(4)  The following golf course outdoor water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of the rules set forth in subsections (c) and (d) above: 
a.  Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by EPD to provide reclaimed wastewater. 
b.  Irrigation of fairways during times of non-drought and declared drought response level one. 
c.  Irrigation of tees during times of non-drought and declared drought response levels one, two and three. 
d.  Irrigation of greens. 
(5)  The following commercial outdoor water uses are exempt from the outdoor water use schedules of the rules set forth in subsections (c) and (d) above: 
a.  Professionally certified or licensed landscapers, golf course contractors, and sports turf landscapers: during installation and 30 days following installation only. Professional landscapers must be certified or licensed for commercial exemptions to apply. 
b.  Irrigation contractors: during installation and as needed for proper maintenance and adjustments only. 
c.  Sod producers. 
d.  Ornamental growers. 
e.  Fruit and vegetable growers. 
f.  Retail garden centers. 
g.  Hydro-seeding. 
h.  Power-washing. 
i.  Construction sites. 
j.  Producers of food and fiber. 
k.  Car washes. 
l.  Other activities essential to daily business. 
m.  Watering-in of pesticides and herbicides on turf. 
(f)  Severability. The parts, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this section are severable. Should any part, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this section be rendered invalid by any court of law, the remaining parts, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases shall not be affected but shall continue in effect until amended or repealed by the city. 
(g)  Enforcement. 
(1)  No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this section. 
(2)  The city shall be the enforcement authority for this section. The mayor or city manager may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. 
(3)  Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the Magistrate Court or by any other legal means set forth in this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2004-10, § 1, 7-19-2004; Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 94-14. - Tampering prohibited. 
(a)  The following acts are declared to be unlawful: 
(1)  Tampering with or altering any utility or any line, wire, pipe or other devices or other instrumentality used in connection with the operation of the utility system of the City of Sylvester; 
(2)  Tampering with, resetting or otherwise interfering with any entering device used in the operation of the utility system of the City of Sylvester whether such device is owned by the City of Sylvester, the customer or otherwise, so as to cause it to run backward or to fail to operate or to register incorrectly;
